DEBATE.TITLE: NEW BUSINESS AFTER 11 P.M.: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That sessional order 48a (adjournment of House) and standing order 103 (11 o'clock rule) be suspended for this sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
(1) That a joint committee be appointed to inquire into and report on:

(a) all proposals for modifications or variations of the plan of layout of the City of Canberra and its environs published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette on 19 November 1925, as previously modified or varied, which are referred to the committee by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories; and
(b) such matters relating to the Australian Capital Territory as may be referred to it by-
(i) resolution of either House of the Parliament, or
(ii) the Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory.

(2) That the committee consist of 8 members, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate.
(4) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman.

(5) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(6) That 3 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(7) That the committee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(8) That the committee have power to move from place to place.
(9) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.

(10) That the committee have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the Joint Committees on the Australian Capital Territory appointed during previous Parliaments and of the House of Representatives and Senate Standing Committees on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure when sitting as a joint committee on matters relating to the Australian Capital Territory.

(11) That the resolutions of the House of Representatives of 2 November 1987 and 5 November 1987 and of the Senate of 26 October 1987 and 3 November 1987 relating to consideration of Australian Capital Territory matters by the House of Representatives and Senate Standing Committees on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure be rescinded.
(12) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(13) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this motion but a number of things must be said briefly about it. First of all, it must be said that it is very curious that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) should propose a motion of this sort-or indeed of any other sort-without explaining its purpose. So, for the record, it should at least be said that this is a motion proposing the establishment of a joint committee of the Parliament to inquire into the layout of the city of Canberra and its environs and other matters related to the Australian Capital Territory, being those matters that are referred to the Committee by a resolution of either House of the Parliament or the Minister responsible for the ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: At the very least, the House and the public should be made aware-and I trust they have now been made aware-of the fact that this motion proposes to establish a joint committee which will deal with matters associated with the city of Canberra and the ACT. It is obviously appropriate that there should be a parliamentary committee established to deal with matters relating to the ACT. Indeed, it should also be put on the record that there has been such a committee in the past. We have had a joint committee which dealt with the ACT. When the present Parliament was elected the Opposition, most notably in the form of Senator Reid, proposed and argued for the re-establishment of the joint committee which existed before the last election, but the Government for some reason opposed that or, at the very least, did nothing to re-establish the committee. So, it is good that at long last there is a proposal before the House to establish such a committee.

My understanding is that the matters relating to the ACT and the city of Canberra have, in the meantime, been dealt with by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, of which you yourself, Mr Acting Speaker, were a distinguished member for some time. However, these matters are now to be dealt with by a joint parliamentary committee.

The Opposition supports the thrust and substance of the motion. It will be in the interests of the people of the ACT, and particularly of Canberra, to have such a committee to deal with matters relating to the ACT and Canberra. However, the Opposition does not support the proposition that the committee should be confined to eight members only. Formerly there was a committee of 10 members, as I recall, and I do not understand why the number of committee members should be reduced. Nor do I understand why one of the Independent senators would be involved. The Australian Democrats hold themselves out as being concerned with much more lofty and widely embracing propositions and matters than those concerning the layout of the city of Canberra. I imagine that it is simply a deal with Senator Sanders to help him along life's rocky road. That certainly does not seem to be any sort of justification for allowing him or any other member of his party to sit on this Committee. We support the re-establishment of the Committee. It should be re-established in exactly the same way it was re-established before the last election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of comments about the remarks made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), Firstly, it should be made clear that the concerns about the planning of Canberra have continued to be addressed by the standing committees on transport, communications and infrastructure of both Houses, which have set up a joint subcommittee. That joint subcommittee has operated during the last two years. It has continued with the work of the previous Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, so the national concerns about planning in Canberra have continued to be addressed. That subcommittee arrangement was found to be quite cumbersome. It was unnecessarily unwieldy and caused some delays in the tabling of reports, and it was felt that a separate committee would be a more efficient way of handling these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the re-establishment of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory is in the interests not only of the people of the Australian Capital Territory but of the people of Australia as a whole. Canberra is the national capital, and it is very important that the national Parliament continue to have something to say about the way in which the national capital is planned. As a representative of part of Canberra I welcome that national involvement in the planning of Canberra and hope that it will continue forever. Canberra is a city that the whole of Australia can be proud of, and we want to keep it that way. We are more likely to keep it that way if the national Parliament continues to have some involvement in planning of Canberra.

Thirdly, the Committee will be small because we want to keep it operational. There are only four locally elected members. Three of those will probably want to be members of this Committee. One is a Minister and is therefore unlikely to have the time. One or two other members of both Houses who have electorates close by would want to be members and there are two or three spaces for other representatives of Australia as a whole. That seems to be a large enough committee. I hope that it will work effectively. I welcome the Opposition's support for this motion and look forward to the Committee working effectively.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1989-90[COGNATE BILLS:SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1989-90SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1989-90]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 May, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with Supply Bill (No. 2) and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. That being the case, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in leading the debate from the Opposition side on the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1989-90, the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1989-90 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90. These Bills make interim provision for the appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the services of government for the first five months of 1989-90. The Opposition will not be opposing these Bills as they form an integral part of the budgetary process. While we are not opposing the Bills specifically, the coalition will reiterate its dissatisfaction in general with the Government's continued mismanagement of the Australian economy. To highlight this I shall move an amendment which will be seconded by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``That be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes:
(1) Australia's $95.47 billion net foreign debt at the end of December 1988 and its continuing balance of payments deficit on the current account which increased by $1,624 million during March 1989;
(2) that the Government is in danger of losing control of monetary policy through persistent attempts to encourage bullish sentiment in financial markets and talk down the dollar;
(3) the Government's high risk economic strategy of sole reliance on high interest rates, whilst increasing Government spending and granting wage increases unrelated to productivity;
(4) the impact of the Government's high interest rate, high tax and high inflation policies on the living standards of all Australians; and

(5) the failure of the Government to address Australia's deep-seated economic problems which require the freeing up of the labour market, a comprehensive micro-economic reform agenda, and policies designed to enhance competitiveness and increase savings''.

I expect that other shadow Ministers and members from this side of the House will discuss in detail aspects of these Bills and their effects on individual portfolios. I want to address myself today to the current state of the Australian economy and to make some points about the current economic debate in Australia. First, one must recognise that partial indicators of the state of economic activity are very mixed at present. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other Government members have argued on occasions that they believe that activity has peaked. They suggest that interest rates will not have to go any higher and that monetary policy will not need to be tightened. However, a realistic assessment of the facts suggest a quite different story.

While it is true that some indicators, for example, retail trade activity, have recently shown falls, suggesting from that point of view that activity in certain areas may be peaking or have peaked, a number of other indicators suggest a quite different story. For example, the recently released ANZ job advertisement figures were up 3.4 per cent in April, following a 3.9 per cent rise in March, and their being up 28.5 per cent over the past year I think suggests sustained strong labour market conditions. It probably suggests that it is a reasonably reliable indication that, overall, economic conditions are pretty tight. Similarly, new motor vehicle registrations increased by 4.1 per cent in March, following a 14.7 per cent rise in February. They have increased by 31.9 per cent over the last 12 months. Dwelling approvals were up 1.8 per cent in March, following a 1.2 per cent rise in February, and over the last 12 months they were up 21 per cent.

However, some of the other indicators also suggest sustained strength in the economy. The demand for credit is, under the Government's strategy, the key indicator, I would suggest, because it is relying on high interest rates in order to pull back economic activity and, presumably, that process works by those interest rates bearing down on the demand for credit, although the demand for credit has not shown a significant shift downwards in recent months. While it appears to have slowed to some extent, it has been a marginal slowing.

The strength of the figures in this regard should be of major concern to the Government, which is prepared to pretend that activity has peaked. Similarly, imports have remained very strong. In a trend sense in particular, they have remained very strong, as have the employment numbers, with the possible exception of the most recent figure. We are due to receive another number this week. However, overall, even those two are lagging indicators. I think, at best, the picture is mixed, and, as I see it, there is certainly no clear evidence that activity has peaked, even though the Government has already cranked interest rates up to what are disturbingly high levels.

Of course, all this is against the background of growing fundamental problems in the Australian economy. The Government's basic economic strategy, as outlined at Budget time last year, is wildly off track. Yet the Treasurer has not really expressed any genuine concern about that. He has made no attempt in the last nine months to adjust policy to any significant extent to deal with that problem. He just let things drift on, hoping to get by with minimal increases in interest rates. The reason is, of course, that he is running not an economic strategy but a political strategy. He is running an election vote-buying strategy, which has very little to do with the fundamental problems that are before us. This is a Treasurer who just a few years ago, in early 1986, made the following statement on the John Laws radio show in Sydney:
If this Government get the adjustment . . . and a sensible economic policy, then Australia is basically done for. We will just end up being a third rate economy-a banana republic.

That is now a very famous statement by the Treasurer. It provided him with a very real opportunity in terms of economic management to shift significantly the direction and the pace of economic adjustment in this country. Yet if we look back over the period since May 1986 we will see that there has been virtually no additional policy adjustment. There has been a bit of an attempt to tighten Government expenditure, but that has been marginal. Rather, there has been a consistent policy of disinformation, backed up by virtually no economic strategy.

The best evidence of the nature of that economic strategy has been provided by some recent comments of the Treasurer at the time of the May statement last year when briefing his Caucus colleagues about how this was the budgetary strategy that would get them back into office. He said that all the nervous nellies in the marginal seats should not worry, that this basic strategy would get them back into office. And then, at the time of the last Budget, he boasted that this was the strategy that would `bring home the bacon'. Over that period, all he really talked about was delivering tax cuts from 1 July this year and paying wage increases quite unrelated to productivity. This was a blatant vote-buying exercise rather than any serious attempt to deal with our economic problems.

The Treasurer has produced virtually no new information on the economy over the last nine or 10 months. Yet, we observe the fact that his Budget forecasts are wildly off track. For example, we were told at the time of the Budget last year that the current account deficit this year would come in at about $9 1/2 billion, that inflation would fall to 4 1/2 per cent, that wage growth would be contained, and so on. Yet here we are only about three-quarters of the way through the financial year and the balance of payments deficit is looking like coming in at about $16 billion or $17 billion, which is substantially above the $9.5 billion that was forecast. Inflation looks like sticking at around 7 or 8 per cent throughout this year, despite the attempts on the part of the Government to fiddle that number, to lower that number artificially on two occasions in the last nine or 10 months. There is mounting evidence, almost on a daily basis, that wage pressures are not going to come in in line with the Budget estimate but that wage increases and average earnings increases will be significantly above those forecast. Yet, throughout this whole period there has been no recognition by the Government that its strategy is in tatters, that it has run a very high risk economic strategy and that it has now put the economic well-being of most Australians significantly at risk.

It is important to note in this regard that the Treasurer has consistently ignored warnings. In political terms, one might understand that he would ignore the Opposition's warnings which consistently have been on the record over the last 12 or 18 months. But why should he ignore the warnings of some people who are notionally quite close to him or who have statutory independence on which to base their views? I will cite two examples. The Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia has warned the Treasurer on three separate occasions in the last few months about the magnitude of our economic problems. On 29 March, when speaking at the award for Businessman of the Year, the Governor said:
It is too early to say that a downturn is at hand. We have to hold to tougher policies until it is clear that results are on the board.

That was the first warning. That was followed up on 27 April when the Governor, speaking to the Australian Institute of Bankers, talked of activity running too strongly and fundamental economic problems still remaining.

Of course he warned quite flatly that inflation rates of about 7 per cent were unacceptable and that further policy adjustment was required. Finally, there was the incident last week when the Governor, in accepting an award from the Australian Finance Conference, prefaced his response by saying:
This is no time to be easing monetary policy.

He alluded to the fact that in making that statement he had not bothered to check with his political masters. So the Treasurer has received three warnings and, generally, those three warnings have been ignored.

Similarly, the Treasurer's previous economic adviser, Professor Barry Hughes, who left the Treasurer's staff early last year, has subsequently warned the Treasurer on several occasions about the nature of the economic situation and the extent to which it is slipping through his old boss's fingers. For example, at the time of last year's Budget, Professor Hughes warned the Treasurer that his forecasts for the balance of payments, inflation and wages were unattainable. More recently, in writing in a bank report-I think it was the First Boston Australia Ltd's economic assessment-he warned the Treasurer that he was `caught in a balance of payments stranglehold'. Of course, most recently on the Face to Face program, on 9 April, Professor Hughes warned his old boss about his `high risk strategy'. In order to get the attention of his old boss, he pointed out in very blatant terms:
We are going to go through 1989 with our fingers crossed that something nasty does not happen.

Two major individuals in this country-one who was particularly close to the Treasurer as his personal adviser and the other the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, one of the more significant commentators on the economic scene and a significant economic manager-have each warned the Treasurer on three separate occasions. The Treasurer has ignored those warnings on all of those six occasions.

The fact is that the Treasurer goes on with this blatant process of disinformation hoping to get by until an early election some time after July this year when he will run to the polls and try to convince the Australian electorate that the tax cuts that he is giving from 1 July and the wage increases that have been foreshadowed in the second part of this year should be sufficient to give honourable members opposite another chance in government. The electorate will not be fooled by that. The electorate is fully aware that, in doing that, the Treasurer is only giving back part of what he has already taken. The electorate will also quickly become aware that any temporary relief that is given from 1 July will not be sustained; it will be quickly clawed back by higher inflation, higher interest rates and further bracket creep. It is important to focus on the significance of that.

Overall, the best way to summarise the increased tax burden on the average Australian is to point out that in the last four years to 1989-90 the Government has increased its income tax revenue through bracket creep-the community has been pushed into higher and higher tax brackets by an amount of about $10 billion cumulatively over that period. This Government is therefore giving back roughly half of that income in the form of tax cuts from 1 July. Also the housing mortgage interest rates have increased since June or July of last year from about 13 1/2 per cent to-this now looks like being the across the board figure-16 1/2 per cent. This is a 3 per cent increase in the home loan mortgage interest rate. This implies a very significant increase in home loan mortgage repayments for the average Australian. I think that every one per cent interest on an average mortgage is worth about $40 a week. The prospective tax cuts and wage increases pale into insignificance relative to those orders of magnitude.

Any close observer of our current economic scene and anyone who shows concern about the fact that maybe the economy is still significantly overheated and has not yet peaked would be very concerned about the prospect that inflation would run away on this Government, in the course of the next six to 12 months, quickly clawing back any benefits that those tax cuts might bring from 1 July. They will also be concerned that that inflation will push them into those higher tax brackets that the Government has stuck with. It has increased the take via bracket creep and so the benefits from any tax cuts will be quickly clawed back through higher inflation, higher interest rates or bracket creep. The worst feature of the Government's current economic mismanagement is the blatant cynicism with which it has addressed our problems, acting like there is nothing wrong and using the, `Don't worry, be happy' strategy: `Don't worry, everything will be fine. We will give you tax cuts from 1 July. We will give you wage increases later in the year. Just vote for us'. As Barry Hughes has warned and as the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia has warned, this is a very high risk economic strategy.

However, the Government's cynicism has gone further than that. Having a background in financial markets, particular concerned at present as to how that cynicism has gone through to the financial community. We saw yesterday the most recent example of blatant market cynicism. The Treasurer has lost all credibility in financial markets. He is a guy who used to go out and court them, trying to coerce them, cajole them and influence them in various ways to support him, and they did. They stayed with him for quite some time. But we now see that he has lost total credibility. Now every time he makes a statement about economic policy, financial markets are very cynical about what it means for them. Yesterday, with the change of leadership on our side, financial markets became bullish very quickly, with pressure to push interest rates down. The reason was that there was an expectation that, in light of these leadership changes, the Government and the Treasurer would push for an early election and that the Treasurer would be in there pushing interest rates down in the run-up to that election-a reasonable bet on the part of financial markets.

This very cynical behaviour by financial markets has been seen on several occasions now from about the middle of April, when the financial markets seem particularly to have left the Treasurer. We can go back to a number of reasons as to why that has happened. One, of course, is the fact that the Treasurer keeps persisting with the line, `There is nothing wrong. Don't worry, be happy'. Every time a bad balance of payments figure comes along, or a bad inflation figure come along, or he fiddles the consumer price index (CPI) or whatever, the markets say, `This guy is not for real. He is not the slightest bit interested in dealing with any of our economic problems', and of course, they now vote with their feet.

That basic cynicism, as continuing pieces of new economic data disprove some of the things the Treasurer has said months before, or months before that, is compounded by some explicit statements by both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that interest rates have peaked, that activity has turned down, that they do not want to see any further adjustment of monetary policy, or whatever the particular statement might be. There were a number of such statements in the weeks from the middle to the end of April, which compounded this inherently cynical attitude which was growing on the part of financial markets.

Financial markets also seem to have come to the view that this Treasurer in particular wants an early election. The story going around is that he is just looking for a crack of light and that as soon as he sees it he will barge straight into it. So anything he says against that sort of belief is generally counterproductive in terms of the reaction of financial markets. This has caused a particular problem in financial markets because a very bullish sentiment has developed in those markets, particularly the bill futures market and the long bond market, from the latter part of April to the early part of May, causing some very real problems for the Reserve Bank. We have had an unbelievable situation in recent days, probably reflecting some conflict between the Reserve Bank and the Treasury, and/or the Treasurer in particular, about the conduct of monetary policy. The Government wants a bullish sentiment designed to get interest rates down, to create a climate in which interest rates may begin to fall, before the Reserve Bank is ready to wear that.

Let us look at the comments made by the Governor to which I referred before. Let us recall those warnings the Governor gave as recently as last week. It is clear that the Governor is not prepared, at this stage, to ease monetary policy. He said the other day, `The last thing we should do in the present circumstances is to contemplate easing monetary policy'. The Governor of the Reserve Bank has been forced into the position of having to push official cash rates up further over the last two to 2 1/2 weeks in order to stem this bullish sentiment. He has also had to give various other signal to financial markets in the way he has dealt in financial markets and the speech opportunities he has had. He has had to use those to send direct warnings out to financial markets to the effect that this early bullish sentiment is unjustified; that interest rates really have not peaked and that, as far as he is concerned, there is still a long way to go in terms of policy adjustment by Government at the present time.

Interestingly, over the past couple of weeks, we have had a very bullish market sentiment forcing down bank bill futures interest rates and long bond rates, while the Governor of the Reserve Bank has been in there on a daily basis pushing up official interest rates and actually tightening monetary policy significantly over the past two weeks or so in order to try to stem that unjustified bullish sentiment in financial markets. This has been created by a totally irresponsible attitude on the part of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister in terms of the sorts of statements that they have made about the economy and the sorts of policy responses that they have been prepared to acknowledge are necessary.

The tragedy is that our problems in this country are very real. At the present time we sit in a set of economic circumstances that are much worse than they were in early 1986 when the Treasurer referred to the possibility our our slipping into banana republic status. Indeed, on the international scene, we are not openly being compared with other countries which have major debt burdens. We rank very highly; in fact, I think we rank No. 3 in terms of, for example, indebtedness to international banks; and we rank very highly in most of the international debt league tables. The situation is becoming worse as every month goes by, every time we have another $1.5 billion current account deficit number, for example. It is interesting the way the press now refers to `1.6 billion'. That 1.6 does not look too large but, if one writes it out in full with all the noughts, it is a very large number. Every day that goes on to the bottom line and every day it adds to our international indebtedness. We are now looking at the prospect of our gross international debts being around $130 billion to $135 billion. We risk the possibility that, if this Government's economic strategy ultimately results in a loss of confidence in financial markets and particularly foreign exchange markets-and I think that that is a possibility-there will be further downward pressure on our currency, and those debt levels could blow out one more time. Debts have already gone up fourfold since 1983 and we are precariously poised at the present time, risking another significant debt blow-out, balance of payments crisis, and so on. It is for that reason that Barry Hughes, the Treasurer's old economic adviser, warned him that he was caught in a balance of payments stranglehold.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would concede that most of that is private debt rather than public debt?

—No, roughly 50 per cent is private debt and 50 per cent is public debt, but it is the total indebtedness figure that is of concern from the point of view of the Australian economy. It is a debt burden that every Australian carries, indirectly or directly, and on a daily basis it is growing. The other day I was fascinated to read that there is now a debt clock in New York. As the United States moves into the position of becoming a major debtor country, it is now starting to focus on the fact that its debt rises every second of every hour of every day. So this clock ticks over in New York for the benefit of all people to see just how fast and alarmingly their debt problem is growing at the present time. Recognising the size of the two countries, our debt problem is much bigger. We have a more significant problem than the US. We need a debt clock and it should be placed out at the front of Parliament House. We need to let that clock tick over on a daily basis to focus the attention of the electorate on what our indebtedness means for them. Every man, woman and child in this country is already committed to the extent of about $7,500 per head, which is nearly $20,000 for the average family. That is a significant commitment in terms of weekly interest repayments for everyone in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning I read a report from one of the major banks in Sydney to the effect that it fears that our interest debt burden will increase to about $12 billion-about $1 billion a month-in the course of the next 12 months. That is pretty alarming stuff. Yet the Government sits around and acts as if we do not have a problem. In particular, the Government plays these cynical vote buying exercises, putting at risk our economic well-being and, as I say, risking an over large debt crisis and a balance of payments crisis. The real problem is that we have some fundamental economic problems in this country which have not been dealt with. Our country is essentially still a primary commodity exporting country. This Government is not concerned to do anything about diversifying our export base.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—It is. I do not see any evidence that it is concerned. For example, a few months ago the Treasurer was talking about the need to stimulate savings; about how we were not ever going to get out of our balance of payments difficulties until we actually did stimulate savings. I will try to find that quote, because I think it is a very important one from the point of view of what I am talking about. Anyway, he said that the fundamental need at the present time is to stimulate savings in Australia. Yet he has consistently ruled out taking any measures that would stimulate private sector savings and, most recently, he has decided to reduce the prospective public sector savings by 50 per cent. He has a prospective public sector surplus next year of $10 billion, $11 billion, $12 billion, whatever it is, and he is reducing that by 50 per cent. He is not worried about generating savings; he is not worried about solving our balance of payments problem from that point of view at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Equally, we have a government here that prevaricates, delays, ducks and weaves over an issue as fundamentally important to our exports as the third runway at Mascot. The Government claims to be interested in developing our tourist capacity, yet it cannot make a decision over six or seven years to build a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The truth is that it should have built the third runway and accelerated the process of building the second airport. Equally, it has prevaricated over the decision of Wesley Vale, an undertaking that promises to be a $1 billion project in this country. It is not seriously interested in exports from those points of view.

Similarly, the Government talks about tax reform another area in which it has to make some fundamental changes. What has this Government done about tax reform? Its idea of tax reform is more taxes. Today in this Parliament we are about to debate a whole range of new taxes on superannuation. The Government has introduced a host of other new taxes. What tax reform means to this Government is increasing the tax burdens on the average Australian. It has absolutely nothing to do with genuinely reforming tax. We have a tax system that discriminates against savings. Why on earth will the Government live with a tax system which discriminates against savings and encourages people to go into debt? There are fundamentally the wrong sorts of signals coming from our tax system for a country like Australia.

The Government has also got-and I will make this my final point-a blind spot on industrial relations and wages. It has just been decisively rolled by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Last year Bill Kelty was talking with the Treasurer about a tax- wage trade-off. What trade-off? All we got was an across-the-board wage increase unrelated to productivity, on top of that a tax cut. What has also been committed is a host of increases in public sector expenditure in the name of the social wage. What price this special relationship with the trade union movement? Until those problems are addressed, all this puts this country at risk. Time will tell, and in the passage of the rest of this year or early next year watch the financial markets vote with their feet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.
—The honourable member for McPherson will have an opportunity to speak at a later time in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my first speech to this House, which I made over 30 years ago, I spoke of my experiences as a prisoner of war (POW) under the Japanese during the Second World War. I spoke of the time at Hintock Road camp when I served under Lieutenant-Colonel Weary Dunlop on the construction of the Burma-Siam railway, and I spoke of the collective principles by which we lived under Weary's leadership during those long years. I stated in my initial speech that in our prisoner of war camp we lived by the principles of the fit looking after the sick, the young looking after the old and the rich looking after the poor. I might say at this time that my whole POW experience had an enormous influence on me, whether it was in Timor, Java, Singapore, on the Burma-Thailand railway or, finally, in Japan where I saw the atomic explosion that destroyed Nagasaki at the end of the war. That experience helped to mould my thoughts during my development as a man and particularly during my political life.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with deep regret and a sense of sadness that I must once again relive these experiences before the House in what will be my last parliamentary term representing the people of Australia. It is particularly distressing that the issue of adequate compensation for former prisoners of war of the Japanese should have to be confronted at a time when we have a Labor Government in this country, a Government which I had hoped would carry out its moral obligations of undertaking a more equitable sharing of the wealth of this nation amongst all people and of implementing the principles which I have striven to achieve throughout my political life.

It is about the needs of those former service men and women who were imprisoned by the Imperial Japanese Army during the Second World War that I wish to direct my remarks today. Four decades have now passed since Australian soldiers of the 8th Division were captured after the fall of Singapore and the islands which now form the nation of Indonesia and imprisoned by the Japanese for 3 1/2 years. Those captured were subsequently subjected to physical and psychological stress which is barely credible; malnutrition, multiple infections, inadequate shelter, prolonged marches, work to the point of total exhaustion, capricious violence and humiliation. At various times work party forces of these prisoners were sent to other areas, the most notorious of which was the Burma-Thailand railway construction project.

The physical and mental deprivation suffered and endured led to the deaths of over one-third of those prisoners during captivity. Individual circumstances which could be described only as horrific, saw even greater death rates. The story of the ill-fated F Force shows the extreme likelihood of death by starvation, ill-treatment and disease. Here there was no heat and excitement of battle, yet the hardships and privations endured by these prisoners were infinitely greater than any likely to be met in active service. The casualties were unfortunately of a greater proportion. In just 12 months the members of F Force lost 3,087 men out of a total of 6,998, and 1,058 of those who lost their lives were Australians.

It is hardly surprising that the occurrence of illness suffered by these servicemen was abnormally high. The personal reminiscences of the medical officers who served in the Japanese prison camps during the war dramatically highlight the medical condition of these men. Dr Ian Duncan, a veteran of the Burma-Thailand railway, spoke during a 1985 Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio series Australians under Nippon of the extent of disease and infestation amongst these servicemen. Dr Duncan said:
At the end of the war I interviewed every Australian and English soldier in my camp; I was the only medical officer in the camp and I thought it was my duty to record their disabilities.
Dr Duncan went on to make the following very interesting comments:

You say to them, `What diseases have you had as a prisoner of war?'. `Nothing much, Doc, nothing much at all'. `Did you have malaria?'. `Oh, yes, I had malaria'. `Did you have dysentery?'. `Oh, yes, I had dysentery'. `Did you have beri-beri?'. `Oh, yes, I had beri-beri'. `Did you have pellagra?'. `Yes, I had pellagra but nothing very much'. All these are lethal diseases, but that was the norm . . . everyone had them. Therefore they accepted them as normal.

Clinical evidence reinforces the poignant nature of the high incidence of disease and illness suffered by prisoners of war of the Japanese. In surveys conducted by Dr Kerry Goulston, formerly the senior specialist in gastroenterology at the Concord Repatriation Hospital, and recorded in the July 1985 edition of the Medical Journal of Australia, the disproportionately excessive incidence of potentially fatal disease amongst ex-prisoners of war compared with non-prisoners of war is clearly demonstrated. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which highlights the mean rate of occurrence of specific illnesses during World War II as recalled by ex-prisoners of war compared with non-prisoners of war.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This table shows several alarmingly high occurrences of disease. Beri-beri was contracted by 83 per cent of ex-prisoners of war compared with just one per cent of non-prisoners of war. Leg ulcers were developed by 60 per cent of ex-prisoners of war compared with 13 per cent of non-prisoners of war. What was called happy feet-jumpy, painful feet associated with vitamin deficiency-was developed by 49 per cent of ex-prisoners of war compared with 4 per cent of non-prisoners of war. Cholera was contracted by 7 per cent of ex-prisoners of war, whilst none of the non-prisoners of war who were interviewed had this crippling, lethal disease.

SPEECH.PARA: I could give graphic descriptions of all these diseases. For instance, prisoners with beri-beri would wake up with their faces and legs swollen abnormally. One could push one's thumb into their skin and the thumb mark would stay there. Some of these people died of beri-beri through strangulation of the heart. The smell and stench of an ulcer ward is still with me today. The odour of dead flesh is indescribable. Worst of all was the cholera epidemic. One would go out to one's work place and come back that night to find that one's comrade had caught this disease and aged 50 years in a day. Cholera sufferers would excrete from the rear, the penis and the mouth the saline in their bodies. Their bodies would dehydrate. Their eyes would sink into their heads, their temples would become deeply sunken in and they would turn a grey-green colour. It was miraculous that many of those people were saved through doctors like Weary Dunlop and others strapping them down and inserting a drip in their arms to try to replace saline into their bodies.

I have talked about the ill-fated H Force, which I mentioned in my maiden speech, which was a group of British soldiers. I am not passing a reflection on the British, but they did not have the same comradeship that we had. Over 400 of them came into an area adjoining the Hintock road camp. The wet season started a few days after they arrived. In the old British tradition the officers took the best tents, the senior NCOs took the next best and the men got the dregs. They hardly did any work at all. Of those 400 men less than 50 walked out of that camp six weeks later, and of that 50 about 25 survived. One would walk out of a morning to go to work and have to walk over the corpses-that would be one's starting point.

The truth is that most of those people died from cholera and some of dysentery. At Kanchanaburi Cemetery in Thailand the period in which these people died can be seen. They died in the second half of 1943. That this occurred at that time is a tragedy. Prime Minister Hawke visited that cemetery recently and at Sir Ninian Stephen's farewell dinner Hawkie called me over and said, `Tom, I was so deeply shocked at that experience and witnessing that those people died in such numbers in that period'.

I am being dramatic today because I want to place on record an account of what these people went through and I want to make sure that the people who will make the decisions understand some of the problems that these prisoners of war were confronted with.

The medical conditions of these servicemen is therefore hardly surprising. For 3 1/2 years these prisoners of war of the Japanese were forced to work on a diet grossly deficient in energy and vitamins. They were exposed to numerous infections, including diphtheria, bacterial dysentery, respiratory infections, tropical ulcers, malaria and various gastrointestinal infections. Added to these diseases were grievous forms of maltreatment, the spectacle of the death of their comrades and the fear that they themselves would die before release. They were denied letters from their loved ones and this contributed materially to their mental anguish.

During the construction of the railway men worked under savage pressure for up to 16 hours a day for months on end without a rest. Many of the prisoners, particularly the weakest, never saw in the daylight the squalid huts where they resided. They went out to work before daylight and got back in the dark. As a result of this protracted, intense, emotional and physical deprivation suffered during imprisonment, the number of men who returned to Australia from Japanese prisoner of war camps was dramatically fewer than those imprisoned by the dreaded fascists of Italy and the Nazis of Germany and those in war torn Europe.

The figures are a telling indictment of the inhuman suffering of the prisoners of war of the Japanese. As I have previously said in the House, 550,000 Australians served in all theatres of war. There were 19,000 killed in action and of the 8,000 prisoners of war taken by the German and Italian forces 7,700 came back. I am not undermining the fact that less than 4 per cent of those prisoners died because that is bad enough. But there were 22,000 prisoners of war of the Japanese, of whom only 14,000 returned. Incredibly, 36 per cent of the servicemen imprisoned by the Japanese died in captivity. This suffering and dying of so many men and women as prisoners of war is a distinguishing experience of Australian history.

The postwar period saw little in the way of compensation for these horrific conditions suffered by the prisoners of war of the Japanese. Indeed, the refusal of the Australian Government-both the Labor Government of 1946 and the Menzies conservative Government of 1949-to allow prisoners of war to collect their entitlement to 3 1/2 years worth of subsistence allowances was seen by many ex-prisoners of war as a rebuke by the very nation for which so many lives had been sacrificed.

Many of the servicemen serving in Indonesia, which was formerly called Dutch East India, were guinea pigs. The group of Australian soldiers from the Middle East landed at Java. A battalion was put onto trucks and they were driven all over Java to make the Japanese think that there were divisions of Australians on the island. On Timor, where I served, there were 1,000 Australians to combat about 24,000 Japanese. We inflicted many casualties, more than in any other theatre of war in the Malaysian and East Indies campaign as a matter of fact. My comrade Sir John Carrick was on Timor with me at the time.

The long period of conservative government following the war saw little in the way of material benefits for veterans in general and specifically for ex-prisoners of war. In 1974 the Whitlam Government represented a significant shift from this general indifference to the continuing suffering of ex-prisoners of war. Free medical, hospital, dental and optical treatment was made available to all ex-prisoners of war irrespective of whether the injuries were war caused or not. Sadly, since March 1983-or really since 1985, but the Government responsible for this has been in office since March 1983-there has been a substantial erosion of these benefits. I set this out comprehensively in my speech during a grievance debate in October 1988. Whilst these erosions represented across the board cuts for all veterans many Japanese former prisoners of war were both deeply hurt and financially disadvantaged as a consequence. Since I last spoke on this issue in the House in October last year I have had meetings with the Prime Minister, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), other Ministers of the Hawke Cabinet and senior public servants. In all cases I have consistently put forward the case for just remuneration for ex-prisoners of war. Up to this stage I have received a sympathetic hearing from all those involved. I am not trying to butter anybody up, but the Prime Minister has been very understanding of the situation.

The Hawke Government's positive action in relation to the establishment of an extreme disablement adjustment to correct the anomaly whereby the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension would not be available to any veteran who had turned 65 years of age or had ceased employment demonstrates an understanding of the care required for all veterans. But it is imperative that specific action be taken to compensate those ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese who suffered more than any other servicemen during the Second World War in the defence of freedom and democracy. Australia was once at the forefront in the treatment of and compensation for ex-prisoners of war but it is now well behind other comparable countries, particularly Canada and the United States.

I am troubled that I have to make this speech on behalf of my fellow former prisoners of war at this stage in our history, 44 years after the cessation of hostilities. Of the 14,000 prisoners of war of the Japanese I mentioned who were fortunate enough to survive the horrors and deprivation of life in the camps fewer than 6,000 are alive today. About a third of these survivors, due to the severity of their medical condition, are now receiving the TPI rate of pension. Senior officials in the Department of Veterans' Affairs have informed me that of these former prisoners of war of the Japanese who are still alive some 70 per cent will die from war related illnesses or injury. Their wives will be able to receive the war widows pension.

It has been made abundantly clear from a vast array of medical evidence that the medical condition of those ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese still alive remains significantly worse than that of ex-servicemen in general. Several recent studies undertaken by doctors pre-eminent in their field state conclusively that former prisoners of war of the Japanese in World War II continue to have a significantly increased risk of illness and death compared with other servicemen who served in the Pacific rim but who were not prisoners of war. As prisoners soldiers were grossly undernourished, overworked and subject to many tropical diseases, as well as maltreatment by their captors. The illnesses suffered by these ex-prisoners therefore bear direct relationship to the nature of these war time experiences.

A study conducted by Professor Christopher Tennant of the psychiatric unit of the Royal North Shore Hospital reported in 1986 in the journal Psychological Medicine that prisoners of war had significantly more anxiety and depressive neuroses than a comparative sample of combatants from Pacific theatres of war who were not captured. (Extension of time granted) In terms of clinical psychiatric status prisoners of war of the Japanese had a greater risk of having a post-war clinical psychiatric disorder than did the comparison group-71 per cent compared to 46 per cent. Similarly, a study by Dr Kerry Goulston of the Concord Repatriation Hospital, reported in the July 1985 edition of the Medical Journal of Australia, on gastro-intestinal morbidity among World War II prisoners of war concluded, in part, that 25 per cent of ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese suffered from duodenal ulcers compared with only 10 per cent of the non-prisoner of war group. Twenty-five per cent of prisoners of war had one or more admissions to hospital for gastric disease compared with 14 per cent of non-prisoners of war.

A further study of post-war mortality among Australian World War II prisoners of the Japanese, which examines the impact of detention as a prisoner of war on post-war survival and disease-specific mortality, reported in as late as the April 1989 edition of the Medical Journal of Australia:
From 1945 to 1959, the ex-prisoner of war group had estimated mortality rates which were four times those of the comparison group.

The article goes on to point out that former prisoners of the Japanese in World War II continue to have a significantly increased risk of death compared with that of other servicemen who served in the South West Pacific and South East Asia but who were not prisoners of war. Further detailed medical evidence, which clearly points to the same fundamental conclusions, is all publicly available. It indicates the urgency of the situation and the real need for action to be taken to recompense ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese in the forthcoming Budget. Action not taken immediately will prove too late for the ever dwindling survivors of the Japanese prison camps of the Second World War.

What is required is a full restoration of all the benefits granted to the ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese under the Whitlam Government of 1974-benefits which in the interim have slowly been eroded. These include the provision of free medical, hospital, dental and optical treatment for all veterans, the proper appreciation of ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese in relation to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and the removal of the statutory patient contribution which currently applies to war veterans who require nursing home care. It must also include a revision of the legislation affecting liability for the Medicare Levy which now means that an ex-prisoner of war whose spouse has a private income is not eligible for exemption from this one per cent tax, which was previously the case. I want to stress that if the spouse or partner is working then that person should have to pay the one per cent Medicare levy. I am stressing that the prisoners of war of the Japanese, who were formerly exempted, whether their wives were working or not, should be exempted from that one per cent levy. Because the totally and permanently incapacitated pension is not available to those ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese who have turned 65 years of age and have ceased employment, and because the Government has already set a precedent in the extreme disablement adjustment available to all veterans, I would argue that the Government should create in this Budget a special pension for ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese only. I stress the word `only' because I am specifically talking about prisoners of war of the Japanese. Those prisoners of war of the Japanese entitled to this special pension should be in need and should not already be in receipt of a TPI pension. This special pension should be paid at a rate higher than that of the extreme disablement adjustment and the entitlement for this special pension should be assessed in a compassionate way.

Finally, some politicians and public servants argue that there should be no special cases in dealing with precedence in regard to veterans. But there have been special cases such as the case set in 1974 when the ex-prisoners of war were granted free medical, hospital, dental and optical treatment. I hope I have given enough evidence in my speech to clearly identify that the ex-Japanese prisoners of war are different from other veterans. I think if we were to ask the veterans themselves they would recognise this proposal. The sacrifices of the ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese are unequalled as a group in the defence of freedom and democracy in the Second World War. No other group suffered as they did. I am seeking justice for the surviving ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese. I hope the Government will give compassionate consideration to their claims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is something of an understatement to say that, following the remarks of the father of the House, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), it is a bit hard to get cranked up and back into a political frame of mind. I want to acknowledge the contribution made by the honourable member and I commend what he had to say to all my colleagues in this place. His remarks in relation to the conditions of prisoners of the Japanese during the Second World War are born of first hand experience and they were, therefore, very welcome indeed. They reflect his years of concern. It is something of a coincidence that my own father was captured on Timor. I guess you did not see him, Tom. Also, my father-in-law was captured and ended up on the railway line. So I have more reason than some others to understand what the honourable member was saying. Madam Deputy Speaker, I am finding it difficult to continue along these lines, so I will now get back to the cut and thrust of politics.

SPEECH.PARA: The Supply Bill (No. 1) 1989-90, the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1989-90 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90 seek interim authority for Commonwealth expenditure not allowed for in the appropriations, which the House has already approved for the period up to when the next Budget is brought down. The amounts dealt with in these Bills represent about $14 billion, which is some 16 per cent of estimated Commonwealth outlays in the 1989-90 financial year. As the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) said in his second reading speech, Supply Bill (No. 1) deals with a 14.5 per cent increase in spending over the amount provided last year in the equivalent Bill, while Supply Bill (No. 2) seeks authority for an amount which is 46 per cent greater than that provided for in last year's legislation.

The Bills offer the opportunity to discuss questions of fiscal policy and its relationship to the role of government. The spending outlined in these Bills makes clear that the Labor Government's claims in relation to a tight fiscal policy are little more than rhetoric, designed to disguise the fact that, while it wants government to run efficiently, as we all do, the Australian Labor Party is still the party of big government and interventionism. Fiscal policy is much more than an economic policy tool which can finetune growth in the economy.

Indeed, there is a lot of evidence to suggest that fiscal policy alone is not effective in achieving the goals of government. Supposedly, expansionary policies in the short term can reduce growth in the long run. Fiscal policy is also a reflection of the Government's ideological beliefs about the role of government. The Labor Party's fiscal policy is dominated by its ideological considerations. What honourable members opposite mean when they refer to `tight' fiscal policy is a tight fiscal policy within the narrow constraints of their ideological beliefs-and those beliefs necessitate extensive government spending.

The Government is committed to the record level of spending required to fund its extensive programs of social engineering. Within those limits, the most that can be expected from the Labor Party on the fiscal policy front is a tinkering at the edges. In recent years, Labor has marginally limited the growth of Federal Government outlays as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP). This has been achieved largely through the use of policies which have produced high growth, but through the agency of relatively high inflation, and it has not been accompanied by lasting development of the productive capacity of Australian business and entrepreneurial activity.

The Federal Government's smaller share of GDP is a feature of growth in measured GDP rather than a decline in the cost and role of government. Thus, much contemporary debate about fiscal policy is wildly astray. The debate cannot just be about a greater efficiency in the provision of government services. Both sides of the political debate want that efficiency-but for different reasons and involving different outcomes. The coalition wants to use savings to reduce the demands of government on taxpayers. Labor wants greater efficiency so that it has more money to spend on defending its electoral fortunes and supporting its favoured constituency. A genuine debate about fiscal policy must involve debate about what government should and should not do.

As it happens, Labor has its hands tied behind its back in the debate about fiscal measures. It is committed to expensive government funding of pet projects and to support for the vested interests which Labor depends on. In the process of this extension of the role of government under Labor, the proper functions of government suffer and decline from neglect and under-funding. Increasingly, it is being realised that economic policy is not a simple exercise in the engineering of economic aggregates and statistics. For all the efforts of the Government to fiddle the measures of inflation, Australians are still aware that prices are rising. The economic effects of high inflation are not eliminated by the less than honest expedient of changing the way that a government agency chooses to measure that inflation. Similarly, the short term effects of a Budget surplus will not alter the reality of an economic policy which has seen foreign debt rise to a record level of some $120 billion-that is, $120,000m.

The macro-economic structure of the Government's fiscal policy-that is, whether it is high or low, increasing or decreasing-can be far less important than the micro-economic make-up of that government spending. The economic effects of government spending can be vastly different, depending on what the money is being spent on. It is at this micro-economic level that the fiscal policies of the Labor Party, under the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Treasurer (Mr Keating), have led to lower growth and greater inefficiency.

Labor has executed fiscal policies which distort the market, reduce efficiency and remove incentives to remain independent of the support of government. These Supply Bills help to illustrate the problem. For example, nearly $1.5m is provided for the Australian Industry Council secretariat. That secretariat provides administrative support for the structure of corporatist industries councils, which Labor developed a particular liking for in its earliest years in office. This expenditure has not only been a waste of money but it has also helped to produce the failures of the Government's industry plans. In turn, industry policy under Labor has compounded the problems of the dependence of industry on the initiatives of government.

Labor's industry planning has increased the power of trade unions and has institutionalised the rigid and outmoded industrial relations systems. It has produced a productivity performance which is well below that of comparable Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries. An important investigation of the Government's car industry plan, once the centrepiece of Labor industry policy, has suggested that the industry is not competitive and that it is producing a product which is too expensive and of inferior quality. The advancements made by automotive manufacturers in recent years have been in spite of, rather than because of, the Government's industry plans and the agencies which are supposedly there to support them. In the meantime, consumers have to pay huge tariffs on imported vehicles, which still manage to compete with their Australian equivalents. Compounding these industrial problems is an industrial relations system which is an affront to all of those who genuinely believe in individual liberty.

This legislation seeks to spend some $12m on the Australian Industrial Registry, which is the agency through which the Government's new industrial relations legislation effectively prohibits genuine freedom of association in the workplace. The Industrial Registrar is responsible for the obnoxious procedure of granting permission to individuals who do not wish to join a union or an industrial association. Under the industrial legislation one has to have the permission of a bureaucrat to retain any freedom at all in the workplace, and even if it is granted, that freedom is heavily qualified. Similarly, the legislation denies freedom of association by prohibiting the registration of new trade unions in competition with those unions which already have registration. Through the agency of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-cum-Labor Party programs for the amalgamation of trade unions into so-called mega-unions, it will see union hierarchies even more distant from their membership, it will see more influence over government and it will produce a more rigid labour market. That has been ordained in the industrial relations legislation. It is an example of a government spending measure which is fairly small in total but which will contribute to the widespread economic disasters of poor productivity and reduced incentives for hard work. It illustrates that the direction of spending can be just as important as the aggregate amount of spending.

Government fiscal policy produces the apparently anomalous position of being fairly tight, while encouraging wages and other outcomes which are themselves far more expansionary than is in the best interests of the nation. Why does Australia need a tight fiscal policy? There are two major reasons why the Government should tighten its fiscal measures. Firstly, a tight fiscal policy will have necessary effects on demand, which will counter the recent enormous growth in the current account deficit. It is the current account deficit which has to be addressed first. A reduction in the role of government which accompanies a tight fiscal policy would open up room for more efficient private sector operations, which, in turn, would help the competitiveness of export industries. Secondly, fiscal policy would take on some of the burden presently shouldered by monetary policy, which has led to increasing interest rates and will eventually cause even greater havoc in the domestic economy. Not only has the Government come to depend almost exclusively on monetary policy, but also it has lost control of some of the most important aspects of that policy.

For some time the growth in monetary aggregates has been amongst the most rapid in the Western world. M1 has grown at the rate of 14.2 per cent, while broad money has grown at a rate of 22 per cent. This growth in money supplies underlies and underpins the high inflation rates which Australia still endures. It contributes to the need for high interest rates, and Australian interest rates are now the highest amongst the reasonably stable countries of the Western world. The response of the Treasurer is to claim that the concern over monetary growth is an anachronism in a deregulated market. He derides monetary targeting as inconvenient and inaccurate. On both counts, experience has proved him wrong. The measures of monetary aggregates might be inaccurate, but so are many of the other economic statistics which the Treasurer quotes with gay abandon if they happen to be favourable to the point he is plugging at the time.

The most difficult problems of measuring money supply occur in the United States of America. The United States dollar is the most heavily traded currency in the world and, being the reserve currency it is, is held in large quantities by governments and central banks around the world, yet the United States has not abandoned monetary targeting. It has set its targets low and has met or exceeded those targets. As to the problems with the economy of the United States, excessive monetary growth is not one of them. Our economy differs very greatly from that of the United States in that respect also.

What the Treasurer has done in the monetary policy field is to abdicate responsibility, adopting confusing practices and confused policy which leads to uncertainty and potentially disastrous results. When monetary policy is lost to the Government as an effective means of dealing with the economic mess which this Government has created and fiscal policy is constrained by the ideological needs for big government and action by the Federal Government, the economic prospects for the country are not all that good. In fact, they might be said to be very dire indeed.

The spending which these Supply Bills outline and the prospects for the next Federal Budget indicate that the Government has failed to come to grips with the recent changes in the economic outlook which, in turn, result from long-run policies, such as the so-called accord, that have undermined the economic future of this nation. The Government is no longer able to deliver the economic reforms which Australia needs if we are to claw our way back from the brink of an abyss which is made deeper by a $120,000m foreign debt, an inflation rate of at least 7 per cent, unemployment levels stuck at around 7 per cent, interest rates amongst the highest in the world, wages growth which is about to get out of hand, and levels of taxation which are unprecedented.

Labor remains beholden to the ACTU, extensive government spending-to the point of being excessive-through the Medicare mess, burgeoning social security costs, and a range of new legislation which will undermine the competitiveness of Australia business. Labor offers no prospect of genuine solutions to deep-seated economic problems. It is unable to deliver privatisation, labour market deregulation and continuing micro-economic reforms. The Labor Party is no longer capable of governing the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Fraser, I would like to assure the honourable member for Curtin that the emotion displayed by him immediately following the contribution of the honourable member for Reid certainly in no way diminished the reputation of this chamber, but rather enhanced it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I was about to make the same point. The comments by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) and the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) about the terrible experiences of prisoners of war of the Japanese were a moving tribute to those men and women. Their comments were a fine example of bipartisan humanitarianism and concern in this chamber. I warmly endorse and support the comments of both honourable members. I would like to be able to go on and say that I agree with everything else that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Curtin, said, but unfortunately I cannot do that. I agree with one comment he made, that the justification for public expenditure depends on what it is spent on. It is true that sometimes public expenditure should be increased and that sometimes it needs to be decreased. I want to present this morning a case for increases in one of the centrally important areas of government outlays, public investment.

SPEECH.PARA: Adam Smith is sometimes claimed to be the chief philosopher of the free marketeers, yet he argues in the Wealth of Nations that one of the basic responsibilities of sovereign or Commonwealth government is to provide an adequate structure of public works `to facilitate the commerce of society'. He argues that an extensive and well maintained system of roads, bridges, highways, lighthouses and canals is necessary to meet the needs of a vital, growing economy. The duty of constructing such public works falls to the Government because their benefits accrue not just to particular individuals but to the economy at large, or because the cost reductions derived from economies of scale are best captured by direct, centralised, public capital outlays.

These propositions would have been accepted generally by public policy makers and other economists for most of the last two centuries since they were written by Adam Smith. It is only the aberrant monetarists, who believe tighter monetary control and cutting public outlays are the key policies, and equally aberrant supply siders, whose highest priority is to cut taxes, who would challenge them. In Australia, at least until the early 1970s, all major political parties, business, unions and academics agreed that the public and private sectors shared the role of being the engine of growth. The rapid pace of Australian private sector development would have been impossible without public investment in roads, railways, water and sewerage, electricity and gas supplies, telecommunications and assisted migration, let alone activities such as health services and education, housing and general government. That national consensus, which had existed for most of Australia's history, disappeared in the 1970s under the influence of the monetarists and the supply siders. One consequence was a fall in the priority given to outlays on public investment. In the 20 years from the mid-1960s to the mid-1980s public investment was allowed to fall as a proportion of national income from about 9 1/2 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent. Private investment did not increase to fill the gap either. In fact, private investment, including housing, also fell from 18 1/2 per cent of national income in the mid-1960s to 16 per cent in the mid-1980s.

Maintenance and replacement have also been affected. Though Australia's infrastructure is younger than that of comparable western countries it is not much younger. Therefore we can expect the build up of rehabilitation or replacement during the next decade that has already occurred in other industrialised countries. Two of Australia's most serious economic problems are the current account deficit and high unemployment. Reducing the seriousness of those problems will involve restructuring economic activity to build up new and existing export industries and to reduce imports. This requires not only private investment but also an efficient, up to date public infrastructure so as to maximise Australia's competitiveness. The need for improved productivity cannot end at the factory gate.

Recent work has shown that Australia is facing severe capital capacity constraints. We need more investment in both human and physical capital to achieve a more rapid growth in Australian exports. This means we cannot simply employ more people without the capital backup, if the employment is to be most productive. The size of the current account deficit is imposing severe constraints on Australia and on the public sector at present. It is tempting for governments to reduce capital spending in the current economic climate. However, this not only reduces economic activity and employment growth in the short run but also runs down the nation's investment in infrastructure, its economic efficiency and eventually the social fabric of society. Increasing investment is centrally important to achieve more rapid economic and employment growth and to cope with our current account deficit.

One of the few relationships about which all economists agree is that between investment and economic growth. That relationship is shown by comparative experience between Australia and other Western countries. For example, from 1962 to 1979, Australia had the third lowest rate of investment and the fourth lowest growth of national income of 25 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries-that is, all Western countries. Only the United States, Canada and New Zealand had a lower rate of economic growth per person employed than Australia. In common with New Zealand, Canada and the United States, we have relied too heavily on past investment and now find our relative place slipping away.

This conclusion is reinforced by research in the United States by David Aschauer. This research shows that changes in public investment have a significant impact on private investment. Aschauer has found that a rise in the public capital stock makes private capital more productive. Public investment leads to growth in private investment by increasing rates of return on private capital. There is a striking tendency for profits to be high when the level of public capital formation is high over the course of several years, even after excluding business cycle effects. This is a clear example of the complementarity of the public and private sectors.

A related area of concern is maintenance. The worst fears of major infrastructure networks all falling apart at the same time are probably unfounded. Many of our infrastructure services and networks compare well with the best in the world. But to avoid the problems of the gradual, inevitable deterioration of infrastructure needs thought and planning. We have not seen major freeways in Australia fall into such a bad state of repair that they could not be used, as happened in parts of the United States in the 1970s. The same thing could happen here, but would not, if sufficient financing is provided to ensure adequate maintenance. However, maintenance and replacement needs will substantially increase during the rest of this century due to the overall age pattern of Australian infrastructure. Unless funding requirements due to ageing can be offset by savings elsewhere through lower demand, aggregate public investment must rise. It says something for the managers of public assets that they have been able to maintain infrastructure assets with a generally declining share of national resources. But this situation is about to change, with increasing requirements for rehabilitation and maintenance expenditure in the 1990s.

Perhaps of more concern than the state of the nation's assets is the failure to examine thoroughly other areas for potentially productive investment. For example, many overseas countries have intermodal links between rail and port and rail and airports-links which are generally missing in Australia. There are many gaps in Australia's infrastructure and areas where it would be desirable to increase investment. These include urban arterial and ring roads in capital cities; standard gauge rail to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and many other potential improvements in the rail system with high estimated rates of return; improvements in airport facilities in Sydney; significant unsewered areas in cities, notably Perth; salination of the Murray-Darling basin; and the quality of Adelaide water. A major potential new investment has begun in telecommunications, including the great potential to improve productivity with the proposed Integrated Services Digital Network.
