There are likely to be many other areas where greater infrastructure investment would yield high rates of return also.

Perhaps the most striking example is the study of a very fast train between Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne. This is being undertaken by a private consortium and the pre-feasibility study has been sufficiently promising for the group to be now doing a full feasibility study. That is a very important private sector development which the public sector should support and look towards ways of cooperating with. Assuming that a thorough procedure for selecting public infrastructure investments is used, the question remains as to whether all viable projects can be funded. If present practices continue to be followed, potentially profitable public investments may still be excluded by a cut-off in funds through the global limits on loan council borrowings. Private investment does not place the same absolute cut-off in funds once a certain level of investment is reached. Rather, projects are considered on their merits and, if finance is not available for justifiable projects locally, local overseas funds may be sought. A similar kind of situation ought to apply in the public sector. Rather than being a residual, public investment should have a much higher priority so that all facets of the budget-recurrent and capital, revenue and the deficit, or, as we have at present, the surplus-are set on a iterative basis in relation to budget priorities.

Another innovation which is important is exclusion of borrowings by commercial public authorities from the public sector borrowing requirement. That would assist better planning of investment by these authorities. The impact of public authorities such as Telecom Australia, Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd on the capital market is very similar to that of private corporations. There is no logical reason for including them in the general funding transactions of government. The question following from what I have said is: How could increased public investment be funded? Increased public investment could be funded by increasing borrowing. That would be the logical way to do it. That is the way the private sector does it; when it wants to invest it borrows. Why should not the public sector do the same thing, because after all, investment is in facilities which will improve conditions for later generations?

Contrary to general belief, Australia has a relatively low level of public debt as a proportion of gross domestic product. In fact, Australia is second only to Finland as the lowest public debtor amongst Western countries. There is little empirical evidence to support the view that public sector borrowing crowds out the private sector. The simple version of the `crowding out' theory, which holds that higher levels of public borrowing will reduce the scope for private investment, cannot be sustained by the evidence. Even the more sophisticated version, that increased public borrowing leads to higher interest rates, cannot be sustained by empirical evidence. As Australia has a small open economy, Australian interest rates are set principally by interest rates in the US, by expected changes in Australia's exchange rate, by our inflation rate and by the standards of monetary policy, rather than by the extent of government borrowing.

It would be essential, nevertheless, to minimise potential damage to market perceptions from any increase in public sector borrowing. One way of doing this would be to separate the capital and recurrent sides of the Budget, as many countries do. This would show that recurrent outlays were entirely covered by recurrent revenue and that revenue at present also pays for all investment. In fact, it has always paid for some investment throughout the post-war period. It would demonstrate clearly that all borrowing was for investment. Publicity about the returns and other economic benefits of that investment would then contribute to justifying the borrowing.

One of the major constraints on investment is simply that Australia's savings rate is too low. The spread of occupational superannuation will certainly contribute to increasing household saving. It is interesting to consider methods used for encouraging saving in countries where the saving rate is high, such as Japan. There, until recently, substantial tax concessions were offered to encourage saving. I think it is very worthwhile to consider that kind of policy also in Australia. A heavy reliance on foreign capital for national investment involves even greater debt and equity servicing obligations which, given our current level of overseas debt, should be avoided. Therefore, it is important to build up Australia's saving rate and it is worth looking at the possibility of offering tax concessions to do that.

I have outlined a strategy for providing the infrastructure framework, for increasing national productivity and for restructuring the economy. Public investment must be increased if we are to improve our trading position, reduce our overseas debt and maintain steady rates of economic and employment growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the contribution by the Hon. Tom Uren, the honourable member for Reid, with a great deal of emotion. I was deeply moved by what he had to say about Australian prisoners of war during World War II, particularly in the Japanese theatres of war. I have a personal interest in this matter. I was only born in 1934, so I was fairly young when the war started. But my godfather was a prisoner of the Japanese in Changi in Singapore and served on that infamous death railway between Bangkok and Burma. In 1945 I can recall going with my parents to the Sydney Showground to greet the returning prisoners of war of the Japanese. I can still see the doubledecker buses coming in and the walking skeletons, the scarecrows of men, being helped off the buses. It may come as no surprise to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that I certainly support wholeheartedly and totally the move by the honourable member for Reid to have some special recognition of these Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: None of us can ever possibly understand what those men went through. One hears our good friend Tom talk and one really gets the feeling. If one sees some of the film from the time and one reads some of the accounts, these must also make any human being abhor war and the inhumanity of man to man. I find it fairly distressing, when talking to a lot of young people in Australia today, that they do not really believe that that happened. I find it quite often. They see things on television. Perhaps it is the conditioning, the horror and violence that we get on our television every day, but very largely one finds that young people say, `Oh, that could not happen. Nobody could do that'.

I certainly do not hold any brief for not forgiving. I do not think we can forget and I do not think we should forget. But most of our ex-service men and women who served in the Japanese theatre of war are prepared to forgive. In the interests of humanity in the long run, however, we must never forget. Over the Christmas period, only a few months ago, my wife and I had the opportunity of briefly visiting Singapore. I also undertook a study tour of parts of Thailand. I took it as a necessary duty and obligation to visit the Kranji War Cemetery in Singapore and to pay a brief pilgrimage to Changi gaol which is still there as a gaol, with vastly different conditions of course. I took the opportunity to visit the small memorial and the reconstruction of the chapel at the Changi prison. Christmas day was the most remarkable and wonderful Christmas day, because we left Bangkok at about 5.30 in the morning and travelled by bus to Kanchanaburi, up towards the River Kwai, where we visited a Commonwealth war cemetery with mainly Australians buried there. It is a great tribute to the Office of Australian War Graves that our war cemeteries are kept in such immaculate order.

As one walks along the rows of those gravestones with those plaques and reads the names and other information, above all, one is struck by the ages of our fellow Australians. Some of course were my age, some in their 30s and 40s, but above all the majority were 18, 19, 20 and 25 years of age. What an incredible waste! On that particular Christmas day we visited the war cemetery there and went to one of the Buddhist temples in which is maintained a museum of the prisoners of war. From there we moved up to that famous or infamous bridge on the River Kwai and walked across it. We then went up to the hotel where we were to spend two nights, the River Kwai Village Hotel. I hired a car and a driver and went further up towards Burma to what has now become the famous Hell-Fire Pass. I walked down the steps which the Australian-Thai Chamber of Commerce had installed to Hell-Fire Pass, which is one of the cuttings on the Burma-Thailand death railway. This is again a very moving experience, because one moves down through open forests of bamboo; it is very still, very quiet, very hot and humid and one walks along the bed of what was the railway line. Some of the sleepers are still there and one can step from sleeper to sleeper. I stopped and realised that in the building of that railway 16,000 allied servicemen died. I could be wrong; if Tom were here he could correct me. As well as that, another 100,000 Asian labourers drawn from Singapore and all over Asia by the Japanese worked on that railway as slave labour. When one stepped on one of those sleepers while walking along the rail bed, one could not help but be conscious that one human being died for every sleeper on that railway line. I will not go on about it at great length, except to say that any Australian who has the opportunity to visit Thailand should take the time to make this pilgrimage, because that is what it is-a pilgrimage. In fact, on 26 April last year-the day after Anzac Day-Hell-Fire Pass was dedicated as a memorial to Australian prisoners of war and a suitable plaque is on display. As I said, I spent a memorable Christmas day visiting Australian war cemeteries.

Hell-Fire Pass is only one of many cuttings where our fellow countrymen suffered and, in many instances, died. Japanese engineers said that it would take them about five years to build the railway which the British had surveyed in, I think, 1902. Of course, it took far less than that; it took probably under two years. This result was achieved by Australian prisoners of war and others working with picks, shovels and crowbars and some explosives but no other equipment or machines. They dug a cutting down through solid rock basically using manual labour and carted the debris away in baskets. They worked God knows how many hours a day, but certainly from the very early hours until well after dark. The area had to be illuminated by flares hung above the pass. Of course, this hellish situation, with the illumination from flares, led to the name of Hell-Fire Pass. I am delighted to see my friend and colleague the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) come into the chamber. He also has an association with Hell-Fire Pass. To conclude my remarks on this topic, I again commend the honourable member for Reid on the proposal he has put forward. I think every member of the House should support it totally because, in my view, there is absolute justice in what he says.

I turn now to another area which is also of great concern to me but on a different level. I refer to the current attack by the Government on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I think it would come as no surprise not only to members of this Parliament but also to members of the public that the pharmacists of this country are quite distressed and up in arms over what has been happening. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme has been a vital and important facet of our overall health scheme for nearly 40 years. However, since the Hawke Government came into office there has been attack after attack on pharmacies, the most recent of which was contained in the 12 April economic statement which proposed to cut from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme $31m in 1989-90, $96m in 1990-91 and $156m in 1991-92-a total of $283m. This is the culmination of six years meddling in pharmacies by the Hawke-Keating Government. We have the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) presiding over the disastrous demolition of our pharmaceutical system.

I think it is proper and in fact absolutely essential that we consider what our friendly family chemist does. Ordinary Australians regard pharmacists as `their chemist' when they go to the chemist shop. The service provided is not just one of handing pills over the counter. The Australian Institute of Pharmacy Management estimates that 1,000 pharmacies will close by 1991 and that the jobs of 35,000 pharmacy workers will be endangered; in fact, some estimates suggest that over half of Australia's pharmacies will be forced to close. I make the point that there are over 450 country towns in Australia with only one pharmacy. I think perhaps it would be scaremongering to suggest that all of those pharmacies will close. I do not think that that will be the case. But it is also quite apparent that those towns with only one pharmacy may have to reduce their services. I am not making an idle claim. I can see the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), stirring. I am not making an idle rhetorical claim: there are facts and figures to support what is happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member does not have to worry about stirring. I can assure him that, if he transgressed Standing Orders, he would hear about it.

—I was not suggesting that that was the case. I know the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs quite well and I appreciate his attitude in respect of a number of things. I thought he was getting ready to interject, rather than stand and make--
—I was just looking up at you. If I knew it had that effect, I would do it more often.

—Please do: I like the Minister's happy, smiling face. But, let us return to the real circumstances that are having an impact on the pharmacies of Australia. In 1987-88, the cost of drugs to pharmacies rose by 25.7 per cent. In the same year, average weekly earnings rose by 5.9 per cent, while pharmacists' remuneration increased by only 4.4 per cent. So, in 1987-88 pharmacists were behind the eight ball in terms of the economic situation. But this is not just one year in isolation. In the past two years the consumer price index (CPI) has increased by 17.4 per cent and average weekly earnings have risen by 13.1 per cent, while pharmacists' remuneration has increased by only 4.5 per cent. I have the greatest respect for the pharmacists that I know. I know that they are running a business and trying to make a profit. There is nothing wrong with that, but they also provide fantastic service. So we have established that in 1987-88 pharmacists were going down the drain and in the past two years they have been going down the drain again. Over the past five years the cost to them of the goods they sell has increased by 101 per cent and the cost of labour has increased by 87 per cent. At the same time, the average pharmacist's remuneration from scrips has increased by only 44 per cent. Again, that sets the stage and tells the story that our pharmacists are going out backwards.
—And country towns will lose pharmacy services.

—There is no doubt about that: country towns will lose pharmaceutical services. To cap it all, the Government will reduce funding in respect of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme by a further $283m in the next three years. So what is the situation we are in? Tomorrow there will be a strike-and perhaps that is the wrong word-involving pharmacists right around Australia. Between 2 p.m. and 4 p.m. the chemist shops of Australia will close in protest. We all know the professional standards of the people who operate pharmacies. Frankly, I think it is quite amazing that they have been pushed to the point where they must consider taking this sort of action. I hasten to add that arrangements have been made for one pharmacist to be on duty in every town and suburb of Australia to make sure that anyone in real need of urgent pharmaceuticals will be able to be helped. That is a slightly different situation to the air traffic controllers' method of making their point.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation has not been helped at all by the Government. In fact, pharmacists have been forced into this position. If one goes back a little in time, the Government added 53 frequently prescribed drugs to the `authority only' list and, following public agitation and representations from the Opposition, it replaced 34 of them. The Government had no medical or therapeutic reason for putting those prescribed drugs on the authority only list-it had no reason at all.

I would like to conclude by asking honourable members to think about their pharmacists, their friendly family chemists, and the sort of services that they provide. Perhaps for people sitting here it might not happen very often, but the neighbourhood chemist for most people is in the front line of the provision of basic health services. I have a list of things that pharmacists do. It is not just a question of taking a prescription in and handing it over and out comes the bottle of pills. A whole world of advice, care and concern comes from the pharmacist. Many things that doctors are never seen about are dealt with by pharmacists. They can advise on things like weight control, travel sickness, sores, bunions, sore eyes and bad breath. All these minor things are treated with the advice of a pharmacist. How often have mothers taken their kids to the chemist to show him a boil or cut on their child's knee and get the appropriate advice and help? I have actually been in a pharmacy when people have brought in their kids with sunburn. Of course, I live in that wonderful electorate of Cowper on the mid-north coast of New South Wales, which has a superb climate, but unfortunately people sometimes stay on the beach too long and get sunburn. I have seen mothers take their children into the chemist and get something to solve that problem.

Whether it is colds, flu, pimples, bruises, cuts or dandruff, advice for these things comes not just when one pays one's money for the treatment itself; a great deal of warmth, compassion, care and concern goes over the counters of pharmacies. I have, of course, forgotten all the assistance given to mothers with young babies-the weighing; the feeding advice; advice about nappy rash, spots and colic. All these things are provided at no fee whatsoever. If this Government, by taking the action it has and the action it has forecast in the 12 April statement, is going to put many Australian pharmacies in a situation where they will have to close, reduce staff and reduce the service they give to the Australian community, a marvellous and valuable service, the people of Australia-the aged, the ill and the young-will be those who suffer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like first of all to compliment the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) on at least the first part of his speech. I certainly appreciate the sincerity of his views and the manner in which he expressed them. I may not totally agree with the second part of his speech and the conclusions that he drew there.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are something like 6 years and 2 months into the life of the Hawke Labor Government. In that time there have been rapid change; major reforms in Australia's economic structures and framework; and an evolution, if you like, of Australia's social structures. These have particularly affected women in terms of the larger number of women moving into the work force and families generally. There is much day to day debate about living standards, productivity, national debt and personal debt, but I suppose it is easy to lose sight of the overall picture of these day to day issues.

I would like to draw attention to some of the large and important items that we may sometimes forget about and look at how Australia is moving along historically, where we are at in 1989 and whether we are moving forwards-or backwards, as members of the Opposition would like the Australian public to believe. Let us look at some of the basic items. For instance, the average life expectancy 100 years ago was 50 years. By 1940 that had increased to 65 years. Today it is 72 years for men and slightly older for women. One hundred years ago the standard working week was some 52 hours. By 1940 it had reduced to 45 hours. In 1989 we are going through a period of transition, with some workers still on a 40-hour week and many working 38 hours or 35 hours. We have far more flexible working arrangements. Rostered days off, flexitime and things of that nature are quite common throughout the spread of the Australian economy and work force. Most importantly, over the last decade disposable household income has increased by some 11 per cent. Total disposable household income has increased in five of the six years in which Labor has been in government. So despite arguments about falling living standards and squeezes on families, in an historical perspective the average household today is considerably better off than it was 10 years ago and immeasurably better off than in decades past.

Although there is a fondness for looking back to the good old days and recalling how life seemed to be easier and more pleasant then, when we actually examine such claims they often do not quite stand up. We often hear that Australian productivity is too low. Yet output per head of population has increased some 20 per cent over the last decade. Let us look at material assets-consumer goods, for instance. The penetration of video cassette recorders into Australian homes has increased, some 13 per cent of homes having had video cassette recorders in 1982 and some 57 per cent having them today. The ownership of personal computers has increased by some 90 per cent in the last three years. In 1982 only 5 per cent of homes had a microwave oven. That is now up to 43 per cent. Only 45 per cent of households had a simple thing like a clothes drier in 1983. That has now increased to 55 per cent. Over that same period there has been an increase in the number of households having a dishwasher, from 17 per cent to 24 per cent.

Motor vehicles are always a very good indication of the strength of an economy. In 1983 there were some 421 motor vehicles per 1,000 of the Australian population. By 1988 that figure was 440 motor vehicles per 1,000. In 1983 some 85 per cent of households had a telephone, a very basic item, and 7.5 per cent said that they could not afford to have a phone connected. In 1988, some five years later, 91 per cent of households had a telephone and only 4.5 per cent said that they could not afford to have a phone connected.

I draw those figures from an excellent article by Michael Stutchbury which appeared in the Australian Financial Review of 26 April of this year. The article points out and those figures show that in many ways there has been a spreading of affluence throughout the Australian economy. Although we are often taken up in this debate with living standards, levels of income, wage rates and inflation rates, the picture which is often tempted to be painted, certainly by the Opposition-and that is understandable-but also, perhaps more broadly, by the media is that Australians have undergone a period of severe squeeze. But while there are undeniable problems, the reality is that the 1980s has been a decade in which there has been a steady improvement in living standards within this country. If one looks at the statistics, that is simply undeniable. A lot of people would argue with that and I can understand that.

There are of course problems which we, as a nation, are still addressing. They are, I suppose, predominantly the balance of payments problem, because we are importing far more than we are exporting and that has led to a large increase in the level of Australia's foreign debt. The inflation rate in this country is too high, and I do not think anyone will argue with that and, of course, our interest rates at the present time are higher than the Government or any reasonable person would like them to be. Again, I do not think we can argue against that. However, we have to look at those problems in the overall context and make a judgment about what is causing those problems and what responses a government should be making to them.

The fundamental problem which the Australian economy is suffering from at the moment is that we have excessive demand; that is, there has been a large increase in disposable income if we look at it in terms of the national figure. The cause of that has been the large increase in employment. Some 1.3 million more Australians are now in a job than in 1983. So while individual wage earners have not seen real increases in wages during that period, 1.3 million more Australians are actually drawing a wage. That has meant that many hundreds of thousands of families who were living on unemployment benefits or in very difficult circumstances, have moved out of that extreme difficulty, out of poverty, and back into a reasonable standard of living. It has also meant that there are now two incomes coming in for many other families. That has obviously led to an increase in those families' living standards.

But employment growth is undeniable and it should be put into that context. It is some four times greater than the rate which was achieved by the Fraser Government, and it is twice the rate enjoyed by the average of the rest of the developed world, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. That is an outstanding record and one of which the Labor Government is justifiably proud. Other economic indicators also reflect this strength. Profitability for Australian business is at levels which have not been seen since the late 1960s or early 1970s and there is at present a record level of business investment. Since records have been kept, we have not seen such a sustained period of business investment as we are seeing at the moment.

Historically, Australia has gone through periods of strong employment growth before it has gone through periods of reasonable business profitability and reasonable levels of business investment. When the Australian economy has overheated in the past it has normally gone through the typical boom-bust cycle. We go through a period of boom and that inevitably leads to a large bust and the economy goes into a recession. The losers in a recession are principally the people who lose their jobs. It is those families, with individuals thrown out of work, who lose that income. They are the principal and the most severe losers in an economic recession and it is that which this Government is attempting to avoid. Historically, Australia will inevitably, if it follows its history and cycles of the economy, move into a period of recession. But the Government is not going to allow that to happen and it will do everything in its power to stop that from happening. The challenge is how to beat the recession.

It is interesting to hear alternative views from the Opposition. We hear that interest rates are going too high. How do we bring interest rates down when the other arms of government policy have been fully utilised? Those other arms of course are government spending itself and the size of government. The Government can reduce the size of its expenditure so as to build up public savings or to stop further stimulation to the economy by its own expenditure. But the record shows that this Government has reduced government spending by some five percentage points of our gross domestic products. For the fourth consecutive year there will be a real decrease in the size of the Commonwealth government. It is unprecedented in this country's history for that sort of restraint to be shown by government.

It is all very well to say that we should have more than a $5 1/2 billion surplus in order to reduce demand in the economy. Unfortunately, there is no more room left to cut, unless the Government is willing to go into the big ticket items, to get into pensions, into the health system and into education. Those are the options which this Government faces, but as a Labor government it is simply not prepared to attack the most disadvantaged in the society, those dependent on the pension system. We are not going to attack those people. There is no significant further room in which to cut government spending to the sorts of levels that we would need to to have some sort of impact on the level of demand in this country.

The other alternative is to slow down the strength of the labour market. We could do that by causing a recession and throwing people out of work. That would lessen the demand for higher wages, but again that has a huge social cost and it is a cost which this Government is not willing to bear. In turn, the Government has negotiated with the trade union movement a wage-tax trade-off. That means that wages will increase by about 6.5 per cent. At the moment that is about the Australian inflation rate, probably a smidgin below it. So it is not a real wage increase in terms of what business has to pay in relation to the inflation rate. So it is a good wage result. But in order to meet wage demands and what could legitimately be expected to be obtained by the work force, or at least significant sections of it, in a free market situation, there has been action by the Government to reduce taxation and improve social wage measures.

So through the 12 April statement we have seen reductions in income tax rates, improvements in family allowances the dependent spouse rebate and other measures, to improve the living standard of the average Australian. That is only fair, right and reasonable. But it is also economically responsible, because the path proposed by the Opposition of, `All right, we need the wage-tax trade-off, but it really should have been a total trade-off, so any wage rise should have been nil in terms of the tax cut', is utterly unrealistic, and it knows it. It knows that when it was in government it had a similar situation of a strong level of domestic demand and strong labour force conditions and there was a wages explosion. Wages went through the roof and that contributed to the recession in which we saw high unemployment and double digit inflation. That path has been tried and it failed. It is really poor that the Opposition has not come up with anything new concerning Australia's economic problems.

We have in place a level of high interest rates, which will dampen down demand. No government likes to see high interest rates, they obviously hurt people-that is indisputable-but the alternatives would hurt an awful lot more and cause a lot more hardship. That is what this all boils down to, the Government taking the responsible course and by no means abandoning its economic responsibilities but ensuring that Australians are hurt as little as possible. That is what the 12 April statement is all about and that is what the Government's economic policies are all about.

I believe that interest rates will play their role and that a slowing down of demand will follow. There are already signs of that through various indicators and that will mean that in the later part of this year or early next year, interest rates can come down and we will have a sustainable level of economic activity, at a base where we can again improve things. We will have avoided the boom-bust cycle which Australia has historically gone through. The Government's economic policies are in place. They are sound policies and I commend them to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say something about the hardships which Australians are incurring under the management of this Labor Government. I will outline to a degree the barefaced attitude of the Government in ignoring the public interest in running for an election. This has been brought out so clearly by the changes made in the Opposition yesterday. The first result of the change of leadership of the coalition will be that we will definitely and automatically win the next Federal election, but beneath that obvious certainty portrayed today by the enthusiastic reception of those changes around Australia is the transparent nature of the Government's previous strategy, which it has now cancelled.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's strategy was to run for a quick and early election and, in so doing, to hide the facts from Australians. As the Opposition spokesman for finance, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), said this morning, `Don't worry; be happy'. That is the theme which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been peddling to Australia to create a bridge to a short term election. It is quite clear and transparent because this morning the reports, which are quite well based, say that the Government is not going to have an early election. Of course it is not because it would lose automatically. Out of this alteration of strategy has emerged the deception that the Treasurer and the Government have been running in relation to the economic health of Australia. This will become more and more apparent to Australians as the argument is developed in this House and in other public forums.

It is interesting also to look at how Australians are meeting this lowering of their living standards, at how they are managing to maintain their home loans and necessary purchases and the like to maintain a certain living standard for their children. How are they doing this in the face of the decline in living standards? One of the most alarming reports of how they are doing it emerged early this month in the Age under the heading `personal debts set at average of $5,700'. A new look at the personal debt held by Australians produced an alarmingly enlarged statistic on the one currently held to be the fact. The report says:

Australia's level of personal debt it almost double previous estimates, nearing $5,700 for every employed person, according to the latest figures compiled by the Reserve Bank. The Bank's May bulletin says the level of non-mortgage personal debt has jumped sharply from previous estimates of about $25,000m to almost $42,000m.

Does not that tell the story of how Australians are managing to maintain their standards in the face of the increasing taxation burden of this Government and the attack on their real wage? Of course, it is hidden in this debt structure. The report continues:
. . . debt has increased by about 13 per cent during the past 12 months.

That is twice the consumer price index. If one looks at home loans, one will find a very great additional burden under this Government. A survey of home loan affordability published in April this year gives the simple fact that the comparisons of the ratio of average home loan repayments to a median family income increased from 27.3 per cent in 1987 to 31.7 per cent in 1988. Yet we hear the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) talking about increased living standards. As if this can be ignored, as the Treasurer tried to ignore it in his short run to the now cancelled election. That is an another indication of the problems Australians face under this Government. In the Australian Financial Review of 3 May in a report headed `Monetary policy stays tight' it is stated:

Revenue collections in the nine months to March were up 7.7 per cent on the corresponding period in 1987-88 below the anticipated 8.3 per cent increase. But key areas were above forecast. Net PAYE payments were up 18.2 per cent compared to the 13.8 per cent in the Budget forecast . . .

This makes a mockery of the Treasurer's tax reductions because every time we hear from the Government about tax reductions we read of these enormous increases in PAYE collections which are totally out of line with the rate of inflation in the community. Also on 3 May under the heading `Screws have to stay on-Hawke', the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) referred to the growing overseas debt and said:
More than 45 per cent of the growth in demand last year was met by imports.

What sort of management is this Government giving Australia? What sort of encouragement is it giving to Australian producers? What sort of attempts are being made to reform the infrastructure of this country to enable people to compete with overseas producers when 45 per cent of growth in demand is met by imports?

We have reached the stage under this Government where Australia cannot afford a lift in production or a lift in internal prosperity. Under Labor's management, as soon as there is an increase in activity in the community we pull in an unsustainable rate of imports, to the degree that our overseas balance is deteriorating as much as it has in the past. When we look at the Australian support industries, we find a report from the Automotive Industry Authority of 3 May which says:

. . . local car makers had the lowest levels of automation and the highest labour turnover rates in the world-even after four years of rationalisation-and there were no prospects of achieving reasonable rates of return on their assets as the industry is structured now.

The report goes on to talk about the best performers in relation to quality cars. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that such is the production control in Australia that a few years ago when I bought a new car I found that the badge on the front of it was upside down. I find it incredible that a car could be turned out of a dealer's retail premises with the badge carrying its name and flaunting its brand upside down. When I took the car back for its first service I left instructions that the badge was to remain upside down so that I could carry with me this example of Australian production inspection, but when I got it back the badge had been put right. No dealer would allow his car to be upside-down badged. Whilst that happened a few years ago, it is totally on all fours with this report of the Automotive Industry Authority of a few days ago. Again, this is Australia under a Labor government.
In a report from one of the newspapers of this month under the heading `Qantas to use ``unqualified'' help' it is stated:
Qantas is hoping to contract out aircraft maintenance work to a Melbourne engineering company that union officials claim does not have the necessary qualified staff.
The article further states:
So far Qantas has sought to cope with its labour squeeze by farming out maintenance work to a diverse range of foreign airlines, and occasionally hiring foreign carriers to run its flights.

Our national carrier cannot meet its maintenance requirements from Australian sources. Topping all this was a report put out by the National Farmers Federation on 3 May which says that if one buys Australian, Australia will be in trouble. At first glance this seems an incredible statement to make, that by buying Australian one will harm Australia's export activities. The claim was that the average Australian family will be $2,000 a year worse off if the Federal Government's `buy Australian' promotion succeeds in its aims. The report says:
It is basically telling people to buy things which we're hopeless at making competitively.

The theme of that assertion is that if one buys Australian goods to reduce exports they will be made at an uncompetitive price because input costs will be totally out of line with the costs of other countries. All of this is an enormous reflection on this Government's management. Since 1983 the Government has been totally unable to argue successfully that previous governments should shoulder the blame. We find that Australia is heading along a road of overseas debt which will be unsustainable and that cannot continue at $1 billion a month. We find no plan from the Treasurer that will effectively reduce that debt of $1 billion a month. At a time when our exports are probably at the top of a cycle-their next move may be down-we find that we are unable to pay for our imports by $1 billion or more a month. The reason for this is the failure of this Government to provide leadership to those companies and individuals who want to do things for themselves that will ultimately lead into the export market. It is difficult in Australia under this Government to find the incentive which will allow us to produce at overseas competitive prices.

We have only to walk around the streets of any capital city in Australia to find the foremost example of restrictive trade practices. I am referring to the `no ticket, no start' banners which are all over the capital cities and provincial centres of Australia. People must pay for a licence to work. This Government does nothing to stop compulsory unionism which is the flag that represents all other restrictive trade practices. This practice may be somewhat open in the building industry. God help us when we examine the unfathomable depths of managed internal labour rip-offs and labour relations in respect of the wharves.

I conclude my remarks by not in any way trying to depress morale in this country. I want to draw attention to the fact that after six years in government the Labor Party has done little to reward those whose efforts are necessary to pull this country out of its problems. Until it can do something about the restrictive trade practices which stand between us and success, we will have no solution to the problems which confront us in terms of overseas debt. The solution lies in yesterday's activities, to which I referred when I began my speech. This will be argued out at another time and in another place. The solution is imminent for Australia. As to when that will occur depends on when the Prime Minister calls the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with some amazement to the opening remarks of the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steel Hall). He closed with the same kind of discourse. Yesterday marked the first anniversary of the opening of this new Parliament House-it is no longer new. Who would have thought that on such a day we would have seen the complete demoralisation of the Opposition. We saw the deposing of the former Opposition leader the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the recycling of the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and a similar sort of exercise in respect of the National Party of Australia. The two deposed leaders are sitting on the back bench. The former Leader of the Opposition is completely ignored by his followers. Yet, the honourable member for Boothby comes into this place and tries to say that this Opposition is capable of leading this country. That is absolute nonsense. I can only think that he must have been making a speech in order to try to get on the Opposition front bench, not that I do not think he might do a better job of it than some people who have been there over the past few years.

SPEECH.PARA: There are going to be a lot of changes on the Opposition front bench. This debate is not being broadcast but no doubt people will read my speech with interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Avidly!

—No doubt they will be reading the speech of the honourable member for Boothby as well. The plain fact is that they will make a judgment and will know which party should govern this country. The Labor Government will be the permanent government in this country, unlike the conservative governments of the past that have brought us to the dire economic straits that we are in today.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking in support of the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1989-90, the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1989-90 and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90, I want to take the opportunity to congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), on the Government's initiatives which were announced yesterday for science and technology. I want to say a few words about the macro-economic aspects of our economy before I turn to other things I would like to say about science and technology. It is going to be very difficult for the Government to ensure that its initiatives-which are aimed at helping Australians in need-are put in place. The initiatives which were contained in the April economic statement and the ministerial statements on science and technology which were made yesterday will strengthen the infrastructure of our economy, particularly in the science and technology areas. It seems to me that deregulation is the real problem. The deregulation of our financial system has meant that the Australian Government no longer has the ability to control Australia's economy. The Government can attempt to influence the economic system with the use of monetary policy, such as manipulating interest rates or fiscal measures or the imposition of taxes or tax relief. But the Government can only influence; it is not able to determine any particular economic outcome. If this was not bad enough, we have the problem that the Australian dollar has been involved in far more speculative pressure now than it ever had been prior to 1983, prior to deregulation.

The assertion that deregulation would ensure that there will be more foreign capital available for productive investment in Australia has been found in 1989 to be totally incorrect. Foreign investment in Australia has been largely used for speculative ventures or for short term gain. Takeover bids of existing companies by Australian and overseas corporations have done nothing to improve productivity or create wealth. Australian corporations, such as the Bond Corporation, are also investing overseas. This has resulted in increases in our overseas debt. That is quite apart from the morality of investing in a country where military dictatorship ensures that exorbitant profits can be gained at the expense of workers employed on starvation wages.

Deregulation was heralded as a means of providing more competition and giving an opportunity for private investors to invest in new industries. But private investment has let the Government down. Assets have been shifted overseas and Australian business, with some exceptions, has failed to invest in new enterprises in Australia. The Federal Government's restructuring of our industry, such as the steel and vehicle manufacturing industries, was essential. But where are the new export and import replacement industries which will help to turn around our adverse terms of trade?

It is true that Australia is in the middle of an investment boom. But the question is whether the investment is occurring in the export and import replacement industries. Nobody, least of all the Government, is able to answer that question, owing to a lack of statistical data. On the face of it, it would appear that financial deregulation is making few dollars available for venture capital and development finance for the new internationally competitive industries which must be created if the Federal Government's industry restructuring initiatives are to succeed. In the years since the introduction of financial deregulation it has been difficult to identify one productive investment or loan to a productive private enterprise which was made as a result of financial deregulation and which could not have been made on better terms under the previously regulated system.

Let us also not forget that, whilst having concentrated on the deregulation of the financial system, deregulation is also occurring in other areas of business and government activity. Whilst it can be argued that regulation in a number of areas can be seen to be archaic, and unnecessarily restrictive, it must also not be forgotten that regulation is a means of protecting the public from the operation of unscrupulous and avaricious business interests. I would be the last to deny that prudence in public enterprises and government activities is essential. Let us not take on the mantle of the conservatives and limit the public investment, which must be made if government is able to undertake responsible management of the economy.

In this sense, the expenditure of an additional $390m over the next five years for science and technology is an essential ingredient for the development of science and technology. The extension of the concessions is also a vital part of the support package. On a number of occasions in this House I have had to express my regret regarding cuts which have been made in funding for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). I have given a number of examples of the valuable research work being undertaken by the CSIRO, and I have detailed a number of research projects which were undertaken by the Entomology Division, for example. It follows, therefore, that I welcome the additional allocation of $90m over the next five years for new equipment and research projects, which need priority funding.

However, I still remain concerned as to whether the welcome addition to CSIRO funding is sufficient to ensure that many of our young and promising research scientists do not continue to leave the CSIRO, as they have been doing, to pursue more favourable research opportunities overseas. I congratulate the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) on his new appointment as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science and Technology. This involves additional responsibilities, and I know that he will carry them out well. I am sure that this is already in operation, but I hope that the Minister will continue to consult with the divisional heads of the CSIRO. Many of them have expressed their strong concerns at the loss of research scientists from their divisions and a consequent loss of many important research projects. I know that other Ministers, such as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), are also involved. I hope that these consultations will continue, because I believe that there are, and will continue to be over the years, problems with the CSIRO.

In the time remaining to me in this debate, I want to raise some valuable points in regard to scientific research. One aspect of research which I think is absolutely vital, and in relation to which I do not believe enough work has been done, concerns the area of renewable energy resources-water, wind and solar power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tidal.
—Yes, that is right-tidal power, too. There are areas, particularly in Western Australia, where we could--
—Tasmania.

—Yes, also in Tasmania, as the Minister says. I can see that the Minister is warming to my suggestions. I think that if we could put more research into those areas that could be a valuable source of funds.
—But how much research?
—I cannot say how much, because the Minister will continue to investigate those matters. However, it should certainly be more than we have been putting in in the past.
—It is pretty generalised.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will have an opportunity to speak in the debate later.

—It will be interesting to hear the honourable member's comments. I have mentioned the Entomology Division, and I also want to mention the Wildlife and Ecology Division, the Forestry and Forest Products Division, and the Soils Division. Over a number of months I have had the opportunity to become acquainted with all their work. I refer particularly to the valuable travelling exhibitions which have been brought here to Parliament House so that we can see the work that the CSIRO is doing, particularly on the greenhouse effect. Those exhibitions have been valuable, and I hope that the CSIRO will continue to ensure that such exhibitions come here, because it is difficult for us to get away from this House and visit them. I have also had an opportunity to visit the CSIRO's research establishments in the work that I have been doing as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts.

SPEECH.PARA: It is notable that at the moment in Britain British Petroleum is now investing very heavily in solar research. This is occurring for the first time. That is an example of the sort of research that ought to be going on here. After all, we have more potential for solar power here than Britain has. These days we are getting more sun in Melbourne than in Sydney. Perhaps that is the place where we should undertake the research.

I also want to mention the difficulty that we have had with pure research as it relates to applied research. I looked at a very interesting article by Gordon Sanson, and edited by Geoff Maslen, in the `Education Age' section of the Age of Tuesday, 28 February. The article, entitled `The cutting edge of evolution', is about the study of the teeth of mammals and other animals. Studies in this area can affect the research that we might undertake in a whole range of areas which would appear to be removed from the area of teeth. It was interesting to see that this kind of research:
. . . encompasses not only the biological disciplines of plant and animal anatomy, physiology, behaviour and ecology, but also physics, chemistry and engineering.

This is a holistic approach and it covers all these wide areas. This relates to pure research into the study of mammalian teeth. This is the sort of applied research that can come from pure research such as this, yet no-one would ever know. No-one would think that the study of the teeth of a kangaroo, perhaps half a million years old, could be used for applied research in this country. But it can, and we must not neglect our pure research work.

Another matter that I want to mention concerns the National Bushfire Research Unit, which, I am pleased to say, was given permanent funding after the 1984 bushfire report of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, as it was at that time. The National Bushfire Research Unit has been doing some valuable work in relation to bushfires and into how we might prevent their very serious effects. In recent years we have not had too many serious bushfires in Australia, but they will recur-they always do. It is absolutely essential that bodies such as the National Bushfire Research Unit should be given more funding.

In the few minutes that I have left, I would like to mention that in relation to forest research, for example, the Soils Division and the Forestry and Forest Products Division have been very worried about the cuts in funds which have occurred in those divisions. I hope that the new money that has been provided will enable those divisions to continue to carry on some of their very valuable research projects, which are so important in a country where two-thirds of the land surface is degraded. In that serious situation it is absolutely important that the consultation with those divisional heads should continue. The money is there for equipment and new research projects, but what about the existing research staff, and also the technical staff?

One of the things that worries me is what will happen to the technical staff. Will the funding that is being provided be sufficient to ensure that the technical staff are able to stay on in the divisions? For the research scientists to do their work properly, they must have support from the highly skilled technical officers who are required to work with them. I commend the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, who is at the table, for his initiative, and I commend the Prime Minister for the new funding that has been provided for science overall. I commend the Bills to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being approximately 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer him to a question I asked in the House yesterday concerning the rate of inflation he assumed when calculating real household disposable income in his April statement. Now that he has had time to check, will he inform the House what rate of inflation was assumed? Why were Treasury officials instructed not to release the rate of inflation to the media during the press lock-up on the day of the April statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very peculiar set of questions. I was asked the question yesterday by the acting shadow Treasurer.
—No, you didn't.
—He was asked the question.
—But he didn't answer it.
—We have another deputy speaker over there running the House from the sidelines.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. The Treasurer has just reflected grossly upon the Chair and should withdraw.
—I was too busy being distracted by the honourable member for O'Connor to hear what the Treasurer said. The Treasurer will continue with his answer.

—Exactly. Yesterday I was asked by the acting shadow Treasurer what underlying deflator was used in estimating the increase in household disposable income. As I recall the question, I was asked what deflator was used and what was the rate. The Prime Minister is showing me the table which has asterisks next to the words `deflated by the private consumption deflator'. Apparently, this is a matter which is supposed to stand the cut and thrust of Question Time. The acting shadow Treasurer asks, `Which deflator is used?' when the table states that it is the private consumption deflator. If the greenest backbencher in the place asked me, `What is the deflator which the Department of the Treasury has used to calculate the increase in household disposable income?' and the table says it is the private consumption deflator, out of sheer kindness I would say to such an honourable member, `It is a private consumption deflator; you might not have noticed'. But to somebody who prides himself on having some technical capacity, which has yet to be demonstrated in the last 18 months, and who asks such a question I would say, `It is here. Apparently you don't know'.

ANSWER.PARA: In his devastating follow-up question he refers to the lock-up in the Treasury cafeteria, and suggests that the Treasurer is apparently not telling journalists what the private consumption deflator rate for the year was assumed to be. In other words he is saying, `Oh, Treasury officers are keeping mum on the private consumption deflator; therefore, the Government is hiding something'. The private consumption deflator for the calculation is 6.75 per cent. It is not terribly strange considering that the private consumption deflator in the national accounts, from my recollection, was just over 6 per cent and the consumer price index is running, according to the Australian Statistician, at 6.9 per cent. So it is 6.9 per cent for inflation to date and the private consumption deflator is 6.5 per cent as used by the Treasury in the calculation.

But these are issues which are coming up at Question Time. We are asked, `What deflator is being used?' when the chart says, `(a) forecast, (b) non-farm sector, (c) deflated by the private consumption deflator'. That is on page 29 of the April statement. Yet the honourable member asked me yesterday what deflator is used. The chart says what it is. Today we have the killer question: `What is the rate?' The answer is 6.75 per cent which is almost at the inflation rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to specific concerns expressed by parents, staff and disabled clients of some Endeavour Foundation workshops and activity therapy centres in Brisbane, and to my requests that his Department seek resolution in coordination with the Endeavour Foundation. Given the serious nature of these concerns, and recognising Endeavour's significant role in providing facilities for disabled people over a number of years, can he assist in the process of resolving these concerns for the benefit of disabled people and their carers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of recent media coverage which has detailed staff concerns about the Endeavour Foundation services for people with disabilities, and alleged action by Endeavour to dismiss staff who raised those concerns. I recognise that the honourable member for Lilley has taken a deep and personal interest in this issue in Brisbane. The concerns raised are about the conditions of employment and wages paid to people with disabilities, and are generally consistent with the concerns of this Government's review of programs for the handicapped. The Government is committed to improving the range and quality of services provided to people with disabilities and the new Disability Services Act is aimed at achieving that objective. Under the Act, organisations can now be held accountable for the services they provide to people with disabilities. The achievement of positive outcomes for people with disabilities, such as a fair day's pay for a fair day's work, is the central theme of the new Disability Services Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Lilley has written to me, and has raised this issue again today, seeking a joint inquiry involving my Department and the Endeavour Foundation into the particular activities of Endeavour's Brisbane North branch. I have approved in principle a joint review and have asked my Department to progress the matter in conjunction with Endeavour. Reviews of this type have been undertaken before in relation to other organisations funded under the Disability Services Act and have resulted in the improvement of services for people with disabilities. I hope that Endeavour will respond to the offer of a joint review so that we can speedily settle the problems in that area.
