QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY POLICY: AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy inform the House of the benefits to primary industries which flow from the Government's science and technology statement which was announced in the Parliament this week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a rather distorted debate running in the country for quite a while about the levels of research spending. I thought that the statements put out by my colleagues and the Prime Minister went some way to remedy that, and to point out what some of the facts are in this whole area. The major thrust of the Government's statement was to increase the links with industry and to improve the level of industry funding for research and development. The primary industries which I represent have already increased their contributions through rural industry research funds which are matched by the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: What has been forgotten in this whole debate is that research and development spending by these means has grown from $33m in 1978-79 to something like $164m in 1988-89. The Opposition never talks about that when it grizzles about funding for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). Of course, it does acknowledge the success of such industry directed funding in its rural policy document. It is one of the 34 Government initiatives that it will maintain. The word `maintain' appears a lot in its policy document. This $164m in industry responsive research and development is accessible to universities and the CSIRO on a competitive basis. We are getting a far more competitive and healthy environment for research in this country. But, again, all honourable members opposite ever talk about is the bottom line in a Budget statement.

Given the response from rural industries, the focus of the primary industries and energy statement is on policy principles as a guide to government funding and the ways in which the administration of these funds can be improved. There has been a specific extra allocation of $1.3m directed towards encouraging more consultation on priorities between scientists and the relevant industries and greater attention to commercialising research results. This is responsive, industry effective research and development. I point out that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy now spends about $200m a year on research and employs about 1,000 people within the Department itself, in the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Research Economics, in the Bureau of Mineral Resources, and partially within the Bureau of Rural Research. As well, there are the rural research and development corporations and the research councils. Too often all this is overlooked.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What is the basis of the disagreement between the Chairman of the Public Works Committee, the honourable member for Throsby, and the Minister regarding the environmental impact study on the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport? Will the Minister give the House a categoric commitment that the already unreasonably long period of 18 months allocated for the environmental impact study will not be extended?

—There is no disagreement between me and the honourable member for Throsby in regard to the environmental impact study-absolutely none. He said nothing about the environmental impact study. He talked about the role of the Public Works Committee in relation to Federal Airports Corporation projects. That, of course, is a matter for Government policy consideration. When we have decided on that, it will be announced in the Parliament.

—Will the Minister for Trade Negotiations detail to the House progress on developing the concept of regional economic cooperation proposed by the Prime Minister when he visited Seoul, Korea, earlier this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Dick Woolcott, has just completed visits to nine regional countries to sound out their reaction to the Prime Minister's proposal for regional economic cooperation. I am pleased to report to the House that the reactions have been very encouraging and in fact suggest widespread support for both the objective of enhanced regional cooperation and the ministerial meeting later this year. I would like to stress one point, especially against the background of a statement by the Leader of the Opposition yesterday, that is, that what is being considered is a framework for regional economic cooperation to progress matters of mutual economic interest within the region. Most importantly, from Australia's point of view, this includes how countries in the region can work to secure a more effective open multilateral trading system. We are not-I emphasise not-talking about developing a regional trading bloc.

ANSWER.PARA: While I have had some difficulty in deciphering what the Leader of the Opposition said yesterday at his press conference, it seems to contrast starkly with what we are on about. Yesterday he said:

. . . take a broader perspective to see Australia playing an effective role in the fastest growing region in the world . . . to be taking beyond the mere talk of OECD type secretariat for interchange of views.
He went on to say:

I would be looking for a trading arrangement as such in circumstances where Britain enters into the whole European, United Europe, if you like, United States of Europe, after 1992, to misuse the term, where the Soviet Union herself is freeing up, where the People's Republic of China has 10 years of that and where North American free trade arrangement has taken place.
Dare I say that that is the end of the quote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you have some difficulty following that?

—I did have some difficulty following that. We have waited six years for some policy on trade from the other side. I only hope that yesterday's exposition is not the best it can do. I can only reiterate that the Government's view is that a regional trading arrangement or trading bloc is not a feasible option and it is contrary to Australian interests for the Opposition even to be raising the prospect.
—Oh, that is ludicrous. You show no understanding of your brief.

—The Leader of the Opposition interjects that that is ludicrous. I can assure him that, as a result of the tour of the regional countries made by Mr Dick Woolcott, the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, there is no interest in such a proposition in this area at all. I remind those opposite of the difficulties in developing the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand-a country which, when looked at from a social, economic and political viewpoint, is very similar to us. The likelihood of being able to develop such a trade arrangement with countries so diverse as those in the region and the core group of countries that the Prime Minister took the matter up with is almost non-existent. Equally, in reply to the interjection of the Leader of the Opposition, any attempt to do so would completely undermine our arguments against the European Commission-that is, that the Europe 1992 exercise should be outward looking and should not be, as some people fear, a fortress Europe.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously, it is in the best interests of Australia and other small and medium sized trading nations to maintain an open multilateral system in which we keep the small players alive and they are able to get a fairer go. From the Secretary's visit, which I referred to earlier, it is apparent that that view is shared by our neighbours, contrary to the view expressed yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition in relation to his plans, if they mean what I think they mean. As I indicated earlier, it is a bit difficult to understand what he was on about.

He then went on to say that trade was the lifeblood of this country. I was delighted to hear him say that because in the last two years and previously, when my colleague the now Minister for Employment, Education and Training was then the Minister, I do not think that anything came from that side of the House to indicate that it was even relevant to the existence of this country. In relation to the multilateral and the bilateral relations, no government has worked harder to achieve this than the Hawke Labor Government.

I will close on this note. I would like those opposite to think of a few things. I ask them: Which government established the Cairns Group to fight for our farmers in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round? Which government initiated the comprehensive China action plan? Which government secured an opening of the Japanese beef market? Which government reached an agreement with Thailand for the development of an economic cooperation agreement and is establishing new levels of dialogue with Indonesia? Which government initiated a trade and commercial development program for Korea? The answer to all of those questions is the Hawke Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Mayo.
—Honourable members opposite are hoping so.
—Order! Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to offers of Commonwealth land made to the States at the housing summit. Did the Commonwealth offer a 51 hectare site at Beam's Road, Carseldine, to the Queensland Government? Is it a fact that, at the date of the Commonwealth's offer, this land had already been sold by the Commonwealth to a consortium of foreign buyers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one honourable member just interjected, `That is an old one'. The list of properties that I put forward to the Premiers at the supply side policy conference on Commonwealth land for housing comprised a number of properties which the Commonwealth thought we would be able to release for housing over the next five years as they progressively become available. The property at Carseldine was certainly going to be used for housing. It is true that it was already on the market. But I made it clear to the Premiers that we would be offering land, either to the States or to the private sector. There was no commitment by me that all of the properties on that list, whether they were in the five-year list or the long term list, would be exclusively offered to the States. That is a fact. In my answer the other day I pointed out how some of the properties I gave as examples would in fact be offered to the States and some would be offered direct to the private sector. Some would be offered to the private sector if the States rejected them.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude my answer by saying that Mr Ahern, despite what he and the Opposition have said about the property at Carseldine, has already indicated interest in another property at Cooper's Plains and in fact has made an offer to buy. I will be coming back to him on that within the next month. Furthermore, we looked at a big property at Belmont the other day and I intend to talk to the Premier of Queensland about it in the near future.

I repeat: of all the properties that we intend to release and later relocate agencies from and look at, there is absolutely no commitment that every one of them will be offered to the States. The Opposition has a lot to say about the Government's efforts in releasing Commonwealth land for housing. I am reminded of the fact that the Opposition was in power from 1975 to early 1983, during which time no effort whatsoever was made by the former Government to examine the correct use of Commonwealth land-whether we were making the best use of it; whether the Department of Defence, or the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, or any other agency, were making the best possible use of the land which they occupied.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I take a point of order on the basis of precedence. A previous Speaker once said, `I now ask him to deal with the question'. The Minister has done everything but answer the question as to whether the property was sold and is now talking about the Opposition.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The Minister will answer the question.
—Answer the question.
—I have already answered that question.
—If the Minister has answered the question; he probably should resume his seat.

—I finally make the point that in all the time the Opposition spent in office in the late 1970s and early 1980s, absolutely nothing was done to examine whether the Commonwealth was getting the best use out of the land that its agencies occupied. This Government is now examining whether particular properties should be made available to the States or to the private sector.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. In the context of the Government's agenda and award restructuring for women in the workplace, can the Minister say what the implications are of today's labour market programs for women, particularly in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and for his interest in this very important subject. Award restructuring and workplace reform are as much about giving a fair go to all employees in the workplace as they are about giving our industry a fair go in the marketplace. The honourable member is very much aware of this. He has been very much involved in the commitment to improving opportunities for Tasmanian women in the workplace.

ANSWER.PARA: Together with this Government's policies of affirmative action and equal opportunity, award restructuring provides an unprecedented opportunity for women to be given a fairer go in the workplace. That can happen through better training, job redesign, flexibility in working arrangements and better provision of career paths. This Government has initiated a range of measures to assist Australian women in the work force. We are now seeing the results of those measures. At a national level, some 700,000 of the 1.3 million new jobs that have been created under this Government have gone to women. That has happened at a time when there has been a record high level of participation by women in the work force. At the same time, we have seen a substantial growth in retention rates for girls in secondary schools and enrolment rates for women in our universities. The national unemployment rate for women of 6.7 per cent is at its lowest level in a decade. Much has been done to improve opportunities for Australian women, particularly to gain employment. But we should note the fact that Tasmania has the worst unemployment rate for women-10.9 per cent-and that the second prize for the worst unemployment rate goes to Queensland. They are two conservative States, so we can understand why that has happened.

This Government has done a great deal to improve the lot of women but a great deal more still remains to be done. The statistics I have quoted show a genuine improvement in the position of women in our society. This has been the result of the deliberate policy initiatives of this Government-initiatives which meet the real concerns of women and their families. These initiatives have not been supported by the Tasmanian Government. Whilst most of the other States have been pursuing policies aimed at closing the gender gap on employment and career opportunities, those policies have been ignored by the Tasmanian Government.

Over the past six years, the Commonwealth and every mainland government except Queensland have enacted legislation on either affirmative action, sex discrimination or equal opportunity for women. That legislation has helped underpin the change in attitude towards women in the workplace. Women are now seeing greater opportunities in the workplace and in respect of jobs, careers and education than ever before. But this is not happening in Tasmania. In short, the Tasmanian Government denied Tasmanian women fair opportunity in the workplace and in education. They have lost jobs, they have lost careers. I can say to the honourable member and to the women of Tasmania that the only solution that is before them on Saturday is a change from the Gray Government and the arrival of a new Labor government in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to the question asked by the honourable member for Mayo, and ask him specifically: Had the property referred to by the honourable member in his question already been sold when it was offered for sale by his Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that the list of properties supplied to the Premiers of the various States at the Premiers Conference on housing in no way inferred that each and every one of those properties would be offered to the States. The documentation from which I quote, and which I will table in a moment, on the property for Carseldene says:

ANSWER.PARA: This property of 51 hectares was formerly used by the Army as a driver training facility. It is currently under disposal for residential development and awaiting settlement.

The document I am quoting from is entitled Commonwealth Housing Land Task Force: Special Premiers Conference, 3 March 1989. I repeat: the status of that property, as with the status of most of the other properties on the list, would have been, should have been, clearly understood by the Premiers. It was not available to them to purchase as some of the other properties might have been. As far as the total list of properties is concerned, it was the Commonwealth's intention, and still is, that over the years they will be made available, if possible, for housing either to the States or to the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Administrative Services.
—Ask him about Sydney Airport.

—Do not worry about Sydney Airport. The honourable member does not have to worry about that; we are looking after it. What productivity gains have been achieved in respect of micro-reforms to government services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Services to government are, of course, a very important part of the public sector. Unfortunately, over many years the provision of these services, particularly as far as their administration and cost of delivery are concerned, had become quite rigid and uncompetitive. I am pleased to be able to report to the House that over the past year or so we have engaged in a major task of reform. In fact, we have looked at something like 12 major common service areas and have taken decisions on them. The three criteria that the Government and I used were, firstly, whether the service should be subject to cost recovery; secondly, whether it should be commercialised, that is, whether its clients should be untied; and, thirdly, which areas should be preserved and funded from the budget in the public interest.

ANSWER.PARA: The combination of those three measures as applied to all of the agencies that were examined results in two things: firstly, the exercise of demand control over the client agency and, secondly, an efficiency incentive as to the cost of the delivery of the service. Several very brief examples of what has occurred include the fact that the very large Australian Construction Services agency has been subject to cost recovery for its services and the fact that clients will be untied from 1990-91 in respect of design and construction services. I can name two public interest activities that will be funded from the Budget in future. The Australian Government Publishing Service and the services it provides to this Parliament clearly should be tied in the public interest and, of course, funded from the Budget through cost recovery appropriations to the parliamentary departments. That has been done. The Australian Government Analytical Laboratories represents an area that should be tied in the public interest, and that is obviously analytical work in respect of the analysis of drugs and imported food under the Customs Act.

In respect of productivity, I make what is, I hope, a very important point: the result of all of this reform obviously creates downward pressure to become more efficient. In the past year or so, the total numbers employed in the Department of Administrative Services across 12 divisions has been reduced by over 1,900 people. That creates an onward cost saving year on year of $55m. In Australian Construction Services alone, where reductions have occurred over the past several months, by the end of June the work force will have been reduced by 550. In the Transport and Storage Group (TSG), the services of which include the provision of car with driver to entitlees, including parliamentarians, there are some problems with administration that we are tackling. Currently, it has 2,100 employees across the board, many of whom are car drivers. I have decided that we ought to reduce the total TSG employment level by something like 700 and then perhaps use some part time workers, which would make a net reduction of approximately 450. We hope to introduce that change over several years.

The important part of all this is that it is happening so far without industrial disputation, in consultation with the trade unions, and through the offering of voluntary redundancy packages to the employees concerned. I think that $55m already saved year on year is a quite substantial achievement, and it is certainly more than any previous government, Minister or department achieved. We are committed to efficiency in the Public Service. We will achieve that goal. The reforms are already under way and I am happy to say that not one of these redundancies has had to be achieved or will be achieved through either sacking or compulsory redundancy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the serious air traffic congestion occurring at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and to the closure of the airport to all incoming and departing aircraft last weekend. I ask the Minister: Is the Government fully aware of the hardship suffered by thousands of passengers and the loss being sustained by airlines and, in particular, the smaller airlines, such as those operating to and from country centres in New South Wales, which now face serious financial problems because of the effect of the disruptions and delays? What action is the Government taking to try to overcome the congestion caused by the timeslot limitations and closures imposed by the air traffic controllers, who claim that adequate staff are not available to enable full manning of the air control system at the airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the closure of Sydney Airport last Friday, which certainly caused great disruption to thousands of travellers, both domestic and international. It was a rather regrettable development, to say the least. It occurred because of the lack of air traffic controllers to come to work given that there had been a high level of supposed sickness occurring amongst air traffic controllers in Sydney. This level of sickness has increased considerably in the past few weeks and was particularly high when the Government was moved to seek bans clauses in the air traffic controllers' award. Following that, the sickness level dropped off somewhat but it has remained at a much higher level than it used to be. I might also say that the sickness level seems to drop remarkably on weekends, when penalty rates apply. The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), which is the employer of the air traffic controllers, has now instituted a system of requiring a doctor's certificate from any air traffic controller who reports sick so that there will be some verification that they are sick. In the circumstances that seems to be a highly desirable development.

ANSWER.PARA: Discussions have been occurring since the major industrial action by air traffic controllers in Sydney and to a lesser extent those in Melbourne a couple of weeks ago. There were discussions between the CAA and the air traffic controllers' union with regard to finalising a number of aspects that it was agreed would be examined in the discussions they had to resolve that industrial action. Those negotiations have continued reasonably productively. The intended end result is that a case will be taken to the Industrial Relations Commission for award restructuring for air traffic controllers as a small group of special cases that will come on before the rest. The Sydney air traffic controllers, however, seem not to accept that this is the appropriate way to go.

It is my belief that the supposed high level of sickness at Sydney has much more to do with the desire of some people there to pursue a wage claim which is way outside the wage fixing guidelines. All I can say is that, in the circumstances, the CAA is doing all it can to ensure that services are maintained. There have been discussions with the union since events of last Friday night. Part of the matters which were up for discussion following the agreement a couple of weeks ago was a review of staffing levels. That review is continuing as a matter of considerable urgency and will be completed in another week or two, following which, if there is a need for any more air traffic controllers to be employed, that will be done.

However, the major problem stems from the fact that there is a level of supposed sickness occurring at Sydney Airport which is far above the historic levels and is not being brought about by their being required to work excessive overtime. They are working to a level of overtime which is that determined by the Industrial Relations Commission as being reasonable, which is one extra shift of seven hours per fortnight. That is the only amount of overtime that any air traffic controller is being required to work. I think everyone would agree that this is hardly an excessive level of hours for people to work, even given that they do have a stressful occupation.

So the question of their numbers is being addressed. I believe that the level of sickness is artificially high, and the action of the CAA requiring doctors' certificates, hopefully, will do something to bring that back and that will mean that there will not be a shortage of air traffic controllers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of claims by the Leader of the Opposition that the Government has given up on social security reforms? Are the claims accurate? Will the Government adopt the changes that the Leader of the Opposition has called for?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the new Leader of the Opposition on Andrew Olle's program this morning referred in passing to what he described as the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister in terms of a commitment with respect to child poverty. He went on to suggest that the Government had given up on income security reform or social reform. That is an extraordinary statement coming from the Opposition Leader. One of the first things that he ought to do is get himself a briefing on what has occurred in relation to social security and, more broadly, welfare reform since this Government has been in power. Indeed, during the Budget last year we actually put out a book which the Leader of the Opposition might like to read. He would see a very significant record there in terms of reform.
—You are not serious.

—The Leader of the Opposition ought to have word with his friend and mine, Bishop Hollingworth, about the question of child poverty. While he recognises, and will see from remarks of the honourable member, a kind of cynicism which exists in the community, he and I and certainly the Prime Minister recognise that cynicism in the community for what it is and recognise that one of the things about leadership, which apparently the Leader of the Opposition thinks he possesses more of than the former Leader of the Opposition, is to take on board commitments to those people in the community who, as everyone recognises, have the greatest need. That commitment means, of course, not some vague vapid nonsense about being concerned for families but a commitment to budgetary strategy. On the one side of the ledger, that means taking the kind of tough decisions that our Government has been prepared to take and to restrain expenditure. On the other side of the ledger--
—Eliminate child poverty by 1990.

—You can see that he is just as sensitive as his predecessor. On the other side of the ledger, that means putting in place reforms that have some real priority about them. I do not think any commentator has suggested, in terms of the social security system, that our Government has had anything other than the priorities of ensuring that those most in need get the greatest assistance. I have not seen a serious commentator suggest other than that the Government's commitment with respect to child poverty has been met by very significant reform; not by throwing money all around the place but by money targeted in terms of a constructive reform of the whole system of family payments.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, that is only one dimension of the reforms that this Government has attempted. I do not want to go through all the areas, but I think we have, in many respects, been one of the leaders in the world in linking income security to labour market reform. In income reform, for example, we have seen the importance of recognising the link between educational payments and what we are doing in the social security system. The common allowance reform will stand as one of the great reforms of this present Government. We have recognised that what we should be about as a government is opening up opportunities for people and not locking them into the social security system. The evidence for that is there not only in terms of the massive reductions in the numbers on unemployment benefit but also in programs like jobs, education and training (JET) and new start. To take new start as an example-and perhaps if those opposite listen they might learn something-in the new start program, 5,000 people on long term unemployment benefit have already returned to work in just a little more than two months. The commitment of the Government to social reform is stronger than that of any previous Government. The reforms, particularly as they come out of the Cass Review of Social Security, will certainly be seen as a great achievement in terms of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order: on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition, could I accept the offer made by the Minister when he suggested that in 18 months the shadow Minister has never provided adequate--

—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Bradfield will resume his seat. I warn honourable members, as a general point, that it has often been seen in the House that members take points of order which are not in fact points of order. They could be said to be--
—I am accepting his offer. I've been waiting 18 months for it.

—I warn the honourable member for Bradfield. They could be said to be interrupting the affairs of the House. Members who wish to take points of order should take proper points of order and not attempt to take up offers that they might think Ministers are making to them.

—I do not want to be distracted, but let me say that nobody before has published a series of reports such as the Cass reports and then pursued them in a totally open way following consultation and, indeed, inviting submissions from the Opposition.

—The honourable member for Flinders will resume his seat.
—May I complete my point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This statement marks a new chapter in defence's relationship with Australian industry. The defence policies adopted by the Hawke Government over the past six years have transformed our defence strategy and reshaped the Australian Defence Force. Defence self-reliance is inextricably linked to our industrial capacity. The capacity of our industrial base to support our defence effort is as important to self-reliance as a Defence Force structure tailored to our strategic environment. Our policies have played a cardinal role in overhauling industries vital to our defence. These embrace electronics, aerospace, shipbuilding and ship repair, heavy and general engineering, and munitions. These are essential elements of an industrial base to serve our defence needs. They are equally essential for the type of commercial industry structure this Government has sought to encourage to serve Australia into the next century: a structure that is global in outlook, export oriented, and internationally competitive.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to announce today another major step in this process with the formal launching of Australian Defence Industries (ADI). ADI has taken over the major defence industry facilities still remaining in government ownership. These establishments were previously controlled by the Office of Defence Production within my Department of Defence. Australian Defence Industries, a government-owned corporation, will operate on a commercial basis. ADI will have an annual turnover of $400m. It will commence as the largest single supplier of defence equipment and services. Instead of 11 independently-operating government establishments, we now have a single company with four operating divisions: naval engineering-principally the Garden Island dockyard; ammunition and missiles; weapons and engineering; and military clothing. We have been fortunate to obtain the services of the former Secretary of my Department, Mr Alan Woods, as Chairman of the new company.

The launching of Australian Defence Industries completes the process we began in 1984, when we abolished the Department of Defence Support, which had been created by our coalition predecessors. By 1984 Defence Support had become one of the largest Public Service departments, with a staff exceeding 15,000, a total outlay of $598m, of which only $242m was recovered from sales to customers.

Since that decision in 1984, this Government has embarked on a quiet revolution in the Australian defence industry. We have undertaken a massive program of restructuring, rationalisation and commercialisation. We have closed or are closing two government-owned defence factories, the Albion Explosives Factory and the Explosives Factory Maribyrnong.

We sold the Williamstown Naval Dockyard in Victoria and the aircraft workshop in South Australia. We converted the former Government Aircraft Factories at Fishermen's Bend and Avalon into a government-owned enterprise, Aerospace Technologies of Australia, run strictly on business lines. In the last five years the annual cost to the taxpayer of subsidies to our government-owned defence factories has been cut by around $250m. That is not a one-off saving. It is a permanent reduction in defence outlays each year in that area.

With the launching of Australian Defence Industries we have taken a further significant step away from the bureaucracy and politics that have bedevilled these defence establishments for so many years. At the same time, the transformation has given us the opportunity to restructure awards and employment levels. Overall, our actions have reduced the number of employees in dedicated defence manufacturing facilities from more than 15,000 to 6,800. This has resulted in a saving of $92m in the wages bill alone. Another round of staff reductions at ADI commencing this year involved about 1,300 positions. ADI's head office in Canberra now has just 35 people. Just four years ago the comparable number was 1,000. There will be further major savings, about $8m a year, with the decision to close the explosives factory at Maribyrnong over the next 18 months or so.

I must emphasise, however, that this has not been a negative exercise; a `slash and burn' pursuit of efficiency no matter what the consequences. Our aim has been to make government factories and dockyards not just competitive, but an integral part of Australian industry. These factories served us well in earlier times. Australia has been in the munitions business for more than 100 years. By the end of World War I we had five government-owned defence factories. During World War II, by mobilising Australian industry around the core of government-owned factories, we achieved genuinely outstanding results in defence production. In April 1940 Australia sent Britain 30,000 rifles. Within 14 months we had also sent 100 million rounds of small arms ammunition. To put this in perspective, British industry in 1940 was able to produce only 81,000 rifles; with some troops being forced to drill with dummy weapons. Other Australian defence production establishments responded with similarly spectacular increases in production. During the war, no fewer than 10 shipyards built three destroyers, 12 frigates and 60 corvettes.

Successive conservative governments after World War II failed to recognise and act on the fundamental change in our strategic circumstances. They maintained massive excess capacity in progressively more obsolete capabilities. As a result the defence industries facilities inherited by this Government were in poor shape. They suffered from low morale, chronic undercapitalisation, excess capacity and totally unsatisfactory industrial relations.

The Hawke Government has finally swept away the long held notion that industry capabilities needed for defence purposes must be carefully identified, and then preserved at public expense. That is not the way to go in today's environment. In fact, it is self-defeating. Our defence industry policy has clear objectives which were spelt out in the 1987 defence White Paper. That document pointed out that, while a substantial commercial workload can provide a base from which to bid for defence orders, the inverse is rarely true. The peacetime requirements of the Australian Defence Force are not usually capable of providing a viable long term baseload for individual firms or industry sectors. An insistence on maintaining specific defence industry capabilities leads to a freezing of technology and, ultimately, to a decline in capability. Defence, like the economy at large, is best served by an industry structure that can hold its own in the world market, capable of recognising opportunities and seizing them. We have not abandoned the idea of nurturing particular capabilities in special circumstances, but government support of that kind is no longer an easy way out for firms unable to compete in the commercial area.

This contribution to the Government's micro-reform agenda was possible because, as my colleague the Treasurer (Mr Keating) puts it, we tackled the big picture first. We recognised that a more responsive financial sector was a prerequisite for change. By floating the dollar, relaxing exchange controls, and freeing up the banks we gave the economy access to goods and services at world prices. We have signalled that the days of Australia's inward-looking, protectionist stance have gone for good. Industry has been a direct beneficiary of the accord process with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Government has succeeded in maintaining a wages policy under which real unit labour costs have fallen by about 10 per cent in the past five years. That restraint will continue under the arrangements announced by the Treasurer on 12 April. The wages-tax agreement contained in that statement will further consolidate the linkage between productivity and wages, and between wages restraint and the growth of employment.

The Government is overseeing a sweeping overhaul of the industrial award system, the most momentous change in 80 years in the sphere of industrial relations. The overhaul of occupational classifications and skill categorisations promises immense benefits to both employers and employees. This will allow Australians to adapt more easily to changing technologies. These initiatives are reshaping industrial practices so that industry can adjust to a more competitive environment. In defence our principal instrument for change has been a greatly expanded capital procurement program. Fourteen years ago the capital program represented about 18 per cent of defence outlays. Today the equivalent figure is around 30 per cent. We intend to keep it at that level.

When this Government took office the average level of local content in new equipment acquisitions was about 30 per cent. Now it has reached 59 per cent. In the 1990s we estimate that it will reach an average of 70 per cent as projects such as the new submarine and the Anzac frigate project gather pace. Our objective is to foster Australian prime contractors able to achieve high levels of local content without subsidies. The shipbuilding, ship repair and engineering industries exemplify this approach.

The submarine project costing nearly $4 billion and the Anzac frigate project costing about $5 billion have prompted a major restructuring of the Australian shipbuilding and ship repair industries. This restructuring started with the sale to the private sector of the former Williamstown Naval Dockyard in Melbourne. Employment in the dockyard has reduced from 2,200 to 750 and the productivity of the overall organisation has increased at least fourfold. The landmark industrial award at the dockyard has fundamentally changed the way people look at their jobs. People are encouraged to develop their skills in order to become an integral part of a multiskilled work force. Some 23 unions have been reduced to three. All this has occurred in a dockyard once notorious for inefficiency. Last Friday Williamstown dockyard launched, three months ahead of schedule, the frigate FFG 05, the first warship launched in this country in nearly 20 years.

Under this Government, Australia is now back in the business of naval warship building. The owner, Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON), is tendering the German Meko design for the Anzac ships, in conjunction with Cable Price Downer, a New Zealand engineering firm. The decision to close Cockatoo Island Dockyard and the Wran Government's decision to close the Newcastle State Dockyard cleared the way for the emergence of a second bidder for the Anzac frigate contract. Australian Warship Systems, comprising TNT, Carrington Slipways, AWA and the New Zealand engineering firm McConnell Dowell, has teamed with the Dutch company Royal Schelde and has proposed the Dutch M class design.

Another important development has been our decision to relocate half the fleet to Western Australia over the next 10 years. To accommodate that move, the naval base HMAS Stirling is being expanded at a cost of more than $300m. We now envisage two centres of ship repair located near the main naval bases on either side of the continent. In Western Australia the facility is to be established entirely in the private sector with investment in the first stage totalling more than $20m. A shiplift has been built and the first docking of an Oberon submarine has been completed. The destroyer escort HMAS Swan is currently undergoing refit at the facility. Garden Island Dockyard will remain the east coast ship repair centre and will remain in government ownership as part of ADI. It will increasingly have to look to the commercial market for part of its workload.

The Hawke Government has also initiated important changes in the aerospace industry. This sector developed its wartime skills in areas such as missiles and aircraft. The Ikara missile and the Nomad aircraft were at world standard in their day. However, as time passed the industry lagged, particularly in management, finance and marketing. As I mentioned earlier, the aviation and aerospace activities of the former Government Aircraft Factories have now been combined in a new company, Aerospace Technologies of Australia (ASTA), established by legislation of this Parliament. ASTA is an independent, fully commercial company, with a board of directors experienced in business and keen to see the company expand on a profitable basis, both in Australian and international markets. It has made substantial progress in this direction already.

ASTA's most recent success is a contract from Boeing to manufacture the composite rudder system for its 757 aircraft. This is the firm's third major contract with Boeing and has a potential value of around $125m. In addition, the company has signed an agreement with the Sikorsky company to take over from Hawker de Havilland as the prime local contractor for the assembly and test program of the Navy's eight second phase Seahawk helicopters. I am pleased to be able to advise the House that the ASTA board is now exploring the sale of some equity in the company. Companies with key technologies, or access to markets, may be invited to make strategic investments in relevant parts of ASTA and its facilities. The Government believes that this will maximise returns to the taxpayers of Australia as well as enhancing the aerospace industry's prospects.

My Department has put its relationship with the rest of the aerospace industry on a normal commercial footing. The private sector counterpart to ASTA is Hawker de Havilland, which took over the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation. Hawker has restructured substantially and has been winning defence and commercial work. It recently signed a commercial development contract with McDonnell Douglas to design a new light helicopter which has already achieved preliminary sales. This industry structure is based on two major companies as prime contractors associated with specialist sub-contractors. It offers the best compromise between competition and economies of scale and bodes well for the future.

The defence program has also stimulated change in the electronics and systems industry, which, in a strategic sense, probably has become the industry of greatest importance to the defence effort. In the last three years the submarine and frigate projects has generated major opportunities in the electronics sector. Most of the world's leading companies in this field now take a more active interest in Australia and are doing business with Australian companies. As with shipbuilding and aerospace, local companies are starting to act as prime contractors and linking with overseas firms to tap their technologies and access to markets. They are starting to acquire the necessary technical, financial and managerial expertise to compete effectively.

There is no doubt that big defence projects have attracted into Australia technologies and investment in this industry that would not be here otherwise. Some are already looking actively for civil sector work to maintain Australian operations for the long term. To an important degree, the increasing sophistication of some sections of Australia's electronics industry has been driven by defence-based research. Perhaps the outstanding example is our remarkable Jindalee over-the-horizon radar system, which will give our forces a surveillance reach of some 3,000 kilometres. Over a decade of research and trials the Defence Science and Technology Organisation has established the principles used in the system and the hardware and software elements have been demonstrated experimentally. Jindalee, as an operational system, will enter service in the mid-1990s. Australian companies have been involved throughout this process, and will be involved more and more as the operational phase progresses, with up to three radar systems being envisaged.

I cannot stress too strongly that my aims for industry development, as Minister for Defence, complement those of my colleague Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Defence has also made a significant contribution to the Government's commitment to help Australian firms to tap export markets. The defence offsets program has been progressively refined and broadened over the years, and it has done much to encourage long term arrangements between overseas and Australian suppliers. The offsets program is now starting to run down because of the success of our overall efforts to encourage local industry involvement. Australian content in the submarine contract was 65 per cent. With the Anzac ships the Australian and New Zealand content should reach 70 per cent and, in fact, with offsets work added, could reach 80 per cent.

We have reached the point where Australian firms are able and more than ready to take on the role of prime contractor for major defence programs. Obviously this means a progressively lower foreign content in such programs and a commensurate decline in new offsets obligations. Nevertheless, the program continues to provide valuable assistance for Australian companies. Last financial year new offsets obligations were a relatively modest $25m. But past obligations discharged in that same period for offsets and Australian industry participation programs totalled more than $120m.

Three weeks ago, Defence signed deeds of agreement with four big overseas suppliers of high technology defence equipment for the accumulation of defence offsets credit. These deeds of agreement will allow the companies to undertake long term programs with local companies to help the Australian partners meet our own future needs and aim at export markets. The companies concerned already have begun negotiations that could lead to Australian industry involvement in joint development, production and export sales. The Government has also fostered the development of a number of specialised technologies to meet particular Australian requirements. Last year we spent $12m to develop generic technologies and a further $27m to facilitate Australian industry involvement in our capital equipment projects. In June 1987 I announced an extensive revision and streamlining of the regulations governing exports of defence-type goods. This is a fairly specialised export area but it has the capacity to foster and maintain specialist skills and reduce the cost of such goods on the Australian market. Last year we received 400 applications for the export of defence goods, of which only 2 per cent were declined.

Australia is critically dependent on access to advanced Western military technology if it is to realise its goal of self-reliant defence, and we are just as critically dependent on access to advanced Western commercial technology if the Government's objectives of more internationally competitive, outward-looking Australian industry are to be achieved. Australia therefore adheres to guidelines developed by the main North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries and Japan for the export of advanced commercial technology with dual civil and military applications. Full observance of these guidelines is vital in maintaining this access. Last month we joined the Co-ordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, COCOM, which administers these arrangements. I am confident that this will both facilitate advanced technology transfer into Australia and help increase exports from Australia.

Under the Hawke Government, defence self-reliance is no longer a mirage but a realisable goal. Our policy of self-reliance has two central pillars. The first pillar is a clear definition of our primary strategic environment, which in turn dictates a force structure matching our unique geographic circumstances. The second pillar is a competitive, technologically proficient and adaptable industry base, able to supply and support the changing requirements of our Defence Force. The Government believes its redirection of our defence industry in recent years has already produced significant long term benefits for Australia. I am confident that Australian industry increasingly sees our defence policies in the same light. I present the following paper:
Defence Industry-Ministerial Statement, 10 May 1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition welcomes the statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). It makes a difference to be able to support a defence statement with which we fundamentally agree. I must say at the outset that the Minister was speaking on his favourite subject. If he devoted some of the time and energy that he puts into equipment and industry to operations and personnel matters he would not have the problems he has on his hands at the moment. Australian Defence Industries (ADI), as I understand it, came into operational effect on 3 May. We wish it well. It is very much a step in the right direction. My colleague the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) no doubt in his service career visited Williamstown in days gone by. Anyone who went there before it was handed over to Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd. could have only been appalled at the state of that government facility and the low productivity that emanated from it, although `emanated' is hardly the word.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems that occurs in government-owned companies relates to capital. I know that the Minister is as well aware as I am that Aerospace Technologies of Australia-and presumably the ADI-has and is going to have this problem of capital. Whereas companies go to their shareholders to raise capital if they want it these companies have to come to the Government. This Government, understandably, as any government would be, is reluctant to keep shelling it out when these companies have been set up for the purpose of looking after their own affairs and making a profit. Nevertheless, they do have a problem when they have old facilities. Some of it is good and some is bad at ASTA. I do not have an instant solution as to how to get it into shape to attract the private sector. I see the Minister nodding his head, indicating that he is aware of the problem. I very much hope that we do not take a purist view of these government companies which are making progress towards achieving profits and getting into shape so that at least part of them can be sold off or privatised and that we are able to give them the reasonable assistance they require and at least access to some sort of capital.

As the Minister for Defence said in his statement, we have come a long way since 1984. I do not defend anything that happened before that-quite the reverse. In 1984, the Department of Defence Support employed some 15,000 people and productivity was low. ADI will now employ some 6,800 people and I am sure that in some areas productivity will be greatly improved. I understand from the Minister that that figure of 6,800 people will be further reduced.

The Minister, in the course of his statement, mentioned two pillars of his defence policy. The first related to a clear definition of `primary strategic environment'. I presume he is talking about the strategic environment as described in the White Paper. It is very interesting that, some two years after the White Paper was tabled, people lower down in the defence structure keep talking about the purity, structure and integrity of the White Paper-although, as the Minister himself has clearly recognised, it has been overtaken by events and seems to have moved on. There is no doubt that in the past two years the White Paper has been seen to be a flawed document. It is basically defensive and isolationist. In considering what has happened in our region in the past two years, it is apparent that there is a need for an outgoing policy of regional involvement. Not only have we seen the events in Fiji, in Vanuatu, and in New Caledonia last week-and particularly in New Guinea-but also we are faced with a declining capability in New Zealand and a declining American defence presence in this part of the world.

All these things point to a policy of increased regional involvement; yet, we stick to the White Paper, which according to some people is always on track. It does not matter how many Budget cuts there are-projected on to a 3 per cent real increase-in every economic statement and in every Budget that is brought down, what happens to defence? A bit more is sliced off the top. The Government's response is, `Don't worry, everything is still on track'. This is another reason why the integrity of the White Paper has been reduced to an absolute shambles. We do not live in a benign region any more. Our defence policy should be based on a strong deterrent approach and maximum regional involvement, including an off-shore deployment capability and experienced personnel.

In the case of a strong deterrent, as has been indicated before, the Opposition applauds the development of the 471 submarines. That is one arm in our effective deterrent strategy. The other arm, the more visible one, involves the F111 aircraft. The F111 aircraft are currently under threat-or at least one squadron is. There is still no aerial refuelling for the F111 and no proposal for this in the program. There are no airborne command and control aircraft or airborne radar aircraft. So, in terms of effective and visible deterrence, that capacity is going down.

In terms of regional involvement, despite the lessons of Fiji two years ago, we still have no real offshore deployment capability. We still have no ship that can carry Blackhawk helicopters. But the Minister does not worry too much about that. If another Fiji-type situation arises, the Minister's solution is to use paratroopers. I saw a statement made by the Minister-and presumably he was quoted correctly-that if that sort of thing happens again we are going to use paratroopers. We will not worry about some seaborne offshore quiet deployment capability; we are going to drop in paratroopers. Imagine what would have happened to the first Australian paratrooper dropped into Fiji-or for that matter a paratrooper likely to be dropped into any other area? It is absolute nonsense to be talking about a credible regional presence if we do not have any capacity to deploy troops, equipment or stores.

As to the third leg of this White Paper, the whole of Australia now knows the condition of the experience levels and the capabilities in our units, arising from the enormous wastage of personnel. In the past six years, 50,000 people have left the service. This is over a trained base-excluding trainees-of 62,000 people. In another couple of years, in numerical terms, we will have turned over the whole of the Australian Defence Force within about seven or eight years.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what it does on average-it always has. The 10-year average is 12 per cent per year.

—The Minister says it is still on track. However, there has been the greatest wastage of personnel in Australia's history. The Minister has presided over the debilitation of the Australian Defence Force and yet he says it is all on track. It would assist a sensible defence debate in this country if the Minister said occasionally that there are problems, instead of denying it, because every time the Minister or the Chief of the Air Staff gets up and says, `Its all on track, don't worry, no loss of capabilities', all the people out there whom they are supposed to be commanding and the people whom they are hoping to retain say, `There they go again, what is the point of staying around here if they deny the very existence of a problem'.
—Let's call on New Zealand.

—Get the Skyhawks over? Maybe we can get some New Zealand naval assets, and maybe some soldiers. What are those people who used to be in the Australian Fleet Air Arm now thinking as they see those Skyhawks coming back, with them being virtually given away in 1984? I suppose they are grateful that they left the service to seek other avenues of employment. The Minister in his speech talks about the force structure. The force structure simply does not exist any more, as a further squeeze is put on the service. They have not been told what they are expected to do; they have simply been told that they have to lop off some more men. A bit has been taken from here and from there.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have now finished up with, of course, is a division that cannot deploy, an Air Force that is barely operational in some of its units, and a Navy that is seriously undermanned. The amphibious squadron is still being disbanded, despite the great requirement for an offshore deployment facility. The Navy has also had to close many of its facilities so that it can man the ships that it has. The Government's manning plan in relation to these new frigates and the Anzac ships is a mystery to me and a mystery to the Navy as well.

As to the balance of priorities in our defence spending-and this is pertinent to the Minister's statement, because it concentrates on industry and equipment-it is now out of kilter. As important as some of this equipment is, the Government does not seem to be able to understand the vital relationship between equipment, operations and personnel. In its enthusiasm to put so much support into equipment, operations and personnel have been allowed to run down-and this is as a matter of deliberate policy. Until the Government recognises this position, even with the best equipment in the world, with young and inexperienced and not properly motivated people, it really has nothing at all.

The Minister in his statement talked about reshaping the Australian Defence Force. Well, the Government has certainly done that. I want to provide two or three quotes from some recent service reports. First, I refer to a Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) report of January 1989, signed by Air Commodore Tuckwell and several other officers. It is entitled `Study Team Report on RAAF Officer Manning Deficiencies', and states:

It is unarguable that the current aircrew to aircraft ratio is so low that the RAAF would be incapable of fully utilizing its assets in any situation except for the most benign contingency, and then only if this was transitory in nature. Consequently, the lack of aircrew is a pervasive and major factor which affects the real (as distinct from perceived) operational capability of the RAAF today.
It is some restructuring that the Minister is so proud of! The Air Force is crying from the heart in that report that its units are simply not operational. The Air Force states:
We can only cope with a benign contingency.

Let me read an extract from the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which inquired into the personnel wastage rates in the Australian Defence Force. The Royal Australian Navy in a submission dated April 1988 states:

Greater emphasis on unit training is required to compensate for this low level of operator and maintainer experience . . . Generally, ships have achieved most annual continuation training targets, but have maintained a less than optimum level of proficiency in some areas. There is evidence, accumulated over the last few years, of declining standards in weapon practices. Further, this evidence also indicates that the trend is accelerating.
That is how the Government has restructured the Navy. Let me turn to the Army. An article in the Army newspaper by the Chief of General Staff, Lieutenant-General Laurie O'Donnell, stated:
Wastage is affecting the Army's operational capability, because we do not have sufficient trained personnel to fill an already finely-honed manpower establishment.

That is how the Government has restructured the Army. I do not know how the Minister can come into this chamber and talk proudly about the reshaping of the Defence Force when we look at how it has been reshaped. What does the Minister say about this time and again? On 23 November he said:
There has been no loss in Defence Force capabilities.

Yet every report we pick up from the Services to their own chiefs tells how badly off they are. The Minister talked in his statement about the number of ODP personnel in Russell Offices. He said that there were 1,000 in 1984. That was an absolute disgrace. I congratulate the Government and the Minister in getting that number down to something like 30. Many are not necessary now that we have a government company. But the growth of public servants in Russell-although there has been an overall decline-is still a serious problem. Figures taken from the last defence report indicate that there are 1,200 civilians in the Russell complex of the equivalent rank of lieutenant-colonel and above. It is very interesting that recently Major-General John Sanderson was commissioned and directed to undertake a structural review of higher ADF staff arrangements-that is, the number of lieutenant-colonels and above in the military. The terms of reference include the words `reduce the number of senior officers'. I suppose the salary compression could be looked at once the number of senior officers was reduced. Quite rightly, a review is being conducted in respect of the military structure. But, is a compensatory review being carried out of these 1,200 Public Service senior positions?

TALK.START.PARA: —The costs have been reduced.

—But there is no study. It is all very well to get stuck into the military, to get Major-General Sanderson to put the axe through them, but at the same time the Public Service is being left virtually untouched. Unless there is a compensatory reduction on both sides, even more power will be in the hands of the Public Service. This is part of the problem that the Department of Defence has at present.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister mentioned the Williamstown Dockyard. There is absolutely no doubt that the Williamstown Dockyard's success in the last few years has been remarkable. One would get the impression from reading the Minister's statement that this success had everything to do with the Government. The fact is that it had nothing to do with the Government. It was not until it was sold that it started to make progress. The private sector was responsible. This success is due to the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation (AMEC) in cooperation with and help of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). Dr John White, the general manager of Williamstown, and his team deserve congratulations for this achievement. They have reduced the number of unions on the dockyard from 23 to three. They have four skill levels and there are no demarcation disputes or problems with them. People move freely in a multiskilled environment. Training in higher skills is undertaken on company time and at company expense. There is every incentive for men and women with ability to move up through those skill levels.

There is some dispute about the numbers which, according to one of the Government's reports when the sale was effected, was about 1,200. Yet, the Government claims today that the number is 2,200. That is a small point; the numbers need some clarification. The number is now about 750 and productivity would appear to be up about four times. The company is very proud of its progress at Williamstown. It is an enormous success story from a productivity and an industrial relations point of view. This was demonstrated last week by the launch of the frigate 05, three months early. No doubt, with the contract for the Anzac frigate project coming up shortly, the company wants to demonstrate what it can do-and that is to its great credit; it shows that it can do the job. If the Government is so clever with industrial relations as it claims, why does it not get stuck into the Garden Island Dockyard and do the same thing there? Having said that, it is pleasing to see that Garden Island has also made great strides in recent years. We should give a lot of the credit for this to Admiral Berlyn and his team.

Aerospace Technologies of Australia (ASTA) was mentioned in the statement. This Government company was established in October 1987 to take over from the old Government Aircraft Factories. I visited ASTA last week and although it is making progress-I wish it well-it still appears to have some union problems. Again, one would hold up the Williamstown example as something for companies, such as ASTA, to follow. ASTA also has a problem in terms of lack of capital. I am pleased to see that the private sector is being invited to become involved in ASTA. That is a major step forward. It is a matter of whether those sectors can be made profitable enough to induce the private sector to come in. This also points up the importance of massaging these companies into shape so that they are attractive. It is not just a question of selling them off; they have to be formed into profitable enterprises before they can be offered to the private sector.

On the question of industrial relations, of which the Minister in his statement seems so proud, we on this side of the House believe that the accord with the ACTU has made our industrial relations system inflexible and has contributed to Australia's problems which have been brought about by a centralised wage system, low productivity and the dominance of the ACTU in any industrial matters as far as the Government is concerned. Once again, if we compare the productivity of the Garden Island Dockyard with that of the Williamstown Dockyard, Garden Island comes a bad second.

On the subject of industrial relations, we still have had no explanation of why 540 people were sacked in August 1987 when the Government Aircraft Factories was overtaken. Up to 150 employees sat around for some six months. Although they were paid for doing nothing, servicemen are leaving the services in ever-increasing numbers because of appalling conditions.

I will make some final points on the matter of defence exports. We now have a prospect of selling some of our defence production overseas. It should have happened years ago. The person who stopped it for all those years is the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bill Hayden. He simply would not allow those exports to proceed. A recent tour by an Australian export study team will say that there are some prospects. It will be a long haul because we are not competitive on world terms. Nevertheless, a start has been made. I once again ask the Minister to address this question of capital because that study team going overseas came up against defence exports from other countries, including Britain and America, that would offer the prospective buyer some capital deal-a cheap loan, a grant or a deferred payment. We simply do not do that. Until such time as we do, we will have great problems in expanding our defence export markets.

A couple of points must be made about the accountability of Government companies. The Auditor-General is responsible for the audit of Australian Aerospace Technologies. I presume the same situation applies throughout the Australian defence industry. The problem is that when the Auditor- General has carried out his audit, he hands the results back to the company. The company then produces an annual report and that report goes to the Government. But these Government companies are not accountable to this Parliament. The Opposition is currently addressing this matter. It seems to us that it is entirely unsatisfactory for a company to be set up with taxpayers' money, to be controlled by the Government and yet not be accountable to this Parliament.

In conclusion, I repeat that the Government has made progress. We support that progress and the restructuring of defence support facilities. It is good to see. The Australian Defence Association is another step forward, although we have a long way to go. We, on this side of the House, are pleased to be able to endorse the thrust of the statement made this afternoon. But we would be more impressed if the Minister had paid some fraction of attention to the problems of operations, conditions of service and personnel progress that he has given to defence industry because, if he had, he would not have the problems that he has on his hands today.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The uncertainty and financial hardship caused to organisations serving people with disabilities by the failure of the Government to properly implement the Disability Services Act.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that we have been able to get the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) into the chamber for the discussion of this matter of public importance. Unfortunately, the only way we can speak to him is by proposing for discussion a matter of public importance. On behalf of many of the providers around Australia, I take the opportunity during this debate to tell him that his lack of contact with, his lack of coordination with and his lack of understanding of the industry are being widely felt outside.
—He is out of touch.

—He is completely out of touch. Quite honestly, great financial hardship is being experienced by many of those people who have been the traditional service providers of disability services throughout Australia. There is certainly confusion in this area and uncertainty felt by the service providers, their clients and particularly the families of the disabled. The most recent example of this is the formation of the Bundaberg Group-a group of parents of intellectually disabled children under the auspices of Mrs Mary Walsh. These people have become a rather large force within Queensland, thus indicating a concern of parents.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a fear of the future. Parents who have disabled children fear that they are unable to plan precisely what is ahead of them and particularly for their children. This is particularly so when one reads bulletins such as Our Voice published by Disabled People's International (Australia) Ltd in which the Minister, under the heading of `No more Cradle to the Grave', says:

. . . Programs and services are to be developed and administered so as to ensure that no single organisation providing services shall exercise control over all or most aspects of the life of a person with a disability.

This concerns parents who, with limitations to their own lives, have to make provision for their children. That bulletin was headed `Blewett Issues Ultimatum'. Where is the concern of the Minister when headlines such as that are generated? There has been a long-running argument in the industry. The Bulletin of 13 December, speaking of Mrs Edith Hall and under the heading `Bashing one's head against a brick wall', states:
Hall is the front line of an `intense and bitter struggle' between the Department of Community Services and Health and ACROD. The battle is over the new Disability Services Act . . .

It is relevant to note that the problem is continuing because from a letter dated 11 April 1989 it is obvious there is an absolute breakdown in understanding of what the Minister is doing. At the conference held last year by the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled (ACROD), the Minister said:

Let me be clearly understood on this point, once and for all: there is no intention on the part of the government, or my department, to close down or defund existing sheltered workshops and activity therapy centres in 1992.

That is precisely the problem set out in the letter dated 11 April, which was addressed to constituents of ACROD. The Minister is now going back on his word. A real battle between the service providers, their clients and the Minister is going on out there. This battle is about retaining existing services against the philosophical commitment of this Minister to change.

Let us look at the changes away from those old services. I think that many honourable members in this chamber, particularly in the Opposition, would be acquainted, in some way or another, with providers of these services. They have given a very long term of service and a very good service to their clients. They have been prepared to change with the times. They have been prepared to accept innovations from overseas. At this stage the volunteers and the charitable organisations are providing the best service in a non-profit capacity.

It does not come as a surprise to hear a person who is a leader in the field of rehabilitation and disability services saying that he is dismayed at the way in which the Department of Community Services and Health seems to be dismantling all the services which, 20 to 30 years ago, were hailed as revolutionary advances-such as the activity therapy centres, the help of volunteer bodies and now the sheltered workshops. It is quite incredible that the departmental officers, backed of course by their Minister, are behaving in such a fashion. They are such impractical people. It looks as though before long we will be back in the era of the 1920s and the 1930s. Instead of moving into the future, we are moving back to the past. Australia is a world leader in rehabilitation services and assistance of the disabled. What is intended, as suggested in the form of that letter, is to turn all of that backwards and to try the high-risk, high-cost innovation methods being introduced from America, when in fact we lead the world in this regard.

There is also financial hardship. I wish to mention a few things in this regard. I understand that pilot projects have been implemented throughout Australia, where the Government has taken the full responsibility of the services being offered in the area of disabilities. These projects have had unlimited access to finance. I understand that the results were so horrific that the Department and the Minister are not prepared to disclose the cost per client on an annual basis. Studies have been done within organisations which suggest that their cost per client under the present method, which involves a lot of volunteer, charitable and public support, is about $14,472 per year, and that their cost per client for accommodating these people and putting them out into the community on a four to a cottage basis escalates to $63,000. The amount has been quadrupled.

The Department and the Minister are quite prepared to change, and to insist on change, but at no stage have they suggested where the cost of these changes will come from. As I said before, it is a high cost operation, but more importantly it involves a high risk, because the American experiment has not shown the results, whereas the Australian experience indicates that Australia is well on the track in this regard and providing the services to the best of its ability. I am not saying that there should not be change. However, when we suggest change, we have to make sure that the change is going to be beneficial.

I wish to make some other comments in connection with the implementation of the Disability Services Act and the concern it is causing the industry and the providers. I wish to mention specifically the Spastics Centre in Brisbane. It is backed by a charitable qualification. As far as the raising of donations is concerned, it is accepted as such for income tax purposes by the Australian Taxation Office and by the Government.
