The Spastics Centre provides an assessment centre, accommodation, education, family respite and transport. Under the new guidelines, this organisation will not be eligible for funding in future, irrespective of the fact that Government members have been on site to say that it is doing a great job. The Spastics Centre has been told that when new projects come up in this regard, it will no longer be available to receive the funds it requires because it is too big a provider, too big an institution. It has been told it has to use up all of its reserves. I believe that it is operating on reserves which amount to about nine months' clear funding if it does not get anything from the Commonwealth. It has been asked to use up these reserves before it comes back to the Commonwealth for funding. In other words, it has to use charity, whereas once it was funded at Commonwealth expense.

There is no transport assistance available under the new guidelines, which state that this is supposed to be a State matter. If one separates services into different centres where transport will be absolutely essential to get people from accommodation to workplaces, that is expected to be at the cost of the provider or the State. Yet, there have been no State arrangements in this regard. The Spastics Centre in Queensland is an example of a non-profit organisation, a charitable organisation. There is a tremendous amount of volunteer effort, a tremendous amount of professionalism, being displayed in the delivery of these services. Yet this organisation is being held to ransom in this regard. It is being told that big is no longer beautiful. If the answer is that small is beautiful, it will be an expensive exercise. The Minister has to assure these people that, if change is absolutely imperative, the finance will be there to back them up.

I cite another example, Bedford Industries, from the Minister's own State. I believe that the Minister has been on site in that establishment and has said that it provides wonderful work. It certainly does. It is providing everything from work placement to training, getting people with skills out into the field. Yet, according to the guidelines under which the Minister is now operating-guidelines he is implementing-Bedford Industries is concerned that it no longer fits the bill as far as further finance is concerned. It provides accommodation and all the related services and it provides skills in 21 different directions, yet it may not be entitled to funding under the new arrangements. I could also talk about Westfield in Dubbo, New South Wales. I could talk about the Australian Quadriplegic Association operating out of Sydney. I could also talk in terms of the Endeavour Foundation and the Challenge Foundation and what they are doing in their sheltered workshops. Yet, all these organisations are under threat of de-funding.

It has been said to me that the Act itself is appropriate; that it is only in the delivery of these services that the Government and the Department have failed. If the guidelines are so bad, and their implementation is so bad, there must be something wrong with the Act itself. I want to mention two areas that concern the industry. Under the guidelines, in chapter 5, which are at the discretion of the Minister, contracts are being entered into where these guidelines can be inserted after the contract. In another area, I think chapter 8, certain services are mentioned which are not being delivered at present. The Minister might look at that.

The guidelines do not make any provision for the differences in the various handicaps and in the degree of handicap. For instance, Multicap in Queensland provides services to intellectually handicapped with an IQ of less than 35 per cent. Endeavour supplies those services for people with an IQ of 35 per cent. Yet, the Act and the particular basis on which these guidelines are being implemented do not take that into consideration. To give an example of that, let me refer the House to a question and answer in Question Time, where the Minister said that in spite of the degree of handicap, intellectual or otherwise, the basis for assistance must be a fair day's work for a fair day's pay. Obviously, the Minister was referring to sheltered workshops and to a comment made in the press in that regard about sweated labour. That is not the manner in which the Department should attack the problem. Nor does the Department show any consideration or understanding of the fact that there can be quite a vast difference in disabilities which cannot be provided for under the one set of guidelines. I think this is fairly obvious from that one example. There are large differences in the degrees of handicap, a fact which the Minister does not acknowledge. There has been talk about flexibility. I had felt that there might be a greater degree of flexibility in the appointment within the Public Service of Mr Ian Fletcher. I have on hand the April-May 1989 statement of the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled, in which the question is asked:
What happened to flexibility under the DSA?
The comment is:
What happened to the flexibility Don Grimes promised us so often? What happened to the emphasis on consumer outcomes rather than processes? What happened to the economic factor?

Here we have the major organisation, the peak organisation, completely at sea in the delivery of these services. On the other hand, we see the use of advocacy teams at great expense; the use of consultants in order to push the governmental guidelines. ACROD is unhappy. There is a compliant that there is a move in personnel and a moving target cannot be hit. Endeavour, for instance, has had 63 contacts with the Department over two years. Finally, Dr Madden was promoted to another position, so the proceedings have gone back to square 1. I would like to draw the attention of the House to the manner in which the Government is trying to discredit organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like first of all to comment on the exquisite timing of this matter of public importance. I have looked through the Notice Paper and I can find only one question on disability services. This is so urgent a matter that looking back over all those questions on notice I can only find one question on this matter. Secondly, I have gone through an entire two years of questions to me. The honourable member for Dawson( Mr Braithwaite), who now brings this issue up as a matter of urgency, has not asked of me in two years a single question about disabilities. So we must ask ourselves why this matter is on the agenda today. I suggest that it has more to do with the blood-bath about to take place on the front bench of the Opposition than it has with concern for the disabled. It clearly shows the cynical nature of this operation and the reaction of honourable members opposite. If over the past couple of years honourable members opposite had asked these questions and shown this concern, one might take this matter seriously. I suggest, as I suggested a moment ago, that the noise being made by honourable members opposite has something to do with whether or not the honourable member will survive the bloodbath next week.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make a second point about this matter. On the very day that this cynical matter is brought on for debate and we are accused of not having proper communications with disability groups around the country, my Department and the heads of all the newly established disability advisory councils in each State are meeting here in Canberra in a constructive way to look at the problems associated with the Disability Services Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about ACROD?

—I will come to the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled in a moment, but not in the negative and mischievous way that this has been brought up. One of the points that was raised, and it is raised in the matter of public importance itself, has something to do with financial hardship. I will discuss the point raised about financial hardship. There is a cold hard fact that the Opposition needs to take into account here. In the last year of the coalition Government, in 1982-83, $72m was spent on disability services. This year the Government has spent $165m on disability services so, in fact, there has been more than a doubling of resources going into disability services in the six years of this Government. However, honourable members opposite have the hide to come in here and talk about financial hardship, even though they can look at the books and see that there has been an increase of over 100 per cent in six years. That has occurred because in many ways this Government has put effort, energy and resources into disability services in a way that no previous government has done.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me look, firstly, at other members of the Opposition. When the Disability Services Act was introduced into Parliament and it was referred to the Senate there was a bipartisan attitude and the kinds of cheap points that have been made today were not raised. There was support for the outcomes and processes of the Act. I will quote Senator Peter Baume. I hope he will emerge as a spokesman for the Opposition once the bloodbath is over. He said:

We regard community services as one part of public policy whose goal is to enable as many Australians as possible to live their lives with dignity free of interference and as independently as possible. To the extent that this legislation seeks to enhance and advance that goal we support it. When we are in government and responding to need we would like to determine priorities, set goals and pursue outcomes. To the extent that this legislation seeks to do those things, we support it. Our goals include the restructuring of Government funding so that we can promote services that look towards producing certain outcomes as they affect the dignity, the financial, physical and emotional dependence of people and a new community integration of people with disabilities. To the extent that this legislation seeks to do that, we support it.

Of course, that is what the Disability Services Act sought to produce. In the defence of all the conservative organisations mentioned by the honourable member, he does not appear to have read the reports and surveys published under both his Government and this Government which show quite clearly the major need for restructuring and change. It is no good saying that our services in Australia have led the world. There is no doubt that in the 1970s and early 1980s reports made conclusions like this:
The review found that the services for people with disabilities were inflexible, poorly funded, inadequate and demeaning.

It is no good accepting the arguments of a few organisations around the country that things in the 1970s and the 1980s led the world when in fact report after report to the then coalition Government and later to this Government suggested that Australia needed fundamentally to rethink the way it treated people with disabilities. In fact, the review report New Directions, which was tabled in Parliament in May 1985, concluded that such were the major massive and sweeping changes necessary to the types of disability services delivered in this country that what we wanted was an entirely new Act. The old Handicapped Persons Assistance Act was no longer sufficient; we wanted new disability services legislation. So this Government went about introducing new disability services legislation. That legislation is unique and, let me say, it is in front of the world. It provides a detailed statement of principles and objectives to be furthered in the administration and implementation of the Act. It encourages the direction of financial assistance to those who would undertake new operations, take some risks and exercise some imagination.

A whole new range of specific services were funded, and this is one the reasons why we have doubled the funding for disability services in our six years in government. These services include new forms of accommodation support. The honourable member talked about big no longer being beautiful. Big is no longer beautiful in terms of disability services. In fact, it is widely agreed amongst those who think about the problems of disabilities that it is a disadvantage to cluster all our disabled people in central complexes. We need to break them down, and I accept that in breaking them down we need to look at some of the issues. One of the more constructive suggestions made by the honourable member related to the question of transport. The general point in relation to people with disabilities is that it is not desirable-and it is no longer regarded in most parts of the world as desirable-to have disabled people in very big centralised institutions. The way to go is to integrate them in smaller establishments and smaller homes and integrate them into the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must recognise that that costs a lot more, too.

—That is one of the reasons why we have had this pretty massive increase, a commitment to a real increase of 5.5 per cent over the next two years. We have made that commitment because we recognise that some of the things we are doing will cost this extra money. I refer to supported employment and the respite care provision. Supported employment is the notion of getting people out into the work force, even if in many cases it demands a back-up person. I have the figures for sheltered employment allowances and their earnings. Those figures certainly do not reflect too well on the State from which the honourable member comes, if he is really interested in disability services. In New South Wales, the average amount earned is $23 a week, in Victoria it is $27 a week, in Queensland it is $14 a week, in South Australia it is $25 a week, in Western Australia it is $38 a week and in Tasmania it is $23 a week. We want people to have more opportunities actually to be out in the work force. We recognise that in many cases disabled people will not be able to go out into the work force and earn wages like others if they do not have back-up and support. Therefore, we have the whole notion of supportive employment. When one looks at the figures for sheltered workshops, and particularly the situation in Queensland, one can see that there is a need to encourage imagination-and I will come to some of the things that have been done in this area-to get people into supportive employment situations and also competitive employment through training and placement.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of independent living training, one of the things that emerged from all these reviews was the desire of so many disabled people to live in their own homes, provided they could be taught the skills and have the back-up services. So independent living training becomes a new emphasis of the Act-as well as advocacy recreation and information. I accept that when one commits to change like this there will be opposition. Some of the points made by the honourable member come from our critics who run organisations which they believe have done a very good job-and in many ways they have done a good job. However, they are somewhat resistant to change. When people face change they always have problems accommodating to it. We have tried, and will continue to try, to be as flexible as possible in carrying through this legislation and to be responsible to needs. For instance, we have a working party which has been looking at activity therapy centres. It is a Government working party which includes members of ACROD, so there is representation from the disability organisation itself. Its report, which is about to come down, addresses again some of the issues and concerns of people.

The Opposition talks about me not consulting or my Department not consulting. But rarely in the history of this country and never before in the disabilities area has there been so much consultation. The whole thrust of what we are trying to do is to enable people with disabilities to achieve their maximum potential. That often means exercising some imagination, which I know comes hard to the conservative parties. It often means taking some risks. They are the sorts of things that the Act is concerned with doing. We aim to assist people with disabilities to participate as fully as possible in society, and that means being very genuinely concerned about employment opportunities, about really trying to get people employment opportunities out in society. That becomes another major thrust of what we are trying to do.

As Senator Peter Baume said-and this is again a major point of the Act-we are concerned very much with the outcomes for clients, judging success very much from their point of view. Finally, we are encouraging innovation and imagination in the provision of these services. Of course, those organisations which have been prepared to exercise that imagination and innovation have certainly prospered under the new Disability Services Act. For instance, I had Bedford Industries thrown up at me. I notice that I was accused of not being accessible on these matters, but the honourable member himself acknowledged that I had been to many of the organisations and conferences that he mentioned. If the honourable member reads the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs of 18 and 19 April this year, he will find that the chief executive officer of Bedford Industries in South Australia was very positive in his approach-it is there on the public record-towards the Disability Services Act. That does not mean that we have not been taking up a whole lot of issues with a big organisation like Bedford Industries. But, certainly, his response to that Committee was extremely positive towards the Act.

What we have tried to do is be flexible and consult, recognising-we do not deny it-that whenever one is faced with change there will be some opposition and people will be doubtful about taking new or imaginative steps. Let me just talk about some of these consultations. We have revamped the whole of the advisory bodies in the States. A State advisory body on disability services has been established in nearly every State. We have been working on that to get proper representation. Their chairmen are meeting here today, as I have mentioned already. There is a whole range of regional consultations and conferences sponsored through the Department. I do not deny that we have had disagreements with ACROD, but we have had a good and continuous contact with ACROD right through these processes.

Let me finally take-I think the sorts of things on the ground are most important-a few of the examples of the kinds of transition programs that are around which really, in a way, prove the successes of the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'll run out of time.

—Let me take a couple of them straight off the cuff. We have an advocacy service in Sydney, which I went to the other day, in which a whole series of advice for the disabled is given by the disabled themselves. They have worked out advice on employment and have published a book called Rights in Residence. Project Employment in Perth, again funded under our new transition arrangements, has proved that people can be placed in competitive jobs.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that that was probably the most shameful and disgraceful display from a Minister in a caring portfolio that I have seen. Is the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) saying that it was not urgent? The Minister should really get out on the ground and have a look at some of the people who are facing these problems. They will tell him whether it is urgent or not. He asked why we did not actually ask any questions. I will tell him why we do not ask questions. The last question I asked the Minister was on 22 November 1988. I got the answer on 28 April 1989. That is how long it takes to get an answer. Why does he think we do not ask any questions?

SPEECH.PARA: What about the other point? The Minister said that it was difficult to take this matter seriously. I think I am almost quoting him. He asked, `How can you take this matter seriously?' I will tell him how he can take it seriously. He should go and talk to the disabled people, their families and to the societies who look after them. One has to take it seriously if one has an ounce of decency in one's body.

The Minister talked about the financial hardships and about an increase in resources under this Government over the last seven years. There has been an increase. If one asks any of the resource groups who are looking after disabled people, they will say categorically that the financial allocations that this Government has made are inadequate because they are being told to spend money on programs and not being given the money to start those programs. The Government is asking them to move people out of hostels into individual community houses, into cottage accommodation, which costs money. The Government is not giving them the money to do it. It is as simple as that. That is why the problems of financial hardship are arising.

The Minister missed the whole point. The whole problem that we and the community have is not with the Disability Services Act. We believe that the Act itself is admirable, and the Minister quoted Senator Peter Baume's comments on this. The Act has admirable intentions: it tries to encourage the independence of the disabled; it gives them economic opportunity; and it provides for community integration. We all believe in these things. Our problem is with the Government's and the Department of Community Services and Health's implementation of the Act. The Government has caused fear and trepidation amongst service providers-organisations such as the Challenge Foundation, which is not known for its radicalism-amongst the families of the disabled and, most importantly of all, amongst both the mentally and physically disabled themselves. What has happened to those groups is a disgrace. The disability service provider groups in particular are distressed for a number of reasons, partly because of the misinformation that has come out from the Minister's Department. I do not know whether that is deliberate, but it is amazing to see different information being spread around the community. This action has to be considered to be deliberate. These groups face uncertainty and delays. Changes are made to the funding formula. For example, there is no flexibility for block grant changes. That is crucial in the society in which we live.

What about the disappearance of the promised equipment and the maintenance funds? All of the major groups in every State of Australia that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), other members of the back bench committee and I have visited and talked to, have the same problem. They say, `What about the disappearance of the promised equipment and the maintenance funds? We cannot survive financially any more'. The Minister has acknowledged that movement from hostels into community houses does cause major problems. We support the concept in general. But there are two factors that the Minister needs to recognise very clearly. First, and above all, it costs money and the Government is not providing that money. This is a very desirable option for a number of people, but it is expensive and the Government has to provide the wherewithal to make it viable.

The second point that the Minister has to realise is that it is not suitable for all people. Unfortunately, a decision seems to have been made somewhere in the Department that there is a blanket move for everybody who possibly can be moved in any State at all from the hostel situation into cottage housing. That is just not feasible. I went with the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Dawson, to the Challenge Foundation at Minnamurra and saw people who were apparently about to be moved. They actually had trouble moving themselves around the floor while they were undergoing their occupational therapy and stimulation. To expect these people to survive on their own is outrageous. That may be an extreme example, but there are whole hosts of other examples of people who should not be moved into the community. But the Minister is moving them into the community. They cannot just be moved into this new type of accommodation. The staff have to be provided and trained and the community around those cottages has to be educated to accept them. The Government is not doing that.

The Challenge Foundation is concerned that the implementation will be done by bureaucrats living in an ivory tower in Canberra who have no practical experience, no hands-on grass roots experience, at helping the disabled organise their day to day living. They would be relying on textbook information of the system mentioned previously from the United States of America rather than actual knowledge. If the Government is going to go down this track, it has got to provide the funds to do it. The Challenge Foundation, one of the most respected groups in this area, believes that the benefits of hostel-type accommodation have been sold short. If hostel-type accommodation is properly designed and staffed, the quality of life can be as good as cottage accommodation and at a much lower cost. In this situation, big may still be beautiful. So stop the blanket approach of getting everybody out of hospital into cottages. By all means do it for those where it is appropriate and provide the funds for it, but do not make this across the board attack. Have some sensitivity for the people that are being attacked. They are scared witless about what is happening to them.

The Minister mentioned the Disability Services Act's aim of getting people out of sheltered workshops and into the open labour market. It is an admirable intention, but in general terms it is unrealistic to do this across the board. The Minister mentioned a number of things. In other speeches he has mentioned this concept of a fair day's pay for a fair day's work, implying some sort of Dickensian workshop experience around Australia. The workshops we are talking about are not similar to that of Dickens with the beadle throwing scraps to Oliver Twist; these are workshops with modern equipment and modern staff and where modern overseeing is carried on day in, day out. If the Minister goes to those workshops-and I cannot imagine he has been to many if he really believes they are Dickensian-he will see that the people there have a role, which is very largely fulfilled by the workshop environment.

We have asked a number of people in the area what percentage of people in sheltered workshops would be able to cope on the open market. The answer is from 5 to 10 per cent. Let us look at those. Firstly, the majority of those do not wish to work on the open market. We may say that they will get much more money on the open market, but the reality is that when they are in the sheltered workshops they are the team leaders, the foreman, the big fish in a little pool. It boosts their self-esteem beyond anything that would happen in the open market. They develop social relationships and independence, whereas if they went out into industry, even those people who are the foreman in the sheltered workshops would become the toilet cleaners and the butt of jokes and they would be ostracised by their workmates. The integration of these people into the workplace can certainly be enhanced by education, but education of the community and the work force needs money, and the Government is not providing enough money to do that.

Programs such as job support work very well. They are very effective at moving these people and training them and educating their work colleagues to understand the problems they face. But the staffing required to educate those people through community programs such as job support is almost one to one. One staff member is needed pretty well full time to look after the first few months of somebody going into the work force in the open market, because the problems that person faces are enormous. The unions are not on side. They are scared that they might affect the employment conditions of the people they are supposed to represent.

That applies only to 5 per cent who might be able to move out into the open work force. What about the other 95 per cent? They will not be able to cope. With all the best will in the world and all the help in the world, they will not cope in the open environment, whereas in the workshops they do. In the workshops they interact with their peers. It is not just a work place; it is also a social occasion, if you like. The workers who attend the sheltered workshops go there as a way of having social interaction. One of the prices they pay for that, and most are happy to pay for it, is that they do not get paid as much as they would in the open market, but their lives are much fuller in terms of their overall lifestyle. They have a joy, if you like, in going to what is a community centre as well as a workshop.

It is a shame that we have to use the term `workshop' because it does have Dickensian overtones, which are entirely inappropriate for the current workshop environment. I have visited many of them. The people working in them have the joy of being productive. According to our scale, in many cases that may not be very productive, but it is productivity as they see it. They see themselves as being useful to the community, to their employer and to their workmates. What would happen if they were forced out into the open labour market? Clearly, they would fail. They would resign or they would be sacked and, if they were sacked, they would be stuck at home in isolation and that would cause more problems for their psychology. It would put more pressure on their families and more pressure on the whole community, which would have to provide other services to look after them.

Meanwhile this Government sits in splendid isolation laying down the law and then not following it. We are basically very happy with the Disability Services Act as it stands, apart from a few minor details. It is the implementation of that law by the Minister's Department which has caused all the problems. The Minister has to stop hiding from the consumers, the disabled and the societies looking after them, and their families, and make himself accessible. The regular complaint we get wherever we go is, `Why cannot we get in touch with this Minister? Why will the Minister not see us?'. I ask the Minister to stop hiding from the consumers and their representatives. I suggest that he come out and let them approach him, and let us together constructively fix these problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am becoming involved in this debate with some feelings of concern, particularly regarding the politicisation of an area affecting disabled people and their carers-that is, the staff, the number of people in the community who have been working together with government for some years to strive to put together programs which will bring up to optimum the way in which people who suffer disablement can effectively perform in the community. I say that it is really important that this debate should not be politicised because I have had experience with the reaction that can occur if one tries to represent concerns which are put forward by disabled people, by their carers and by their staff. When politicised, people misrepresent the genuine efforts of members of parliament and governments as merely looking for a headline.

SPEECH.PARA: The comments made by the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods) and some of the comments made by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite)-although I am sure that they do have real concerns-if acted upon would, I think, make the matter very much worse. Questions have been asked by people on the other side and out in the community as to why so many people are confused. The Opposition's contributions today have suggested that it is all the fault of the Government, the only government which is funding workshops and activity therapy centres (ATCs) in conjunction with the community-about 30 per cent funding from the Federal Government in the case of some major organisations, the community putting in the rest. I find this extremely unreasonable. One could say that the concern and the confusion in the minds of some parents, some disabled people, some carers and some providers, could be because of a breakdown in communication between parents and the board of management of the provider, and between the provider and government. But it is absolutely unintelligent and lacking in integrity to try to channel home criticism to the one body. This Government and the Department of Community Services and Health are striving to effect change in an area in which trauma can lead to fear. In the 1980s we are now looking at an altogether new scenario for disabled people. At the start of the century disabled people were just shut away and not assisted. People with disablements or with mental disturbances were shut away in hospitals or institutions or left at home and not assisted, mainly through a lack of knowledge. Parents underwent trauma and stress trying to care for disabled people. Disabled people wanted to become more operative, and there were no ways open to them.

The Disability Services Act prescribes two discrete employment outcomes for people with intellectual disabilities: supported employment and competitive employment. It was envisaged that people with mild or borderline intellectual disabilities and working in sheltered workshops would stream into competitive employment, while those with moderate or severe intellectual disabilities and working in activity therapy centres would move to supported employment. There was an attraction in the different options which were offered by this legislation. However, it was found that there were inherent flaws in the basis of the legislation. They were quickly recognised by the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health, leading to efforts to introduce a more flexible approach which was premised on individual needs and aspirations. Following that, a number of transitional plans have been undertaken to try to ensure that the facilities and services offered for disabled people are effective. So it is not at all true or fair to say that nothing is being done in this context.

It might be easiest for me to refer directly, in the very brief time I have, to the experience of people working in activity therapy centres and sheltered workshops within the electorate of Lilley. In March of this year I was contacted by parents and staff members at workshops and ATCs in the north Brisbane area who outlined specific concerns regarding an alleged lack of services for disabled clients. They did not wish to speak out against the Endeavour Foundation, which provides 45 per cent of the services for intellectually disabled people in Queensland-some because of a sense of loyalty; others, however, feared victimisation. Although this may not have been based on fact, they feared that if they spoke out their sons or daughters could be denied access to the workshops and centres.

I visited the workshop, spoke with staff members, liaised with the Endeavour Foundation and spoke to parents. Eventually, I calmly and factually stated some of these allegations in the grievance debate in this House on 6 April. However, following that speech, conditions reached the stage where, although those people were afraid to speak out about the alleged lack of facilities, staff members expressing concern at alleged poor conditions at ATCs went to the media. My concern is about misrepresentations which followed this publicity.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always the media's fault.

—No, this is not the media's fault; I am not saying that at all. I am not trying to put the fault anywhere. It is a matter of great concern. One staff member who had been with the Endeavour Foundation for over five years was dismissed for going against the guidelines and speaking to the media. Three other staff members-gentle, intelligent, caring women from the Northgate workshop in my electorate, one of whom had been at the Foundation for 18 years-resigned, allegedly in support of Kathy Cross, the Endeavour supervisor who was dismissed.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage I decided to take the matter to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and also to the Endeavour Foundation to see whether we could work out some way in which the Government could liaise directly with the Endeavour Foundation to review the specific and serious allegations which were made and which I have on record. There had been a number of serious allegations and I decided to see whether they could be addressed with a view to reaching just resolutions and the best outcome for disabled people, for their carers, for the staff members concerned and consequently for the Endeavour Foundation.

The Endeavour Foundation is not the only provider of these services in Queensland. Certainly there would be question marks over some services which, I believe, operate under very bad conditions. I have supported the Endeavour Foundation for many years. It is not true that that organisation does not have my support and that of this Government; it does. But it advantages no-one if serious allegations are not met and addressed. If the iceberg of unresolved allegations were allowed to surface slowly, the public animosity and misrepresentation that would surround such an ongoing situation would discredit all of the good services offered by the Endeavour Foundation. I am very pleased with the response I received from the Minister, who has approved in principle a coordinated review of the areas of concern identified by the Department of Community Services and Health and the Endeavour Foundation. This afternoon I will be liaising with Mr Tom Barry, the State Executive Director of the Endeavour Foundation in Queensland, to seek his cooperation in the interests of disabled people and their carers. I trust that those people who have incorrectly and publicly assumed that there is an organised attack of the Endeavour Foundation will realise that this is not so. I wish, and the Government wishes, to put the interests of disabled people first. Surely no-one would expect us to ignore the allegations and concerns expressed to us, rather than moving to assist those who have requested help. I hope we will now be able to work together towards a just outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the taxation laws in a number of respects and in addition will remove some 180 pages of redundant provisions of the income tax law. Three outdated tax-related Acts will also be removed from the statute book.

The Bill contains measures to apply after today to specifically tax gains and allow a deduction for losses on the disposal of traditional securities. As announced on 22 November 1988, the exemption from capital gains tax for a taxpayer's sole or principal residence is to be extended to make sure that it covers those residing in retirement villages and the like.

The Bill extends the exemption from income tax of maintenance payments received by a wife or former wife to maintenance payments received by a spouse, former spouse, de facto spouse, former de facto spouse or by or on behalf of a child. Other amendments in the Bill ensure that a minor who is in receipt of a child disability allowance or is a disabled child will not be subject to the special anti-avoidance measures that deal with the unearned income of unmarried minors. The level of beneficiary rebate for 1988-89 will be increased from $260 to $262.

Gifts to funds for the relief of persons affected by the earthquakes in Armenia and to the Australian Ireland Fund are to be allowable income tax deductions. The taxation secrecy provisions are to be amended to allow the Commissioner of Taxation to disclose tax information to specified law enforcement agencies in certain circumstances, and to the Australian Customs Service. Finally, the Bill makes some minor technical amendments to the tax laws. I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
Redundant Provisions

The Government is conscious of concerns expressed over the volume and complexity of tax legislation with which taxpayers, tax administrators and other users must cope. Much of this legislation has been directed at curbing the excesses of the tax avoidance era that we inherited in 1983, and at creating a fairer taxation system. As part of this overall process, the Government is committed to improving the tax laws and to responding to constructive criticism of these laws. In that vein, this Bill will slash some 180 pages of redundant provisions from the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Further changes of this kind will follow.

Honourable members will also continue to see the adoption of a simpler drafting style in new tax laws, and the gradual revision of their provisions that could be expressed more clearly. It must be remembered, however, that all developed countries have complex laws-including tax laws-which necessarily reflect the complexity of commercial affairs. Indeed, some laws must be complex, if only because those out to exploit them do not shy from complexity in what they do. This ongoing process of law improvement, which will involve consultation with practitioners and industry groups, will ensure continuing progress in a key element of our tax reform program. The whole Australian community can only benefit from this initiative.
Taxation of Traditional Securities

This Bill introduces new rules to apply after today for the taxation of traditional financial securities not being securities issued at a discount to which the accruals provisions of division 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 apply. Under the existing law certain gains and losses on the disposal or redemption of traditional securities are dealt with under the capital gains and capital losses provisions. This Bill excludes from the operation of those provisions gains or losses on the disposal or redemption of traditional securities acquired after today. Instead, under specific measures included by this Bill, the future tax treatment of gains and losses on the disposal or redemption of traditional securities will be dealt with under the general income tax law. The amendments will result in a small but unquantifiable gain to revenue.
Capital Gains Principal Residence Exemption

The Bill will give effect to the proposal announced on 22 November 1988 to extend to units in retirement villages and similar accommodation the exemption from the tax on capital gains for a taxpayer's sole or principal residence. The amendment will apply from 20 September 1985, the date of first effect of capital gains tax.
Maintenance Payments

The income tax exemption available for periodical payments of maintenance received from a husband or former husband will be extended to include payments received, on or after 1 July 1988, from a wife or former wife, or by a person from a de facto spouse or former de facto spouse. Periodical payments of child maintenance received by or on behalf of a child will also be exempt from tax. A related measure will ensure that an income tax deduction is not available for expenditure or payments in respect of maintenance of a spouse, de facto spouse, or a family member under 16 years of age. The annual cost to revenue of these amendments is estimated to be $100,000.
Taxation of Unmarried Minors

This Bill will amend the special provisions dealing with the unearned income of unmarried minors which is taxed at the top rate of personal tax. The changes take account of an amendment of the Social Security Act 1947 which replaced the handicapped child's allowance with the child disability allowance. The amendments made by this Bill will ensure that a minor in receipt of a child disability allowance, or who is certified by a medical practitioner as being a disabled child, will not be subject to the special provisions. These amendments cover all payments of the new allowance, which began on 15 November 1987. These amendments cover all payments of the new allowance, which began on 15 November 1987.
Beneficiary Rebate

A small adjustment, from $260 to $262, is being made to the level of the beneficiary rebate available for certain single taxpayers in 1988-89, so that no tax will be payable on taxable incomes up to $6,192. The rebate will shade out where taxable incomes exceed the $6,192 threshold and will shade out completely where a person's taxable income is $8,288 or more. This adjustment, which ensures that persons wholly dependent on specified Commonwealth benefits or allowances do not pay income tax, is estimated to cost $200,000 in 1989-90.
Gifts

As announced on 16 December 1988, gifts to a public fund for the relief of persons affected by the earthquakes in Armenia made on or after 8 December 1988 and before 1 July 1989 will qualify for tax deduction. The revenue cost of this proposal is estimated at $500,000 in 1989-90. Gifts to the Australian Ireland Fund will qualify for tax deductability for today at a cost of $50,000 in a full financial year. I think you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will be particularly interested in that provision.
Access to Taxation Information

Amendments to the taxation secrecy provisions contained in this Bill will permit the Commissioner of Taxation to provide taxation information to certain law enforcement agencies. The authorised law enforcement agencies are the Australian Federal Police, State and Northern Territory police forces, the Director of Public Prosecutions, the National Crime Authority and State and Territory corporate affairs commissions. The legislation contains tight controls on the use that may be made of any information provided by the Commissioner. The amendments will allow the Commissioner to disclose taxation information to authorised law enforcement agency officers only where he considers that the information is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence-that is, an indictable offence-has been committed. The information may only be used for intelligence purposes.

The amendments also allow the Commissioner of Taxation to release taxation information relating to a person convicted of a serious offence for evidence purposes for a post conviction proceeds of crime proceedings. The Commissioner will be required to disclose in his annual report to this Parliament, in respect of each broad category of offence, the number of requests for information by each law enforcement agency and the number of occasions on which information has been provided to each agency. The taxation secrecy provisions are being further amended to permit the Commissioner to provide taxation information to the Comptroller-General of Customs. The requirements of secrecy applying to taxation officers and other persons privy to confidential taxation information will, of course, extend to persons to whom taxation information can be communicated under these amendments. I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am very pleased to introduce this Bill, which will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of a comprehensive double taxation agreement with the People's Republic of China. The Bill will insert the text of the agreement into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as a schedule to that Act. This agreement substantially accords with the other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years. The Government believes it will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment, and wider relationships between Australia and China. The agreement was signed on 17 November 1988, at which time details were announced and copies of the agreement were made publicly available. It deals with all substantial forms of income flowing between both countries, apart from profits on international air transport operations covered by the existing Chinese Airline Profits Agreement.

A particular feature of the agreement is that it provides for `tax sparing' credit relief to be extended by Australia for tax forgone by China under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment. Where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from one of the nominated development incentives, the agreement calls for a tax credit to be allowed as if the Chinese tax forgone had been paid. By this means, the Chinese development incentives will retain their attractions for Australian investors as they will not be effectively negated by the imposition of Australian tax. I note here that the agreement was negotiated on the basis of the existing income tax laws of the respective countries.

The Government recognises that aspects of proposed changes to Australia's general foreign tax credit system, which have been foreshadowed as applying from the beginning of the 1990-91 income year, could affect the practical operation of the tax credit provisions of the agreement, including the tax sparing mechanism. For example, proposed income tax exemptions under our domestic law for certain dividend payments and branch profits derived by Australian companies from comparable tax countries are likely to provide at least as great relief from Australian tax, and would operate in relation to such income from China. The agreement will enter into force when all necessary constitutional processes are completed both by Australia and China. This Bill, when assented to, will complete the processes required of Australia. The agreement is not expected to have any significant effect on the revenue. I table the explanatory memorandum on the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989 [No. 2]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act to give effect to the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 13 February 1989 that only bottles that are for repeated use in marketing alcoholic beverages qualify for exemption from tax on their initial acquisition by a brewer or wholesaler of such beverages. To achieve this, the Bill will remove containers used for marketing alcoholic beverages from the scope of items 94 and 94a of the first schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. At present, these provisions exempt from sales tax bottles and jars that bear a moulded notification that they remain the property of their supplier.

The Bill will also modify exemption item 95 which applies to bottles for repeated use in marketing non-alcoholic drinks. That item will now also operate to exempt, at the time they are first acquired by a manufacturer or a wholesaler, bottles for repeated use in marketing alcoholic beverages. The cost of such bottles, together with costs associated with their recovery and preparation for reuse, will be included in the sale value of the beverage on which sales tax is payable.

Finally, the Bill will extend parallel treatment to beer kegs. This will remedy a situation under which beer kegs became exposed to potential double taxation since beer first attracted sales tax on 24 August 1988. This amendment will apply from that date so that affected taxpayers may obtain refunds of overpaid tax. I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains a more detailed explanation of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill contains social security and veterans' affairs legislation amendments to refine programs introduced by the Government in 1988 and to correct minor drafting defects. In the Budget sittings last year a far-reaching housing assistance package was introduced primarily to help social security recipients renting privately. The measures included rent assistance rate increases, a rise in the rent threshold to address the greater need of people paying higher rents, restriction of rent assistance eligibility to non-home owners and rationalisation of the assessment process for board and lodging rent assistance.

Several refinements are being made by this Bill to improve that comprehensive package. The measures introduced last year are split between two different commencement dates. In the interests of the efficient delivery of these important initiatives, this Bill is aligning the take up dates. All will now begin on 13 June 1989.

In making changes last year to the rent assistance provisions for people in board and lodging accommodation so that only two-thirds of their costs were treated as `rent', special saving provisions enabled existing boarders and lodgers to be phased into the new arrangements. Provision was made for them to continue to receive the same amount of rent assistance they would have received before June 1989 had the higher threshold applied, until they either stop boarding and lodging or become eligible for a higher payment under the new rules. This Bill clarifies certain aspects of those saving provisions.

The notion of `existing boarders and lodgers' is being extended to ensure that not only people already receiving rent assistance but also any who advise the Department of Social Security of their eligibility before the commencement of the new rules will be covered by the saving provisions.

The rent assistance provisions relating to residents of retirement villages will be expanded to ensure that all married persons living apart owing to ill health will be more beneficially assessed as individuals in determining their eligibility. At present, these provisions exclude cases where a married couple is living apart for reasons of ill health but where only one of the couple is a pensioner.

An amendment is being made to one of the rent assistance definitions. Currently, the legislation defines `rent' for rent assistance purposes as `amounts payable every three months or more frequently'. An amendment would provide for the inclusion in the definition of regular payments in the nature of rent. This will have the effect of extending eligibility for rent assistance to people who pay amounts on a regular basis which are clearly rent although they may be paid less frequently than three monthly-for example, annual rents for caravan sites, boat moorings or some retirement villages.

This Bill also makes further improvement in the equity and effectiveness of payments to Australian families. The 1988 May Economic Statement announced the integration of all family payments. This was largely achieved by the Social Security Legislation Amendment Act 1988. To consolidate the integrated payment cycle, the Government proposes minor and consequential amendments in the areas of payment of arrears and cessation of payment.

One of these amendments is to bring the family allowance supplement (FAS) provisions into line with those for family allowance in allowing up to four weeks' arrears to be paid for a newborn baby, provided the claim is lodged within four weeks of the baby's birth. The FAS provisions are also to be brought into line with those applying to other family payments for the purpose of cessation of payment of pension, benefit or allowance. This will be done by concentrating all the cessation provisions in one reference in the Act. The operation of the formula which applies to the reassessment of the FAS rate following a substantial increase in income will be clarified. This will be achieved by deleting a reference to `125% of' the income threshold as the basis for the recalculation-the intention is that the flat income threshold be used.

The first of two minor amendments to the child disability allowance (CDA) provisions is to make it clear, by reinstating a reference to the Handicapped Persons' Assistance Act, that CDA is not payable where a child in an institution attracts certain payments, including handicapped child's benefit, under that Act. Secondly, it is being made clear that qualification for CDA is preserved even where family allowance, which is usually a prerequisite of CDA, is no longer paid because the child has been admitted to an institution for a period.

Last year, an income test for maintenance income was introduced. It applies in addition to the longstanding test on general income for all means tested pensions and benefits. A small technical amendment to the maintenance free area component of the new income test is required to remove an anomaly in the splitting of the free area between married clients.

As announced in the Treasurer's April statement, an additional waiting period is to be inserted for unemployment or sickness benefit for people who receive payments for annual leave on termination of employment. This will be over and above the usual seven day waiting period. The new waiting period will be the same as the period of annual leave for which the payment is due, up to a maximum of four weeks. This extended waiting period is a more accurate reflection of a person's need for support in such circumstances.

Two minor corrections are also to be made to the existing waiting period provisions as they apply to unemployment benefit. An existing reference to a period of three months will be revised to read 13 weeks. This reference covers a particular circumstance in which the waiting period may be waived. The amendment provides equal treatment regardless of the number of days in a month and is consistent with adjacent references. Special benefit is to be included in the list of benefits which entitle a former long term beneficiary to a waiver of the waiting period on reclaiming within the requisite period.

This Bill also has provisions to promote a fair and efficient system for dealing with certain debts due to the Commonwealth arising from prosecution action. Where a person is convicted of an offence under the Social Security Act, a court may, as well as imposing a penalty for the offence, order him or her to pay back any incorrectly paid entitlement resulting from the act, failure or omission for which the conviction was made. This is known as a reparation order.

The only mechanism available to enforce such a debt is through picking up the relevant State or Territory laws on the enforcement of fines. Differences between these laws have resulted in disparities in the treatment of Federal offenders who have been ordered to pay reparation. Where they are not treated as civil debtors, these people may become embroiled in criminal recovery procedures with the possible consequence of imprisonment in default. Such results should be avoided.

By inserting a ruling that reparation orders are to be enforced as civil judgments, this Bill, along with complementary amendments being made to the Crimes Act, makes sure that any order will be dealt with as compensation for loss rather than as a punishment. The risk of imprisonment for default will be eliminated and all Federal offenders will be treated consistently. Furthermore, enforcement will be at the discretion of the Commonwealth.

The remainder of the Bill deals with a series of technical amendments and name changes. These include amendments to various references in the legislation to certain prescribed educational schemes for Aborigines to reflect the decision to change their names as from 1 January this year. The former Aboriginal secondary assistance scheme and Aboriginal study assistance scheme have been replaced by one comprehensive program, known as Abstudy, which encompasses both secondary and tertiary elements, known respectively as Abstudy Schooling and Abstudy Tertiary. Another amendment is to state correctly the name of the Air Force emergency Force as it appears in the provision which exempts participants from the work test requirements for unemployment benefit. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1989-90[COGNATE BILLS:SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1989-90SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1989-90]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on the contribution to this debate on the Supply Bills made by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) before the suspension of the sitting for lunch.
—A good speech; I heard it.
—Yes, so did I. It was top class.

—Despite the interjections from the honourable member for Parramatta and the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, the comments by the honourable member for La Trobe fell far short of the standard required of this House in that they misrepresented the true funding position of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation-or perhaps I should say the funding that afflicts CSIRO. I have to admit that I have been developing a sneaking regard for the honourable member for La Trobe in his advocacy of CSIRO over the past few months, however lame that advocacy was on occasions. However, after his comments today in which he welcomed the supposed Government rescue of CSIRO and science generally, as announced in the Government's major statement on science on Monday, I now regard him, as I always have, as a rabid left winger, incapable of addressing in any structured way the realities that afflict our great institutions. The honourable member for La Trobe--

—I thank the honourable member for naming the honourable member. I came in at the end of that utterance. I draw to the attention of the honourable member for Gippsland the fact that it is against Standing Orders to cast personal reflections on members of this House. I ask the honourable member to adhere to that.

—Certainly, Madam Deputy Speaker. However, I remind the House that the honourable member for La Trobe is a self-proclaimed radical left winger. That is exactly what he is-myopic and out of touch. He has now betrayed the same people he has sought to represent over the last few months. Nonetheless, towards the end of his speech before the suspension of the sitting for lunch he swung back to veiled criticism of the Government. He posed the question of what would happen to the technical staff of CSIRO after the injection of Government funding following yesterday's science statement. He said that he hoped the funding would be sufficient to maintain CSIRO as the premier research institution in this country. He started off congratulating the Government but, by the time he had finished and perhaps thought through as he was speaking some of the realities of that charade, that fraud of a science statement, he was not so sure that the Government deserved congratulations.

SPEECH.PARA: One cannot help being utterly bemused by the praise he heaped on the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who was then at the table. He congratulated the Minister on his new responsibilities, those new responsibilities being twofold: First, the elevation to the position of Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on Science and Technology and, secondly, the responsibility of formulating and developing a coordinated strategy on science. Let us look at both of those elevations in turn to see whether they are deserving of congratulations. First, as I told the House on Monday, can one possibly think of anything more absurd than giving a Minister of State the title of Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the same portfolio that he already has? There is not a Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on Defence Science and Personnel, there is not a Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on Defence; there are Ministers for those separate portfolios. It is playing with words to elevate a Minister already in charge of a portfolio to the position of Minister Assisting the Prime Minister. It is a total con.

Secondly, the Minister has been given the responsibility of formulating science policy. It is tragic not just for the Minister concerned, who has been completely humiliated, but for the constituency he is supposed to represent in his role as a Minister of State. If he has not been developing science policy and coordinating Government strategies in this area, what has he been doing for six years? We are delving into the realms of the ridiculous if we believe that this turn of events has heralded some changed circumstances, that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business will now have any more influence over this Government than he had in the past-and that was precious little.

It is a payoff to the Minister for Science for withdrawing at the last moment one of his numerous threats to resign. He has gone to the brink and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has bought him off. I am not so sure that the Minister for Science knows it. If he is incapable of understanding the true crisis of science in Australia today, he is probably incapable of knowing that the Prime Minister has pulled the wool over his eyes. The Minister for Science has been patted on the head and told that he is a great academic. He is an important man now! He will now have the ear of the Prime Minister as the person responsible for coordinating science strategy, as if he was not always the holder of that responsibility. I ask the House the rhetorical question as I did on Monday: can anybody imagine Bob Hawke sitting around on a Saturday afternoon as the races are being run at Randwick and the football is being played at the Melbourne Cricket Ground-presuming he is not at either event; I expect that he would be-listening to Barry rabbit on about science?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! For the further reference of the honourable member for Gippsland, as he continues to speak, I inform him that he should refer to the Prime Minister by his title as is required under Standing Orders.
—If the Prime Minister has displayed an utter contempt for the Minister for Science in the past six years, that is not about to change magically because he has a new title.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now draw the House's attention to what the coalition would do on assuming the Government benches. I will advise how science, and in particular, the CSIRO would profit under a coalition government. Under a coalition government, this country would enjoy a comprehensive strategy for the development of its science and technological potential. A coalition government would bring to an end the fragmented and ad hoc approach to public policy in respect of science and technology.

If one benefit has been accrued from last Monday's statement it is that the Government has finally realised that a coordinated strategy is needed for science. We cannot have the several different Government Ministers responsible for different aspects of science and technology running in different directions. When the absurdity of the very first sentence in the Minister's statement, which read that this was the first time in six years that the Minister for Science had stood before the House to deliver the Government's coordinated science policy, was pointed out to him, his lame reply was, `It's the first time I've managed to get together the five Ministers who have an influence in this area'. What sort of explanation is that? What sort of justification is that for standing for the first time with a supposed coordinated policy in his hand? Was it so difficult to bring five Ministers together? Is Cabinet not a regular occurrence? Is it not possible for the Minister for Science to bang together the heads of the Minister for Defence and Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) to bring some sense to science planning and implementation in this country? Why has science been the loser for six years? Is it because of the personal antagonisms among those five Ministers, with the Prime Minister on the sidelines? Of course it is.

We know about the celebrated, bitter personal attack made by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) on the Minister for Science. I will spare the House the vulgarity of the language used but, in effect, the Minister said, `You've done nothing for this Government over the past six years except whinge. You've never argued for increased funding on a factual base. You're nothing but a liability'. Suffice it to say that, given the vitriol of his attack, the Minister had to write a personal letter of apology to the Minister for Science.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has dismissed out of hand the Minister for Science as an irrelevancy. He has taken over the policy formulation of CSIRO and has even taken unto himself most of the day to day functions of CSIRO, leaving the Minister for Science as the titular head of CSIRO only. I know from the shadow Minister for Customs, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), that the Minister for Science now has little effect, even in Customs. Everything must be cleared either through the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce-DITEC-or Senator Button's office.

I regret very much that the Minister for Science has been bought off so very easily with meaningless titles that give him no more weight, no more influence and no more power to argue on behalf of the science community in this country than he had over the last six years. No-one from the Government benches should come into this House and pretend that the problems of science have been meaningfully addressed. The status of the Minister for Science might have been papered over but the structural fundamental problems of CSIRO, of university research, the dilapidated equipment and this Government's failure to attract the best and brightest young people, still remain for the reasons outlined by the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and me last Monday.

We would put an end to the Ministerial rivalries. Indeed, it is not overstating the case to say that the loser in this inter-Ministerial rivalry and bitterness that exists on the side of the Government, is of course the science community. Whilst the Ministers engage in a most self-indulgent way in their personal rivalries and animosities, science loses out. Under a coalition government, immediate and direct steps would be taken to implement a coherent science and technology strategy which would fill the vacuum left by our predecessors. Under a coalition government, CSIRO would again assume its position as the critical centre of the nation's research. It would be adequately funded and effectively administered so that all of its divisions could get on with the job of providing the base for our short and long term economic needs. Moreover, all CSIRO divisions would be adequately funded. They would be free of fears and suspicions brought on by apprehensions that their research project might not be favoured by particular Ministers. Nobody should underestimate the fear that resides within CSIRO. If one does not play favourites and does not indulge in some of the particular research programs that are likely to appeal to some of the Ministers with some influence over CSIRO one will lose out.

We would meet the CSIRO's current funding shortfall of $40m and supplement it to the value of a further $20m per year in line with the advice of that organisation. Under a coalition government, the CSIRO would be accountable to a committee of Ministers, who would articulate the economy's needs and lay out an agenda for that organisation which would, firstly, spell out what is to be the balance between applied and pure research. Secondly, it would lay to rest debates about the merits of industry and agricultural research, which have, at points, threatened to tear that organisation apart.

In what little time remains to me, I wish to address, under these Appropriation Bills some energy matters. I refer particularly to confusion within Government ranks regarding uranium. As we know, this Government has pursued a three mine policy-the three mines being Ranger and Nabarlek in the Northern Territory and Roxby Downs or Olympic Dam in South Australia. Following the fury of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) National Conference in Hobart last June, a committee was established to examine the three mine policy. It is now emerging that the divisions that ran so deep in the ALP up to that conference remain.

Let us examine some of the different positions of the senior Ministers of this Government and let those submissions to the ALP committee of review on the three mine policy speak for themselves. The Prime Minister has mooted the use of uranium as a substitute for coal fired electricity generating plants so as to diminish the greenhouse effect. He mentioned this at the time of the announcement of a new package for funding for further research efforts into the greenhouse effect which was on 6 April this year. That set the hares running and followed very much on comments made by the Chairman of the CSIRO, Mr Neville Wran, late last year, that he believed that nuclear power should be considered as an alternative to carbon dioxide producing coal-powered plants.

Senator Richardson, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, defended the Prime Minister in early April when the Prime Minister floated the idea of nuclear plants. Senator Richardson's submission to the committee of review has ridiculed the current three mine policy as being purely illogical, ideological, hypocritical and a demonstrable failure. He believes, as does the Prime Minister, that nuclear powered plants would have a beneficial environmental effect, particularly so far as the greenhouse effect is concerned. He has put forward other arguments. He has argued that the ALP is out of kilter with attitudes of international socialist movements towards uranium. He also argues that more than two producing and operating mills are needed in Australia to fully employ Australia's potential so that the only limitation to expansion would be commercial viability. Obvious economic benefits, in terms of offsetting current account deficits, also form part of Senator Richardson's submission. Senator Richardson is dismissive of the Chernobyl and Three Mile Island incidents. He replies, `Look at other industry deaths, accidents and hazards'. Moreover, he concludes by saying that ideological principle overshadows reality; the reality being that Australia needs to export uranium. Moreover, the effect of locking up uranium reserves in Australia has had no influence of any kind on the expansion of the nuclear power industry.

Senator Button contends that one ought to get into the value-added side of the uranium market. He believes that Australia should become involved in chemical conversion applications worth about $30m a year; that is, the conversion of uranium oxide-yellowcake-to uranium hexafluoride. Uranium enrichment would add $300m to exports through metalazer technologies. He likes the idea of fabricating fuel rods in Australia.

Senator Evans is somewhat circumspect about expansion of the industry on economic grounds alone, but he believes in the possibility of involvement in the uranium enrichment processes. The biggest surprise of all comes from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. He is a supposed economic rationalist who wants to deregulate the wheat market but leave alone the very highly regulated labour market. In other words the form of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is that he will do the easy thing as long as it does not affect his supposed constituency, being the trade movement in the example I have just given. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy defends the three mine policy in his submission, or in his public statements. He says that there is no immediate economic benefit from expansion. Why does he not let the market determine this? He sees nothing to be gained from involvement in the conversion and enrichment technology available as the market is in oversupply.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a regulator.

—He is a regulator; a regulator when it suits him and a deregulator when he thinks there is not a vote in it for him. What way is that to approach one's responsibilities as a Minister of State? In other words, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in regard to the uranium debate, takes merely a political stance, because he is fearful of divisions amongst backbenchers and in the ALP generally. The South Australian Government is flagging the notion of nuclear power as an alternative power source through its so-called discussion paper prepared for the Bannon State Government by its Energy Planning Executive.

SPEECH.PARA: In Western Australia Premier Dowding says that the idea of building a power station would be inconceivable, given Chernobyl and Three Mile Island. He takes a different view again. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) and the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) have complained in a letter dated 5 April to the convener of this committee, Mr Ian Henderson, the ALP's assistant national secretary, that the committee was being railroaded into a pro-uranium policy, because of the tight timetable for the report at this year's end. The committee has only had 18 months; it has been in existence only since last June; and it only has to report in December this year-hopefully, the Government believes, after the early election. There is no way in the world that that committee will deliver a report before the next Federal election. This Government is likely at this stage to have an election early next year, so let us not hold our breaths for this report.
