DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 6) 1988[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988INCOME TAX (FUND CONTRIBUTIONS) BILL 1988INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1989INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 November, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) concurrently with the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Income Tax (Fund Contributions) Bill, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill and the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill (No. 2). There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is now commencing a debate on six Bills: the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, Income Tax (Fund Contributions) Bill 1988, Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1989 and Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. If these six Bills are passed in their entirety, they will introduce into the legislation of this nation some of the most profound changes ever seen by the superannuation industry and by over 3 1/2 million Australians who belong to superannuation schemes. The Bills will introduce a range of changes which, while many are necessary, the Opposition believes will have a profound and negative influence on the future direction of individual savings in this country, with particular reference to the capacity of Australians, the work force in particular, to save for their ultimate retirement so that they may in due course have a degree of financial independence which previous generations were denied.

SPEECH.PARA: It has now been nearly 12 months since the Government, in its statement of May 1988, announced these superannuation changes. Towards the end of the last session, in the dying days of the Budget period, we saw introduced into this place three Bills which the Opposition at that stage simply refused to take, because it argued then-as was certainly its right-that the people of Australia deserved the opportunity to see the entire package debated concurrently. Therefore, I am pleased to say that after so much delay and prevarication, and after government by what can only be described as press release, both the Opposition and the industry-representing, as I said, over three million Australian superannuants-now have before them these six most important Bills. The major tax measures which are the essential ingredients of this legislation will impose a 15 per cent tax on employer contributions to public and private sector superannuation funds, a further 15 per cent tax on superannuation fund income and a 16.25 per cent tax, which of course includes the Medicare levy, on lump sums over $60,000.

The purpose of this package is to replace the 30 per cent tax introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) back in 1983. It may be recorded that at that time it was this Labor Government which did away with the old 5 per cent lump sum tax and replaced it with a very high level of lump sum tax when people took their final benefits. In an effort to get access to revenue earlier rather than spread it over about 30 years, this really brings forward the tax which otherwise would have to wait for collection until ultimate retirement. There is nothing illegal nor illogical about that-it is a legitimate thing to do. Of course, it is equally legitimate to conduct one's tax policy on the principle that one is not taxed through the period of generation of the asset but is taxed when the asset is realised. However, the Government has gone further than that: It has introduced a third element into the equation, that is the 15 per cent tax on fund income. It is that point above all else that particularly concerns the Opposition in this debate. In due course, in the committee stage, I will move a range of amendments so that the House, and the Australian people through this House, will have the opportunity to determine whether that is the right direction in which superannuation policy should go for the future of this nation.

When the Liberal and National parties released their policy a few months ago they made some very important commitments in the area of superannuation. At that time we stated that we were committed to a retirement income policy which gives opportunities for all Australians to plan their retirement and achieve greater self-reliance so that they may live in dignity with an adequate and secure level of income. We believe that this subject is of paramount importance, and that is because our population, like that of Western Europe and the United States, is now going through a cycle of ageing. People are living longer and they are retiring earlier. By the year 2010 it is estimated that the number of Australians over 45 years of age will be between 8.5 million and 8.7 million, or about 40 per cent of the population-a growth of 70 per cent over that period. This significant change in our demographic profile, combined with the trend to early retirement, highlights the need for a sensible, coherent and socially responsible retirement income policy which will ensure greater financial independence, self-reliance and security for all Australians as we prepare to enter the twenty-first century.

It is a matter of profound regret to members of the Opposition that, while the opportunities have been before this Government for over six years, so little has been done in a long term sense to put in place a range of policies which will achieve those obvious objectives which are of such profound importance that the Opposition believes they should meet with agreement across the political frontiers of this land. Since coming to office in 1983, this Labor Government has repeatedly chipped away at retirement income, leaving it with no comprehensive philosophy or national strategy for retirement income planning. Over the past five years, the Government has increased the tax rate on superannuation alone by nearly 1,000 per cent. Everyone knows that the Labor Government is Australia's highest peacetime taxing Government, but I wonder how many people realise what impact that taxation has had on the life savings and retirement savings of millions of Australians.

Over that period the Government also introduced no less than 20 major changes affecting retirement planning. While the purchasing power of the pension has fallen dramatically, the eligibility criteria for the age and service pensions have been changed on no less than seven occasions. Under Labor, Australia now has one of the most complex systems of occupational superannuation anywhere in the world and undoubtedly this has created massive uncertainty in the minds of contributors, beneficiaries and fund managers alike. Through the rigid application of the income and assets tests, a great many people in need have been forced off the age pension. That is why they need access to superannuation and life savings more today than perhaps at any other time since the second world war. Undoubtedly the atmosphere of this constant change created by Labor has made it virtually impossible for many Australians to plan their retirement income with any real confidence.

It is for that reason that the Liberal and National parties' retirement income policy is designed to achieve the following three primary objectives: firstly, a stable and simple legislative and administrative environment in which people can plan their retirement income with confidence; secondly, greater encouragement for all Australians to plan and contribute to their retirement income with the aim of achieving universal coverage of the work force and increasing significantly the level of domestic savings; and, thirdly, ensuring that those in genuine need are protected in their old age.

It is a matter of profound regret that Labor has failed those three tests. It will continue to fail unless it is prepared to support the policy approaches adopted by the coalition. Therefore, these six Bills are of profound importance. While they bring forward a number of administrative changes which are necessary and which we support, it is our profound belief that at the basis of the legislation there is a lack of political and philosophical integrity as to what the objectives of retirement income policy, and especially the interface between that policy and role of superannuation, should be all about. When the Treasurer announced the superannuation tax changes in the May 1988 statement, he said:
The taxation and superannuation benefits will be radically yet sympathetically changed, putting it on a more logical long-term basis without reducing lump sum and pension entitlement.

He said that one year ago and since then, almost on a monthly basis, we have seen constant changes, through press release, to the ball game. The industry has been in consternation; fund organisers have been in consternation; and investors have been in consternation. Meanwhile millions of Australian workers, frankly, do not know who to believe. Is that any wonder, when one literally does not know the basis upon which one enters into a fund and for how long that basis will remain intact? So if it could be said that there are three fundamental contradictions in the Government's policy, that is clearly the first. The next contradiction is contained in this further statement of the Treasurer:
Together these changes complete the Government's review of superannuation tax arrangements.
and listen to this-
People can now plan their retirement with complete certainty and confidence.

The Government should go out and tell the three million pensioners of Australia on superannuation and people in the work force who are contributing to superannuation how real that situation is. They have no confidence because the changes which are now in place-and I will discuss them in a moment-emphasise fundamentally that without a stable legislative basis, one cannot plan with any confidence for the future.

Where does this leave the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and his proposed retirement income policy which we are told will be introduced to the Australian people, I hope, some time in June or early July? Will it contain further changes because, if it does not, I seriously question how it can be a retirement income policy. Clearly, it will have to contain changes, which emphasises yet again the fallacy that the Treasurer put to this House in May 1988 that people could now plan with confidence.
The third point is the question of tax changes, and in that respect this is what the Treasurer said:
They will allow the Government to bring forward nearly $1 billion of its own tax money now lying in superannuation funds without diminishing any personal end benefit by one cent.

Those words should be emblazoned upon the Treasurer's forehead for the rest of his life-`one solitary cent'. He is a very brave man to make a commitment like that. It is almost as silly as saying what the tax changes are going to be 12 months before they are introduced, totally ignoring the realities of economic change over that period. But we have done our examinations of this particular commitment, and I can confidently tell the House-and I will be tabling information to emphasise this point in due course-that there are few, if any, members of superannuation schemes around Australia who will not lose 10, 12, and sometimes as high as 15-odd per cent of their end benefits because of the impact of the three tax points introduced in this legislation. `But do not worry, no one will lose one cent'. It must be true! Why? Because the Treasurer told us so, the same man who told us that inflation was going to come down, joined by his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the same man who said that everybody was going to be better off than they had been in the past, despite the realities of at least six years of diminishing income for the average Australian family. But do not worry, nobody is going to lose one cent from his or her retirement income!

Since that famous promise, the coalition has consistently stated that its attitude to this legislation will be predicated on two important facts: Firstly, the need for the Treasurer's promise to be met and, secondly, the need to ensure that the level of tax would not become a disincentive to superannuation savings. We made those commitments because we want this Government to be honest to the Australian people and to be responsible for the commitments it made in this House and elsewhere in the area of superannuation. Secondly, we made this commitment because we believe that in the Australia of today, which is so desperately crying out for greater domestic savings, the integrity of superannuation savings must be beyond doubt. That is why we will stand and fight to stop those millions of small Australians-not people who have a big voice in this Parliament, but ordinary workers who are simply trying to save for their future retirement and save something for future taxpayers in so doing-from being walked over yet again by this Government.

We have remained consistent on these points. It is a matter of great sadness that others have not. We believe that the need for greater self-financing for retirement income to reduce the inevitable demand on present and future taxpayers should be self-evident. Following the Government's personal tax cuts announced in the April statement, it is clear that the comparative attractiveness of superannuation as a long term source for savings under Labor's new superannuation regime is no longer viable. That is particularly so for low income groups. They would do better to spend their money elsewhere, to put it in real estate or in their own domestic homes, but not in superannuation, because with the new tax scales, as against the 15 or 16.25 per cent tax levels introduced by Labor, the differential has gone. There is simply no longer a tax advantage in superannuation.

I confess that I honestly hoped that the Treasurer, in introducing his tax changes, would realise this fact and would bring into this chamber in his White Paper a statement saying, `We will now reduce the tax on superannuation to bring it into line with the new personal tax scales'. If he had done that, that would have been a step well and truly in the right direction. But the Government failed, and it failed for one fundamental reason: It is either inept or it is simply interested in collecting as much revenue as it possibly can. I leave it to the audience to choose which they like. The coalition is, therefore, determined to ensure that these new taxes do not discourage people from planning for their retirement via superannuation.

I refer now to the tax on earnings, the 15 per cent income tax. Our main concern is that this tax on investment income, and the two amendments that we will move in this regard to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6), have the following effect: The critical effect in the Government's front end taxation package is meant to allow imputed tax credits to offset the nominal 15 per cent tax on fund earnings. The front end tax measure is designed to force a greater proportion of the investment assets of the superannuation industry into what the Treasurer euphemistically called the quality end of the Australian share market.

Surely, no one in this chamber should object to the concept of encouraging investment in Australian manufacturing and other industries. Let me make that absolutely clear. But let us also face the fact that it is this Treasurer who seeks such credit on his own behalf for the fact that he deregulated the financial industry-in other words, he said to the banks, building societies and everybody else, `Go out, do your hardest, maximise the return on your investment and help your shareholders accordingly'. That is splendid stuff; we have endorsed that all the way. Yet at the same time, through this particular proposal, he is putting limitations on the capacity of the free movement of funds towards investments of quality, wherever they may be, when the objective should surely be to maximise the ultimate return.

According to the Treasurer, superannuation funds can bring the 15 per cent nominal tax on earnings down to a lower effective rate of some 4 per cent. That was because he gave them the right to dividend imputation, which was quite sensible in that context. It meant that they could write off their taxes, that they could have tax credits elsewhere, which to some degree will be affected when the company rate comes down from 49 per cent to 39 per cent, and when those credits are used up perhaps there will be higher taxes in the future. But one thing is clear: companies which have the best portfolio balance in terms of shares which attract the full range of dividend imputation credits can significantly reduce their taxes.

But the system tends to fail in view of the fact that not all of us put our money into superannuation schemes until death. The vast majority of people change jobs at some stage, and when that takes place the money goes into an approved deposit fund (ADF) or into a roll-over fund. Other people do not even have to go to superannuation; they can go directly into roll-over funds. In those funds, for the most part, they do not have access to the same level of dividend imputation as is available in superannuation schemes, because the investments in those schemes, for the most part, are in longer term fixed investment-type arrangements. Consequently, the outcome is clear: From the moment one's money is taken out of a superannuation scheme one is lumbered with the full 15 per cent. There is no way it can be avoided. That is why we argue that there is a fundamental fallacy and a lack of equity in the approach to individual investments in this field.

There is a wide range of reasons why superannuation funds, with the exception of large funds such as the AMP Society, do not hold a greater proportion of their assets in equities. The principal among these is that the value of shares is subject to wide and unpredictable fluctuations over time. What greater example of that did we see than the crash of 1987? Prior to the crash, funds which did not have an annual return of around 35 per cent were regarded as the tail end of the market, whereas the average fund today is lucky to make it to 15 per cent. That is a clear demonstration of the realities of the marketplace, realities which, I submit, were not taken into account by those in the Treasury or elsewhere who advised the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that this was a milch cow that had to be milked for all it was worth, ignoring the fundamental fact that if investments are taken out of superannuation not only is the capacity of individuals to have greater financial security and independence in retirement effectively reduced, but also, at that tax point, much more so than the tax on employer contributions or even a limited tax on final end income, one is maximising the administrative costs and, therefore, the costs to the individual, of going down that second tax point road.

What is so sad, coming from a Labor Government, is that union based superannuation funds, which are capital guaranteed, for the most part-the so-called 3 per cent productivity schemes where the contributions mainly come from employers and workers who do not have any other form of superannuation-will be the greatest losers of the very scheme that Messrs Kelty and Crean, the Treasurer and others put together and forced on the manufacturers and employers of Australia in a so-called productivity package. They did not think it out. Twelve months later they still have not had the courage to say to the millions of workers whom they want to bring into superannuation-an object which the Liberal Party and the National Party totally support, I might add-that their end benefits are being cut to ribbons because of the impact of this tax package, which is onerous and grossly unfair on that section of the superannuation market which has the least level of protection. They will have to pay the full 15 per cent tax on employer contributions across a wider base than other funds, and will be severely disadvantaged by their reduced access to the offsetting imputation credits.

The Treasurer made it clear in May 1988 that he wished to see ADFs and roll-over funds become a natural extension of superannuation. As I have already pointed out, the very impact of the tax, unfair as it is on superannuation schemes and their various categories on the one hand, and the way they impact upon ADFs and roll-over funds on the other hand, demonstrates clearly that while it is correct to say that they should be a natural extension of superannuation, the fact is that this policy has utterly failed in achieving that most important outcome. Therefore, as I said earlier, Labor's tax package will seriously affect simple accumulation funds, especially the 3 per cent productivity schemes, the majority of which accommodate low paid workers, the very backbone of the union structure of this country, which the Australian Labor Party has claimed for so long as its own.

The coalition believes that the imposition of the 15 per cent fund income tax does reduce people's end benefits, not only for those in ADFs and roll-over funds, but for those in normal superannuation funds as well. As a result, it can be seen only as a fundamental disincentive to save. There are three categories of losers comprising hundreds of thousands of superannuants. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —This table is self-explanatory, so I will not comment on it. It simply demonstrates quite clearly that whether we are talking about investments in fixed interest ADFs in situations where we have both employer and employee funded schemes, or where we have productivity schemes, or in the case of new members joining contributory schemes, the simple and sad fact is that in virtually all categories, everyone is a loser. So much for the Treasurer's commitment that no-one will be worse off by one cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to fixed interest ADFs. Individuals who have placed their accumulated retirement savings in a roll-over facility with no equities exposure will pay the full 15 per cent tax, even allowing for the Treasurer's generous transitional rules. Therefore individuals must pay substantially. For example, for individuals aged 50 at 1 July 1988 with 18 years prior service, the cumulative effect of this tax at the full 15 per cent will reduce the end benefit at age 65 by 12 per cent, and by 6 per cent if the benefit is taken at the age of 60. Even if those individuals transferred to a roll-over facility, they would still lose.

There is a similar situation with the loss arising out of the May 1988 package for these people, which is substantial indeed. For a 40 year old with 18 years prior service, the loss is as high as 17 per cent of end benefit for a person aged 65, based on a fund income tax rate of 10 per cent after imputation. Even if the fund income tax rate is reduced to 5 per cent, as the Treasurer claims it can be, the loss at age 65 is still 10.5 per cent. For young people who are commencing to participate in superannuation, the cumulative effect of the fund income tax over a working life will also be substantial. I give an example of this. For a 30 year old, the loss at age 65 in a non-contributory scheme, for example Labor's glorious 3 per cent productivity arrangements, will be 6.5 per cent based on a tax rate of 5 per cent, again after imputation, and 15 per cent based on a tax rate of 10 per cent. Except in those rare cases where the tax rate will be zero, every new contributor 30 years of age or less will lose out because of the fund income tax. For these reasons, we will be moving a range of amendments to this legislation which will have the purpose of removing from the Act the effects of the 15 per cent tax on dividend income, irrespective of where it falls. Furthermore, we will also be removing, as a result of that amendment, the effect of the capital gains provisions under this Act. The Liberal and National parties' policy on capital gains is well known. We will remove utterly Labor's capital gains tax and we will certainly do so in the area of superannuation. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has indicated that the coalition is concerned about the overall bias in the tax system against savings. For some time this has been a matter of great concern to us. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard statistics from the database of the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —The significance of this table is that ever since 1982-83, the position has been getting steadily worse, but I am pleased to see that there was some improvement in the year 1987-88. The fact is that the level of total savings as a percentage of national disposable income has fallen below 3 per cent, and that is a matter of the gravest concern to this nation, which is now so dependent on foreign investment and an accumulation of capital from the people's savings elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: It cannot be stressed too highly that superannuation is the only form of saving which is specifically intended for retirement purposes, and hence has the potential to reduce the demand on the Budget. Any measures by the Government aimed at enhancing the attractiveness of savings and investment in general must ensure that superannuation retains its relative attractiveness if future governments are to have any hope of funding adequate retirement incomes for an ageing population, with the fundamental principle, which I thought was supported by this Government, that we must help to the maximum extent possible especially those most in need. As a result of all this, we are also concerned about the impact of this legislation on final end benefits. Consequently, we will be moving another amendment to lift the current threshold of $60,000 below which no final 16.25 per cent tax is required, to $125,000, which we regard as a more responsible figure, because that in fact equates with what it costs the taxpayer fully to fund a retired couple over the normal number of years in retirement. If we can encourage people to be more independent in their lives so that they can accumulate funds to give them greater financial security in retirement, we will have achieved a great success for this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of Bills-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) and cognate Bills-introduces measures which give effect to the superannuation tax reform announced in the May 1988 economic statement. The two central elements of this package are: firstly, the bringing forward of tax from end benefits to the point at which employer superannuation contributions are made and, secondly, the introduction of a tax at a concessional rate on the investment income of superannuation funds and approved deposit funds.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) also includes legislation announced in the May statement to repeal a special tax treatment relating to the calculated liabilities of life insurance companies. The Bill also incorporates changes in relation to arrangements where a holding company cancels shares that are held by a subsidiary company. The Bill removes the tax exemption from the income of compliant superannuation funds that satisfies standards laid down in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act. Any income accrued before 1 July 1988 will not be taxable, even if derived after 30 June. This will ensure that there is no retrospectivity in this provision. In broad terms, public sector funds are being brought within the scope of the taxation provisions.

There has been some discussion in the 12 months since the May statement about different aspects of the package. Some people with interests in the area have quite rightly brought forward concerns. I wish to touch on one of those concerns which has been brought forward by unions which cover people working in emergency services. They are concerned that this legislation will effectively remove proper early retirement provisions from the superannuation of those emergency service workers.

It has been indicated to those unions that there is an assurance that, in applying the new reasonable benefits arrangements, any benefits accrued in the emergency services superannuation scheme up to 30 June 1990 will be fully protected. To achieve those benefits the Government has requested the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to review the existing arrangements for the administration of the reasonable benefits limit. The Government has not considered the Commissioner's proposal, but the unions have been assured that the Government will support the development of arrangements so that emergency services officers are not disadvantaged by any requirement to retire early. I think that is important because it characterises the way in which the Government has entered into full consultation with those people who have concerns about some of the aspects of the proposal as outlined in May of last year.

In contrast, like so much of Australia's economic and social infrastructure, the retirement income industry was left neglected by decades of coalition incompetence. Since 1983 the Government has embarked upon a process of review and reform. The results of the reforms speak for themselves. In 1983 the total assets held by superannuation funds amounted to some $25 billion. By March 1988 this figure had grown to $80 billion. This Government has given strong and consistent support to private retirement incomes. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has stated in the past:

This is the first Government since Federation to recognise the right of all Australian workers to superannuation, the first to actively support its extension to areas of the work force long left forgotten.

That is important. Not only has there been an expansion of access to people who traditionally were involved in superannuation schemes, but the Government has set out to ensure that those at the lower end of the scale have had similar opportunities. In fact, by the end of the current parliamentary term the level of superannuation coverage is likely to have doubled-and I think that is quite an achievement for this Government. The Government is determined to get retirement incomes policy right to deal with the fact that Australia is an ageing society. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) touched on this matter and it should be indicated that last year there were about 2.5 million Australians aged 60 and over, which represented about 15 per cent of the population. It is estimated that by the year 2021 there will be about 5.3 million Australians in that age bracket, which will constitute 24 per cent of the population.

Currently, older Australians are not a particularly wealthy group. Nearly three-quarters of them have very modest assets. Apart from their family home, their assets amount to under $50,000; but it is important to note that in this age bracket there is a high home ownership rate-76 per cent. The income of older Australians has shown a general improvement since the early 1970s in relation to the Henderson poverty line. Fortunately, it was less likely for an older Australian to be living in poverty in 1987-88 than it was in 1972-73. Although Australia has a better projected age dependency ratio than most other major Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, we cannot afford to ignore the policy implications of an ageing population.

At a macro-economic level, the Economic Planning Advisory Council estimated in 1988 that, to maintain parity with a general rise in living standards, outlays on age pensions would increase from 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product in 1985 to 4.5 per cent of GDP in 2025. This Government has undertaken the necessary research and consultation to ensure that the policy settings are in place to provide security for an ageing population.

As part of the overall Social Security Review, recently paper No. 6 entitled Towards a National Retirement Incomes Policy by Chris Foster was released. The Social Security Review highlighted the fact that comparatively few pensioners received a superannuation pension or annuity income. In 1987 it was a mere 98,000 out of a total age pensioner population of 1.3m, which represents only 7.5 per cent of that population. This reflects the fact that widespread coverage of superannuation has occurred only in the last 15 years. On page 62 of the Social Security Review paper it is stated:
The consumption of lump sums prior to age pension age remains a source of policy concern and could thwart the longer term objective of encouraging self provision for retirement.

The Government is providing considerable retirement income support in two forms: the age pension system and taxation concessions for superannuation. It is estimated that the annual cost of age pensions this year will be in the order of $7 billion. This is, of course, income and assets tested to ensure that it is properly targeted. On the other hand, the Social Security Review paper estimates the value of the tax concessions for superannuation at anywhere between $1.6 billion and $4 billion. Like a whole host of other taxation expenditures, it is always very difficult to get accurate figures. Other estimates have put the figure at about $3 billion. Whatever the amount, it is considerable.

In 1986 the Treasury estimated that the tax exemption for employer contributions and individual contributions to approved funds amounted to $1.71 billion in 1985-86. Again in 1986 the Treasury estimated that the tax free status which applied to most forms of the income of superannuation funds amounted to a further $1.7 billion in forgone revenue. The problem with this form of taxation concession is that it is highly regressive. This problem has been in part addressed by the 1988 May statement. The exemption from taxation of superannuation contributions and investment income derived from a superannuation fund was terminated. It has been replaced by a flat rate tax of 15 per cent. Tax on the end benefits will be reduced by the same rate. Other changes, for example, to the reasonable benefits limit are designed to encourage end benefits that genuinely provide continuing retirement income.

Issues of fairness and equity, especially in relation to retrospectivity, have by no means been completely resolved. The flat rate tax of 15 per cent still represents a considerable concession to wealthy taxpayers who would normally be subject to the top marginal rate of taxation on employment and investment income. I have previously quoted Rick Krever, a senior lecturer in law at Monash University. Tonight I wish to quote from some of his work which appeared in the journal Impact in July 1988, where he made some comments on the effects of the May 1988 statement. In talking about the regressive aspect of the impact of taxation expenditures, Mr Krever had this to say:

The level of Government subsidy has dropped, but the upside-down effect remains untouched. Compared to the tax that would normally be levied on a taxpayer's remuneration and investment income, the new tax on contributions and fund earnings represents no concession for lowest income taxpayers, a slight concession for low income taxpayers and a massive concession for high income taxpayers.
Again he has illustrated and outlined a concern with the present arrangements. Rick Krever also pointed out in a recent issue of Australian Society:
The attraction of this low rate-
which, in particular, is the 15 per cent that is being introduced in this legislation-
drops with a taxpayers income, as the gap between the 15% and the marginal tax narrows.
In the case of low income earners there is no subsidy. Krever concludes:
Only the rich continue to enjoy significant tax hand-outs from the concessions.

When I have spoken previously of the way the effects of taxation expenditures impact on superannuation, the honourable members opposite have quite unfairly suggested that by making those comments I am seeking to have a higher tax burden placed on superannuation. In putting forward my concerns and those of others, I ask that in considering these matters we fairly and squarely keep the fairness and equity points in mind and that we attempt to ensure that the effects are put in place in an equitable manner. It is unfair that, having gone through other aspects of income support and ensured that any benefit that derives from government is appropriately targeted, we should ignore in the overall review of superannuation government assistance to superannuation which is not given the same appropriate targeting. I hope that at some stage we will be mature enough to be able to have that discussion and debate. I hope that those sorts of points are not in some way misrepresented by someone saying that they are an attempt to increase the tax burden. That is not the case.

The May statement of 1988 provided that the overall effect of the superannuation measures would be neutral. That is an important aspect. It is disappointing that the Opposition cannot see its way clear to support this package of legislation. It is important that we try to rearrange the way superannuation is treated. The other important aspect-I do not think the honourable member for Bradfield, on behalf of the coalition, actually addressed these points-is that this package is an attempt to tie in the disparate aspects of income support for the aged, not only age pensions and superannuation but the general way the tax system affects both. We have to realise that. There should be much more importance placed on the effect of so-called tax expenditures-that is, tax that is foregone by special arrangements-that government puts on activities. We tend to overlook and ignore those aspects. The Department of Finance puts out a paper which is separate from the Budget related papers. Whether it be through the committee system of this Parliament or in some other way, we should be looking more closely to see that the effects of those tax expenditures do not in some way run counter to what we are trying to do in other areas.

In conclusion, I simply say that this is an attempt by the Government to put in place and to improve further a superannuation system that is open to a wider range of the work force. This is very important. This system will assist members of the work force to ensure that during their working lives they can make proper arrangements that will give them support in their retirement years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take part in this debate because I have had a continuing interest in the development of this country's retirement incomes policy. Sadly, since the present Government has been in office a number of significant opportunities of developing a rational retirement incomes policy have been missed. That is a very great pity. There was a time when over 80 per cent of the Australian population reaching retirement were eligible to an age pension or part age pension. We were so close to a situation where there was universal availability of that age pension that it is a tragedy that the opportunity was not taken to abolish both the income and the assets test so that all those people aged 65 and over could become entitled to a basic pension.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is introducing taxation legislation in respect of superannuation funds because it failed to take that opportunity. Had it done so there would then have been an automatic eligibility for Australian citizens with the appropriate residence who attained the age of 65 to receive a universal and basic pension equal to 25 per cent or thereabouts of average weekly earnings. That would have brought about a dramatic change in people's social savings, investment and working behaviour. What we find now is that everyone, as they approach retirement age, asks the question, `How will the system prejudice me if I take a certain course of action?'. They ask whether they should continue in employment. They ask themselves whether they should save and if so in what form should they save. They ask themselves whether they should run down their savings in order that they may get below the limits, whether it is the assets test limit or the incomes test limit. As a result of that, we have many thousands of Australians whose basic desire is to be self-reliant, to save for their future, saying to themselves, `I have paid my taxes; a large percentage of people are entitled to a pension so why shouldn't I be entitled to that same pension?'.

It has been my view that all who reach retirement age should receive, as of right, a pension. But governments have walked away from that. They have said, `Oh no, there are some few wealthy people, whether asset rich or income rich, who will get those pensions and therefore we must have a needs based system'. They do not understand that they are denying those who are totally reliant on the pension greater levels of pension benefit because people's behaviour as to earnings, savings and expenditure is changed and distorted in a way which is not in the interests of the Australian economy. We find that people spend their money overseas so that they will, like those who have spent their money during their working lives, enjoy the benefit of a government pension. We find that they invest their money in their houses because their houses are exempt from the assets test and capital gains tax when we want that investment put in the development of Australia's taxable and income earning capacity.

In this legislation people are being encouraged to take out superannuation. It is very pleasing to note that as a result of a changed view about superannuation savings an increasing number of people in the Australian work force are becoming members of or contributors to superannuation funds. The pity is that too many of them are receiving benefits that are contributed only by their employers, because they are not encouraged to contribute or pay for themselves. The reason for that is that the tax system is not a level system. It is to the advantage of an employer to pay the contribution and get the tax deduction for making the payment rather than to pay additional wages to an employee, who then in most circumstances is required to pay into a superannuation scheme out of after-tax income, without any tax benefit. I think that is a crazy system. I think also that it is most unfortunate that now in this legislation the contributions going into the superannuation funds are to be taxed in the hands of the superannuation funds when received. More unfortunate is the fact that then the income of the superannuation fund is to be taxed, and it is unfortunate again that the taxation of any lump sum payments is still to be continued, albeit at a lower rate.

The major issues of this retirement incomes policy have not yet been faced up to. We will not get individual and family retirement income self-reliance until contributions are made by or on behalf of employees to their superannuation funds at a rate not less than 10 per cent of the income of those employees. Indeed, for lower paid workers it should probably be at a rate not less than an amount equal to 10 per cent of average weekly earnings per annum during their working lives. Only in that way will we reach a situation where retirement savings-whether they have come as a consequence of payments made by employers into superannuation funds on behalf of their employees or as a result of the employees making payments direct, or a combination of both-comprise a sufficient fund to provide a person at the end of a normal working life with a pension which is at least equal to pensions now being paid, from tax revenue, under the social security system.

I think it would be much better for Australia if this were handled by the private sector, with a safety net for those people who had not made such a provision. I believe there should be a universal safety net, with everyone entitled to a basic pension. People may well ask how that can be done. Everyone should be entitled to a basic pension, in one of two forms, but not both. One form is through social security payments, and the other is through the tax sheltering of superannuation funds. Notwithstanding the introduction of the superannuation contribution tax, the superannuation fund income tax and the tax on lump sum payments, there is still a significant level of tax sheltering available through saving in superannuation funds.

I think that that should be quantified. Everyone in the work force should be entitled either to those tax concessions or to a pension-but not both. I think there should be a ceiling on the extent of the tax concessions that are available. That should be on the basis of a universal flat rate retirement income provision. Also, the provision calculated on an earnings related basis should be in relation to after-tax income. It should be a matter of choice on the part of the employee as to whether he wants to have an income related retirement benefit or whether he is satisfied with a flat rate basic minimum.

That is not the case with the legislation that we are considering here. This legislation is just a revenue collecting measure. It does not provide for a mechanism to bring fairness into our retirement income system. Honourable members opposite talk about the people who will benefit from a universal pension at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, the wealthy people of the land, and they say that those people should not get those pensions, but what are they allowing to continue? They allow those very same people-including ourselves as members of parliament-to receive huge tax free benefits, earnings related, to provide themselves with a very substantial retirement income, out of a tax sheltered savings mechanism. If the Government wants to have a rational retirement incomes policy in Australia, it should limit the amount of tax concession available to all. Whether it is through employer payments or through employee payments, it should be limited to the capital cost of purchasing a flat rate age pension of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

I was interested to read in the publication put out by the stock exchanges that these days one can buy immediate annuities. For $50,000, which is about twice average weekly earnings, a 65-year-old man can purchase from the AMP Society a flat rate annuity of $7,754, to be paid for the balance of his life. If he wanted an indexed pension, he would have to take a lower amount. The interesting thing is that an accumulation equal to about twice average weekly earnings-and maybe a bit higher-will purchase an indexed pension equivalent to the present age pension.

I believe that for a person who reaches 65 and who has made no provision, the Government, through the tax system is, in effect, giving that person $50,000, but in a pension form, over the balance of his or her life. That should be the limit of the amount that is provided through tax concessions to those who are saving for their retirement. For the rest of us, if we want benefits beyond the flat rate pension, which the Government has a responsibility of ensuring is available to everyone, that should be provided for out of our after-tax income. If we developed that model we could then have a tax system under which top marginal rates would be much lower than they are today and the general underlying flat rate of the tax system would also be much lower than it is today.

TALK.START.PARA: —What tax would you pay on the earnings?
—On the earnings of the superannuation fund?
—Yes.

—Maybe that should pay the same rate as any other investment would pay. What I am saying is that the total extent of the tax concession to a superannuation fund saver should be limited over his or her lifetime to the capital value of the pension, which is the guaranteed minimum pension that should be available universally to the whole community. Beyond that level, if anyone wants a higher level, we should be able, out of our after-tax income, which would generally be income that is taxed at much lower rates, to save for ourselves according to our own choice.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I want to make now-and because time is limited I will have to develop this point on some later occasion-is that I think there should be a much greater freedom for people to make provision for their own retirement. People should not be forced, in an almost compulsory unionism sort of way, to save through the AMP Society, the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd, approved deposit fund, building unions superannuation or BUS scheme, the union controlled schemes, the joint employer-employee schemes, or whatever it might be. They are fine, and everyone should have the choice of going into those funds if they want to do so, but, equally, people should have the choice of saving for themselves. I might be a young person aged 25 being told that 3 per cent of my income must go into a superannuation scheme, and I might then find that I do not have enough money left to save for my own home. I believe that in those circumstances I should be able to put that 3 per cent of income into my home-with the only requirement that I would have to guarantee that, because I have put that money into my own home, I will not call upon the social security system when I turn 65. There are legal methods whereby adequate security could be provided to guarantee that that saving would be available ultimately for one's retirement and that one would not be able to double dip in the system. It is a great pity that the present Government has not taken the opportunity with this legislation to introduce a major reform of the retirement incomes system. It has been left for a future Liberal government to provide for a universal system which encourages self-reliance and which maximises freedom of choice for retirees. This legislation before us at the moment penalises and punishes many of those people who want to save and achieve retirement security.
Debate (on motion by Dr Charlesworth) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.00 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill-by leave-presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I bring before the House a Bill to enact a number of changes to improve a range of human services provided through the community services and health portfolio. The most significant changes involve the implementation of the first stage of the new general practitioner (GP) fees package as agreed between the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP), and new private health insurance arrangements with are designed to maximise the security and protection of the insured aged.

The new GP arrangements are the most far reaching advances which have ever been achieved in general practice in this country and are consistent with advances occurring in many similar Western nations. The new arrangements will promote better quality patient care, resulting in improved treatment and assessment outcomes through the provision of incentives to GPs to take part in continuing medical education and quality assurance programs. Private health insurance arrangements are to be changed to protect the elderly and share the insurance risk of Australia's ageing population fairly among all private health insurance funds. The changes will lead to increased stability within the private health sector, advantaging the majority of health fund contributors in the short term and the entire private health care industry in the longer term.

The Bill also proposes strengthening of the confidentiality provisions of the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987. It introduces a new pathology services table and changes the arrangements for future alterations to the table. The Bill establishes a Private Health Insurance Administration Council to take over many of the health insurance functions currently performed by the Department of Community Services and Health. It introduces new health benefit arrangements to encourage greater use of day surgery, and establishes differential day only benefits based on the different types of treatments provided.

A further amendment will enable an independent person or body to apply for the classification of residents in nursing homes where the proprietor has frequently misclassified residents. The Bill provides for transitional funding arrangements for 38 nursing homes for disabled persons still covered under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 until that Act ceases to operate after 30 June 1992. Finally, there is a minor amendment in relation to the transfer of nurse education to the higher education sector and the dates of collection of higher education census data.

Part 2 of the Bill provides for amendments to the Australian Institute of Health Act 1987 to impose more stringent controls on release of information by the Institute, preventing the disclosure of information, other than to the Minister, contrary to the conditions under which it was supplied to the Institute. The amendments recognise the concerns of States and Territories to ensure adequate safeguards of confidentiality of data which may be supplied by States and Territories to the Institute. In particular, the minor amendment to paragraph 29 (4) (b), which ensures that an information provider includes a State or Territory as a body politic and, therefore, gives that State or Territory power to set terms and conditions for the release or publication of the information it provided to the Institute, represents an agreed response to these concerns.

The amendments in part 3 of the Bill relate to an agreement between the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners on a package of measures designed to improve the quality and cost effectiveness of medical services provided by general practitioners. The package provides a number of interrelated measures to provide incentives for general practitioners to strive to improve the quality of care. These measures are: a vocational register of general practitioners; the requirement that for general practitioners to remain on the register they undertake continuing medical education and quality assurance programs accredited by the RACGP; the introduction of new items into the Medicare benefits schedule for consultations by vocationally registered general practitioners; the new items to attract higher fees than those currently available to general practitioners and to be generally based on both complexity of the service provided and the time taken; and the introduction of improved audit and monitoring arrangements, involving an independent professional organisation, for services provided by vocationally registered general practitioners, which will extend to examining, referral and prescribing patterns and the ordering of diagnostic tests.

This Bill makes provision for the establishment of the vocational register which will enable the new items to be introduced from 1 August 1989 by regulations. Existing items for general practitioner services will remain for use by other doctors providing primary medical care. The Government intends to introduce further legislation in the Budget session to permit the establishment of the improved audit and monitoring arrangements.

The proposed register will be maintained by the Health Insurance Commission. The Bill provides that the Commission shall register a medical practitioner who has been certified by the RACGP-or other body as determined by the Minister-as practising predominantly in general practice and as having appropriate training and experience in general practice or who is otherwise eligible in accordance with the regulations. Enrolment on the register will be voluntary.

In assessing a practitioner's medical practice, the RACGP will have regard to whether the practitioner provides a comprehensive primary medical service, including treating a wide range of patients and conditions using a variety of accepted medical skills and techniques, providing services away from the practitioner's surgery on request-for example, home visits-and making appropriate provision for the practitioner's patients to have access to after hours medical care.

The Government has accepted that fellowship of the RACGP, or an equivalent postgraduate qualification in general practice, should ultimately be the only experience and training which make it appropriate for a practitioner to be placed on the vocational register. This will apply from 1995. However, to protect doctors already engaged in general practice, other qualifications and training will be accepted in the meantime, including membership of the RACGP, a certificate of satisfactory completion of the family medicine program, or five years experience in general practice. This will ensure that doctors who are currently in practice will be able to qualify for vocational registration on the basis of experience before the tighter requirement comes into effect in 1995.

I want to stress that any medical practitioner whose practice has been predominantly in general practice as defined for five years-whether full time or part time-will be eligible. The RACGP has defined part time practice as a minimum of two sessions a week, which I regard as a generous provision.

I am concerned that the Australian Medical Association (AMA) has been involved in a campaign of misinformation, with its claims that part time GPs, the majority of whom are women, will not be eligible to register, when a simple inquiry would have revealed that this was patently false. Likewise, doctors who work in sports medicine, student health clinics, women's health clinics, and family planning clinics-other areas targeted by the AMA-will be assessed on an individual basis against the eligibility criteria. It has been the aim of the Government and the RACGP to include as many GPs as possible within the eligibility criteria-not to exclude them.

I also take issue with the AMA's attempts to depict the new arrangements as in some way discriminating or disadvantaging those doctors who are found to be ineligible. Rather, the reverse is true in that the arrangements will reward those GPs who are prepared to improve their skills by taking part in continuing medical education and quality assurance programs. Certainly not all doctors will be eligible, but neither should they be if they are not prepared to meet those requirements. What the Government and the RACGP are in effect seeking are changes in work practices which result in increased productivity in general practice through an improvement in the quality of patient care. The Bill also makes provision for a doctor's name to be removed from the register in certain circumstances.

The proposals provide an active role for the relevant professional body, the RACGP, in ensuring the quality of general practice in Australia. It conforms with the role of other specialist medical colleges as the arbiters of professional standards in this country.

The RACGP will provide a review mechanism for its decisions relating to vocational registration, including independent arbitration, to ensure that its assessment processes are fair for all doctors. An independent arbitrator who is acceptable to both the aggrieved doctor and the RACGP will perform this function. Should such processes present difficulties, there are provisions in the Bill to enable registration to be done by other means and another body to be substituted for the RACGP.

The Bill also provides for the general public to be able to find out from the commission the names of medical practitioners on the register and for the Commission to make information about the register available to the RACGP. These provisions will assist the public to make informed choices about medical care and will facilitate the RACGP's role in registration and removal from registration. The Government and the RACGP are jointly developing a program to better educate and inform the medical profession and the public about the new arrangements.

Taken together with the proposal for monitoring arrangements, these proposals will create a climate for improved patient care at the primary level, a more professional approach to general practice, and improved public accountability for the $1.4 billion in Medicare benefits which go to underwriting the costs of general practitioners' services.

In the longer term, the Government expects general practitioners to be more willing to care for more complex conditions within their competence and to be more discriminating in their use of specialist referrals, prescribing and diagnostic tests. This should lead to reduced costs in the secondary and tertiary sectors and overall a much more effective use of health resources. I am confident that this package will have the overwhelming support of the majority of general practitioners, and of the community in general.

Part 3 of the Bill also includes new provisions for variations and alterations to the pathology services table. As a result of findings of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts report No. 236, entitled Medical Fraud and Overservicing-Pathology, a new statutory body-the Pathology Services Advisory Committee (PSAC)-was created to review pathology items and fee levels and related matters and to make recommendations to the Minister for Community Services and Health on such matters. The framework of PSAC was designed to bring about a more appropriate level of financing of pathology services which would adequately compensate the industry, while at the same time removing the potential which had been identified by the PAC report for abuse and overservicing. PSAC made its first recommendation, which the Government accepted, for an increase in fees of 6.62 per cent to all pathology services, to take effect from 1 December 1987. In July 1988, PSAC recommended a new pathology services table (PST) aimed at rectifying most of the major concerns raised by the Public Accounts Committee. This new table came into effect on 1 November 1988. However, following a challenge in the Federal Court, the new table was ruled to be void and benefits reverted to the 1 December 1987 PST.

I should stress that the Federal Court ruling on the November 1988 table was not made on any inherent structural deficiency in the pathology table put on the basis that PSAC, in making its recommendation, had not followed parts of the principles determined for the performance of its functions. Subsequent legal opinion was that PSAC's previous recommendations to me were also void, because PSAC had followed a similar approach in regard to the principles that had applied to the 1988 table. Payment of Medicare benefits for pathology services therefore had to revert to the table in effect prior to PSAC's establishment, that is, the August 1986 pathology table. This table against which Medicare benefits are currently being paid has all the deficiencies identified by the Public Accounts Committee.

Late in 1988, the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia (RCPA) withdrew its nominees from PSAC, rendering the Committee inoperative. In effect, under the existing legislation, this means that the pathology table cannot be amended. The Government therefore has no option but to introduce this amending legislation so the pathology table can be varied when necessary. This legislation proposes that those provisions in the Health Insurance Act relating to the pathology services table and PSAC mechanisms be repealed and replaced with a structure which allows the Minister for Community Services and Health to determine an appropriate table which is then prescribed by regulation. This is a similar mechanism which is in place, and has been in place for many years, in respect of the general medical services table. The new table is based broadly on the 1988 table recommended by PSAC, but with modifications to reflect some of the concerns raised by the profession. While it simplifies the existing table, taking into account advances in technology which have occurred since the last major restructuring of the pathology services table in 1977, and reduces the overall number of items, it also eases some of the restrictions contained in the 1988 table in relation to the availability of some tests. The Government is confident that the new table will promote good medical practice and reduce the potential for abuses, and believes it essential for it to be put in place to allow for a more appropriate level of Medicare benefits for patients compared to the existing table.

I would like to place on record my appreciation of the considerable input made by the pathology industry through the Australian Association of Pathology Practices (AAPP) in the development of the new PST which is appended to the draft Bill. AAPP gave freely of its time and expertise throughout this process and I am pleased that agreement has been reached on the structure of the new table and the description of individual items within it. I am confident that the continuation of this consultative process in relation to matters concerning the pathology services table will be of benefit to Government, pathologists and patients.

Part 4 of the Bill seeks to make two main changes which affect people with private health insurance, firstly, in relation to revised reinsurance arrangements which will commence from 1 June 1989 and, secondly, in relation to the establishment and functions of the Private Health Insurance Administration Council. The reinsurance account arrangements form an integral part of community rating, which has always applied to the health insurance arrangements in Australia and has an important social welfare role. This principle provides that all people are treated equally for health insurance purposes, regardless of age, medical history or family size. The alternative is a risk rated system where the young and healthy would pay lower premiums but the aged, the chronically ill and people with large families would find the cost of insurance prohibitive. They would pay far more than they do currently. The reinsurance arrangements provide a mechanism for part of the benefits liability for heavy claiming contributors to be shared between funds on an equitable basis. The current system, which has remained largely unchanged since 1978, involves sharing the benefits liability at the basic table rate for any days in excess of 35 per contributor unit in a 12 month period. The effect of this system is that funds with a higher than average reinsurance claims experience are subsidised by funds with a lower than average experience.

As a result of concerns that the current arrangements were not adequately reflecting the varying experience of funds with a disproportionate share of heavy drawing contributors, a detailed review was conducted. That review showed that benefits paid out to the 65 and over age group amounted to about one-third of total hospital benefits, although the group represented only about 15 per cent of the total insured population. Moreover, there was a significant disparity between funds in the liability for these benefits, some 70 per cent of which related to hospitalisation under 35 days in a year and were thus not included in the current reinsurance arrangements. It also became apparent that total hospital experience, as opposed to basic table only, would be a more appropriate basis for reinsurance as some 83 per cent of all those insured have supplementary cover. In addition, basic table cover is being increasingly aligned with public hospital experience and thus increasingly is out of step with benefits paid for private hospital services.

After extensive consultation with the private health care sector, preference was given to a reinsurance system that covered the total hospital experience of the 65 and over age group as well as total hospital experience over 35 days for the under 65s. The proposed new arrangements therefore provide a much fairer basis for reinsurance and specifically recognise those people, that is, the aged and chronically ill, who are the heaviest users of hospital services. These changes will provide greatest assistance to those long established non-profit funds with a disproportionately high share of aged and chronically ill members. Where possible, the Government will be looking to those funds to reduce their contribution rates or forgo planned future increases. Some funds, particularly the small new for-profit funds and the closed funds with restricted membership, and which have a better than average claims experience related to age profile, will, of course, face an increased liability, which is the very nature of reinsurance.

Many of these funds have enjoyed a privileged position within the health insurance market, either because they are relatively new or because they have been able to be more selective of their members. The Government has decided that this unfair competitive advantage should not be maintained at the expense of the majority of contributors and that there should be a more even playing field between funds. The extent to which these changes will need to be reflected in contribution rates will vary from fund to fund, depending on factors such as the profitability of current contribution rates and the level of accumulated reserves. Many of those funds with an increased liability already possess substantial reserves.

As well, the Government will be making a one-off contribution to reinsurance of $20m this financial year to minimise the effect of the new arrangements. This money will be disbursed over the next eighteen months to December 1990 so as to cushion the impact of the reinsurance changes on those funds most heavily affected. Apart from this one-off contribution, there will be no further Commonwealth contribution to reinsurance. This combination of factors will mean that any increases in contribution rates as a direct cause of the new arrangements will be minimal. It should be noted that, although the changes will increase the reinsurance pool from $200m to more than $600m a year, this will result in a redistribution of only an estimated $70m, as compared to $29m under the current arrangements. This represents less than 5 per cent out of total hospital benefits of $1.54 billion. Thus, while these new arrangements will provide for a greater sharing of risk and therefore greater stability within the industry, there will still be ample scope for competition and cost efficiency.

As a further incentive for funds to seek to expand their memberships, newly insured members-not including those who transfer between funds-will be excluded from the reinsurance count for the first year of their membership, although their claims will be included in the reinsurance pool assessments. The new arrangements remove the disincentive to insure people aged over 65. They also provide a positive incentive for funds to offer better supplementary benefits and therefore will encourage the use of private hospitals-a fact which the Australian Private Hospitals Association attempts to gloss over. The supplementary benefits, which will be acceptable for reinsurance purposes, will be defined by ministerial determination. By providing for a greater sharing between health funds of the cost of caring for the aged and the chronically ill, the Government is underwriting its commitment to community rating-a commitment which to date has been shared by those opposite and which I would hope they would continue to share, as community rating works to the benefit of the aged, the chronically ill, and large families.

Much needless anxiety has been generated in recent times by hysterical claims about a supposed crisis in the private health care industry, yet an analysis of the facts shows that this is simply not the case. Over the past four years, the private health sector has remained relatively stable, with only small variations overall in both the levels of private health insurance coverage and in private hospital utilisation. Indeed, despite what some prophets of doom have claimed, the number of people with private hospital cover has grown by more than one million in that period. I have always maintained that Medicare's continued success and high popularity is dependent upon the maintenance of a strong, viable private health care sector. The Government recognises that there are particular pressure points within the private health care market and indeed these changes are designed to alleviate some of those pressures. However, they are not intended to solve every problem besetting the private health care market as some would wish. It is not the Government's responsibility to maintain the viability of every private hospital bed in Australia. That would simply better sustain an inefficient private system at public expense. Nor is it the Government's responsibility to compel or encourage people to take out private health insurance. Under Medicare, all Australians are covered for essential medical and hospital treatment and then have the freedom to choose whether to take out additional private cover.

With this initiative, the Government is ensuring increased stability for health fund contributors and a more even playing field for the private health funds-it is now up to the private health funds, private hospitals, and private doctors to make the private health care market work. For example, if private funds and private hospitals cannot agree to closely align their charges and benefits, and if private hospitals will not observe the step down periods, so that patients are left substantially out of pocket even after paying top table insurance, then quite naturally they will question whether they should retain their private cover or go to private hospitals. But these are problems which only the industry can resolve.

This Bill also provides for the devolution to an industry body of certain private health insurance functions currently carried out by the Department of Community Services and Health. This proposal accords with the Government's Budget strategy to reduce the size of the public sector and its policy of reducing the degree of regulation in the private sector. The industry body is to be known as the Private Health Insurance Administration Council. It will be under the control of an independent Commissioner, who shall have four advisers-three representing the health insurance industry with the remaining adviser also being independent. Members of the Council will be appointed in accordance with guidelines which will be developed in consultation with the industry.
The main functions of the Council will be to:
administer the reinsurance arrangements;
monitor the financial performance of health funds to ensure viability and to make recommendations as to the action to be taken where a fund's experience declines;
collect and disseminate financial and statistical data, including an annual report for tabling in Parliament, on health funds' operations; and
administer the funding arrangements for the operation of acute care advisory committees.

The Bill proposes to allow individuals to seek an injunction from the Federal Court against an organisation that appears to be acting in breach of section 67 of the National Health Act. This section was primarily designed to ensure that health insurance business could only be offered by registered health benefits organisations in accordance with community rating. Section 67 has, in the interpretation of `health insurance business' versus `accident and sickness insurance business', generated a substantial number of legal challenges which have proven to be both complex and time consuming. Departmental resources will no longer be available to be devoted to the resolution of these disputes.

The Bill also provides that organisations may register as a health benefits organisation on a national basis rather than a State basis as at present. However, organisations will still need to conduct a separate fund for each State in which they have approval to operate. Also, they will still need to seek approval to transfer reserves between States as a safeguard against predatory pricing to increase their membership size. The repeal of section 73baa of the National Health Act which controls diversification activities by registered organisations is merely in keeping with decreasing unnecessary regulation. The Bill also provides for tighter solvency requirements for health funds, similar to the requirements for general insurers provided under the Insurance Act.

Organisations will be required, nationally, to maintain the greater part of $1m-with provision to prescribe a higher amount to maintain monetary value because of the effect of inflation-or two months contribution income. Provision is included to exempt funds from this requirement-for example, for small funds which would have to cease business if forced to carry reserves of $1m. Where exemptions are sought by existing organisations, they will need to produce satisfactory actuarial and other evidence to demonstrate their viability. No exemption will apply, however, to a new organisation seeking registration. These more stringent requirements are considered imperative as a safeguard against a fund collapsing, particularly in this increasingly `de-regulated' environment. However, in the unlikely event of a collapse, two measures are proposed to protect the interests of contributors.

Firstly, the Private Health Insurance Administration Council will be empowered to impose a levy on health funds for the purposes of meeting any outstanding claims for benefits of the collapsed fund. Secondly, the Bill proposes an expansion of a condition of registration on funds to accept former contributors of a collapsed fund with full continuity of benefits entitlements. The changes proposed to section 78 of the National Health Act are designed to simplify the processing of changes in health fund rules and complement the reduction in departmental staff resources.

The purpose of the changes in clause 48 of the Bill is to facilitate mergers between registered health benefits organisations located in different States. Currently, mergers can take place only between organisations in the same State. This amendment is consistent with that contained in clause 28 to provide for national registration of organisations. Clause 51 makes provision to prescribe by national health regulation a specific modification to the operation of the basic private table. The purpose of this amendment is to allow for a health fund to seek ministerial approval for self-funded pilot or demonstration schemes to advance private health insurance. As part of the devolution process, provision is made for a rationalisation of the acute care advisory committee review process and hands over responsibility for the administration and financing of the process to the Private Health Insurance Administration Council.
