However, the purpose of the review process, namely to adjudicate on whether certain long term patients in hospitals are acute care patients or nursing home type patients, remains unaffected, as will the medical basis for that adjudication.

Clause 17 is designed to close a loophole whereby `gap' type medical benefits can be paid when not related to the actual loss sustained in meeting medical expenses. This practice is contrary to the Government's policy of prohibiting certain medical insurance, as intended by section 126 of the Health Insurance Act. In clauses 20, 21 and 22, changes are proposed to remove anomalies in the current day hospital arrangements, as well as to encourage day-only admissions in lieu of overnight in-patient hospital stays, for a range of surgical operations and medical procedures.

Overseas experience suggests that up to 40 per cent of surgical procedures can be safely undertaken on a day-only basis. The amendments proposed should ultimately achieve a similar result for Australia, which will:
be more convenient for patients;
assist in reducing public hospital waiting times;
reduce hospital costs; and
contain health fund premiums.

The proposals allow for the identification of a range of largely surgical procedures considered suitable for day-only admissions to either hospitals or licensed free-standing day surgery centres. These procedures will, where the patient is privately insured, qualify for a day-only basic table benefit rather than a full in-patient hospital benefit unless the patient's doctor certifies that an overnight admission was warranted because of medical, social or environmental reasons.

As an adjunct, in recognition of the varying levels of complexity of procedures which can be carried out on a day-only basis, a grouping of the procedures will be undertaken to which a differential scale of basic insurance benefits will apply. The present arrangement of a flat rate benefit does not recognise the differing costs and complexities of individual procedures. These changes are designed further to promote day surgery in line with the special funding being provided to the States and Territories under the new Medicare agreement incentive package arrangements which provide specific grants for the development and improvement of day surgery in the public hospital system.

The Bill also amends the National Health Act to introduce provisions designed to prevent abuse of the resident classification system in nursing homes. Under current arrangements nursing home proprietors are able to abuse the resident classification system by providing information leading to the classification of residents at unjustifiable levels, thereby obtaining excess benefits. These amendments enable the Secretary of the Department of Community Services and Health to determine that an independent person or body should apply for the classification of residents in cases of flagrant and frequently provided inaccurate information leading to the classification of residents at levels which have not been sustained at review. A nursing home proprietor will have the right to request a review by the Minister of the Secretary's determination.

The Bill also facilitates the phased transfer of all nursing homes for disabled persons from the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 to the Disability Services Act 1986, which provides access for people with disabilities to a more appropriate and extensive range of services. Honourable members would be aware that all aged persons nursing homes previously covered by the Nursing Homes Assistance Act have been transferred to the National Health Act. The Nursing Homes Assistance Act now covers only 38 nursing homes for disabled persons, with the further 20 nursing homes for disabled persons covered by the National Health Act.

It is the Government's intention that all nursing homes for disabled persons should be brought under the Disability Services Act by 30 June 1992. All of these homes were advised of this in May 1988. Eight have transferred and a number of others have indicated their intention of doing so. The nursing homes have also been advised that, once they transfer under the Disability Services Act, additional funding, as necessary, will be made available to enable them to deliver a less restrictive range of services to people with disabilities.

Consistent with the Government's view that the nursing home model does not provide the most appropriate, least restrictive, accommodation for people with disabilities, the Bill introduces a sunset clause to the Nursing Homes Assistance Act to provide that the Act will cease to operate after 30 June 1992 and provides that no approvals will be given for new nursing homes under this Act. This brings services funded under the Act in line with those services formerly funded under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974, which are already required to have transferred to section 10 status under the Disability Services Act by that date.

The Bill also amends the definition of `nursing home care' by including a specific reference to `personal care' which is defined as `assistance of a personal nature given to help a person attend to his or her daily needs or carry out his or her daily routine'. This recognises that many people with disabilities are in nursing homes because they have high personal care needs, not because they require the medical model of nursing care provided in such homes.

The Bill also seeks to establish an indexed upper limit on the level of funding that can be provided to nursing homes that choose to remain under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act. The Bill therefore provides for the continuation of the previous deficit financing arrangements, with the proviso that the level of ordinary expenditure per occupied bed in 1988-89 can be increased only in accordance with an approved level of indexation.

Finally, the proposed simple amendment to the States Grants (Nurse Education Transfer Assistance) Act 1985 is consequent upon a change introduced by the Department of Employment, Education and Training to collect census data on students enrolled in higher education courses on 31 March and 31 August rather than 30 April and 30 September. The census data is used to check, for payments purposes, that the planned numbers of students are actually enrolled. Any future amendments to the key dates for collection, or other matters required or permitted by the Act to be prescribed, may be made by regulation of the Governor-General.
Financial Impact Statement

The amendments to the Australian Institute of Health Act have no financial impact on government outlays. The financial impact of the new GP fee arrangements will be announced separately as part of the Government's statement on Medicare fee increases for 1989-90. The revised pathology services table arrangements will result in a saving of $45m on the Forward Estimates for 1989-90 and 1990-91.

The Government will be providing a one-off payment of $20m to the Reinsurance Trust Fund in this financial year but will remove its $1m annual contribution from 1989-90. The effect on the consumer price index of the full impact of the reinsurance changes as reflected in contribution rates will be nil. An amount of $300,000 will be provided over three years to assist with the establishment costs of the Private Health Insurance Administration Council. All other expenses will be borne by the industry, with the Council having the power to impose levies to meet the costs.

The amendments to the Nursing Homes Assistance Act are expected to provide moderate savings in the order of $1m a year, although this will be offset by the requirement for additional funds to assist nursing homes for disabled persons to make the transition to the models of service delivery required under the Disability Services Act. I now present the explanatory memorandum for this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shack) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 6) 1988[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988INCOME TAX (FUND CONTRIBUTIONS) BILL 1988INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1989INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) and cognate Bills give effect to the May 1988 economic statement on superannuation tax reform. It has been introduced in two stages. The first, in November last year, legislated for the introduction of a 15 per cent tax on superannuation contributions and earnings. The second, which was introduced last week, provides for compensating reduction in the tax rates on end benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been three speakers in the debate so far. I suppose the most interesting speech was that of the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) who, in a somewhat tortuous treatise, started attacking the assets test and the incomes test. He put the view very strongly that we should revert to the situation that previously existed where millionaires and anybody else could be in receipt of the pension. I doubt very much that this will be part of the new Peacock economic push but, as with the Foreign Investment Review Board, the honourable member for Sturt seems to be slightly out of step there with the rest of his Party. He suggested that there should be a universal benefit of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and, beyond that, choice for those who wished to supplement their retirement income with further superannuation. He did not suggest for a moment how it should be set up or how people could be conscripted to such a scheme. Indeed, the whole idea seemed rather anachronistic.

The honourable member for Sturt did say that many opportunities have been missed by this Government. When one looks at the history of this Government, one finds that rather absurd comment particularly galling. When the Hawke Government come into office after 30 years out of 33 of conservative rule in this country, what sort of retirement income policy did we have? We found ourselves with a massive deficit of $10 billion in the domestic framework and a tax framework which was structured like a piece of Swiss cheese. One could drive holes through the tax system in all sorts of areas. Indeed, in the area of superannuation, there were fantastic concessions available to those who were able to take advantage of them, particularly those who were very fortunate. Only four in 10 Australians had access to superannuation at that time. Indeed, it was a lamentable picture.

So we set about rectifying the tax system. As part of that rectification of the tax system, we introduced a lump sum tax on superannuation benefits. That was a very difficult decision for the Government to make. It is never a popular thing to do. But it was part of a whole structure that made the tax system fairer. We looked at introducing the fringe benefits tax, clamped down on entertainment expenses and tax rorts that were involved there, and introduced the prescribed payments tax and the capital gains tax to remove many of the distortions which existed in the system. Not only did we do that, but also we improved incentive for people. The top rate of tax by the end of this year will be 47c in the dollar, whereas previously it had been 60c in the dollar. The bottom rate for those in that framework will now be 21c in the dollar whereas previously it was 29c or 30c in the dollar. We introduced the tax file number system and we introduced substantiation and self-assessment. Very significantly, business imputation removed the double taxation on dividends and distortions in investment. It is this element that gave effect to the moves that we are able to make towards superannuation in this legislation. Fully franked dividends of the superannuation funds will be available to balance against the tax on contributions and earnings that allows these new initiatives to function.

If honourable members do not believe what I say about tax and the inequities and the lethargy of the previous government, I might mention something that occurred earlier this week. I am a member of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which was privileged to have before it Mr Mark Liebler, senior partner in the legal firm of Arnold, Bloch, Liebler and Deputy Chairman of the Taxation Committee of the Law Council of Australia. We asked Mr Liebler about the sorts of practices which were involved and the sorts of practices that tax planners became involved with in the late 1970s and 1980s. He said, unequivocally, that the reason that many tax planners got involved in paper schemes and bottom of the harbour schemes was that the Liberal Government of the day was tardy in its action against those schemes and, indeed, the Commissioner of Taxation and the Government at the time allowed those things to occur. So honourable members do not have to take my word for it. What we inherited was a tax structure which was unfair and inefficient and through which one could figuratively, drive a truck when one looks at the number of opportunities there were for people to take advantage of the scheme.

When we talk about superannuation-and principally that is what this legislation is about-we talk about ordinary people being able to save enough money for retirement. We talk about people being able to earn sufficient so that they are better off than on the pension. Some will be able to accrue only a small amount over a period, but others will take the choice and have the opportunity to accrue larger amounts for their retirement and will provide themselves with an opportunity to be comfortable in that retirement. Unlike the Opposition, we have done something about it. The record speaks for itself. There are two statistics which stand out. When we came into government four out of 10 Australian workers had access to and were involved in superannuation schemes. Now, five years later, eight out of 10 Australians are in that position. There has been a doubling of the number of Australian workers who have access to superannuation and thereby are able to plan for their retirement.

The second very significant figure is that, if one looks at total assets of superannuation funds, one finds that five years ago there was $25 billion and that there has been a significant increase to $80 billion now-more than a two-fold increase. It is hard to suggest, as the Opposition does, that the moves that this Government has made, the legislation it has introduced, is in some way anti-retirement income and in some way anti-superannuation. The whole tax system is fairer. We have closed off those areas where there was leakage and we have provided incentives for those people who were in a position to take advantage of long term benefits.

The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who led the debate for the Opposition, was correct when he said that Australia's population is becoming older. Indeed, it is necessary for us to plan for the ageing of our population. It is necessary for people in that situation to plan for their own self-reliance, security and independence during that time. That is what we have done, and that is what this legislation gives effect to. There was a massive haemorrhaging of revenue previously through superannuation concessions. That has been brought under control whilst still allowing an incentive for people to take advantage of the concessions available.

What argument did the Opposition produce? The honourable member for Bradfield said that there were two principle concerns that the Opposition thought were the principle reasons why it should oppose this legislation. The first was that in fact within the structure of this legislation-I admit that it is a complicated piece of legislation-there would be many people who would find that their end benefits were affected. In the May 1988 statement the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that there would be many whose end benefits would increase, but none who would be disadvantaged by these moves.

The honourable member for Bradfield suggested that hundreds of thousands of Australians would find themselves in that position. I have looked very closely at it, and it appears that theoretically it is possible that some people may find their end benefits affected, but it would take unusually bad management of the fund and a refusal on the part of the management of the fund to take action as to what is the most appropriate investment course. Indeed, it would mean that the managers of that fund would have to refuse to take advantage of fully franked dividends from investments in Australian companies, which is something we are trying to encourage. There are some very wealthy people who, because of the tightening of the maximum end benefit limits, will be affected by this legislation. But is the Opposition arguing on behalf of a handful of very wealthy people-I am talking about the people who would receive benefits of about half a million dollars and more-because we have not heard any screams for them? Those are the people who are best able to look after themselves in their retirement.

Those of us who work here knew about these changes. There was a great deal of speculation before May 1988 and an intensive amount of lobbying from the superannuation industry, because it was very concerned that the changes that may be made-there was a great deal of speculation about the changes-would affect the industry and would be a disincentive for people to get involved in superannuation. What have we found since then? Since the May statement we have found a stoney silence from the superannuation industry. The Life Insurance Federation of Australia wants this legislation passed. The life insurance industry in Australia got on with business, it got involved with selling more business and it has found that its business has continued to grow. Yet we hear hysterical bleating from the Opposition that hundreds of thousands of Australians will be affected. The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), who is sitting in the chair, I am sure like me would have been plagued by constituents if hundreds of thousands of Australians were to be affected by this legislation, but that is not the case. We are not hearing this from our constituents or from the life insurance industry, so where is this mythology coming from? It seems it has been conceived in the mind of the honourable member for Bradfield.

The second point he made was that these legislative changes encapsulated in the May statement would in some way provide disincentive for superannuation savings and for people to be involved. I have already given the statistics. We have seen an increase from four in 10 Australians to eight in 10 involved in investment. The total assets of the superannuation industry were $25 billion in 1983 and they are now $80 billion. In desperation he said-I suppose this is a Malcolm Fraser type comment, and we all remember the comment in 1983 about the money under the bed-people would be better off to spend their money elsewhere. It is a very stupid comment to make, because it is the sort of thing that the Opposition does time and time again, trying to frighten people away from what is a very sensible form of investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The old scare tactics.

—The old scare tactics. The members of the Opposition are spoilers from way back, and they always have been. It is just misleading and irresponsible to say things like that. One industry that I have followed for the last five years is the restaurant and entertainment industry. There are a large number of restaurant owners in my electorate in the inner suburbs of Perth. So when we introduced the entertainment tax changes years ago, I was very interested in the impact that they would have on the restaurant industry. I remember hearing the former honourable member for Denison saying in here that 80,000 jobs would be lost in the restaurant industry because of this tax.
—No wonder he lost his seat.

—Yes, he lost his seat to a very good member from this side of the House. He changed that figure after a week and came down to 10,000 jobs being lost. Yesterday I asked the statistics group in Parliament House to find out what the figures were. We find that in the last five years of the Fraser Government, there was an increase in employment of 13,000 in the restaurant, hotel and club industry. In the last five years of our Government, there has been an increase of 74,000, four or five times the record. While gloom, doom and spoiling was the name of the game when it came to the introduction of those changes, we find that once again the spoiling tactics of the Opposition were all that it was left with, because it did not have a structure or a policy. All it is left with is spoiling.

SPEECH.PARA: The new legislation maintains substantial concessions for people, but it keeps the cost to government within affordable limits. We have had two days of the new regime of the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and we want to hear about his policies. He has been sitting there for a long time spoiling, trying to destroy, but we want to know about policies, because we think the Leader of the Opposition is all froth and bubble. Honourable members do not have to take my word for it. The Australian Financial Review of Wednesday, 10 May said:

As Shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock was a lamentable failure, making virtually no impact on the development of economic debate in an atmosphere where the Government was itself struggling. The coalition needs to lift its economic game from the second division, where it is currently wallowing.

Indeed the second division is about where it is at the moment, I do not think there is any question about that. It is no good the Opposition coming in here and bleating about interest rates day after day if it does not have a solution or a policy that can change them. To bleat about interest rates is ridiculous. Again, if we look at the economic statistics in the Economic Round-up of the Treasury of April 1989, we see that the 90-day bill rate was 17.5 per cent. No government wants interest rates at that level. But if we look at June 1982, the interest rate was 18.7 per cent. We find that it is all froth and bubble on the other side, lots of spoiling but no substance.

This legislation improves the efficiency of the dividend imputation system and it reduces tax avoidance opportunities. It increases the spread of superannuation without an unsustainable Budget cost, and it allows for the tax cuts that we were able to deliver on 1 July and which we will deliver on 1 January of the new year. It reduces the unequal tax treatment for employer and employee contributions, and it increases the incentives for employees to make contributions to superannuation for their retirement. It is consistent with the long term philosophy that this Government has. It is economically sound and it is socially appropriate. I object to, and reject, the Opposition's amendment. I wholeheartedly support this legislation and hope that it passes the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in speaking tonight to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) and cognate Bills. As honourable members know, 5 amendments will be moved, which I will support and which apparently the Government will not accept. It is very important for our side of politics that the Government accept this amendment, because we feel it will help this package of six cognate Bills that has been introduced. Most of the income tax levy Bills are about the Government increasing taxation on Australians, which it has done consistently since it came to office in the early 1980s.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only have honourable members talked about increases of taxation tonight, but the previous speaker, the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), talked about the level of interest rates we are suffering from. Admittedly the bank bills were running at 18 per cent, but for how long? It was about two months. Under this Labor Government we have been paying an interest rate of over 15 per cent for the last three years.

When the Government came to power the debt owing for overseas borrowings was about $25 billion. Under this Government and other governments throughout Australia we now have a debt of $125 billion. These characters opposite have seen fit to prop up their own Government to the tune of $100 billion in the last two terms in which they have been in office. These are the sorts of problems faced by this nation. Not only that, the Government is desperate for more income tax to continue to prop up the standard of living of those who need so-called social justice. Unfortunately, the middle and upper income people continue to be shocked by the taxes imposed by this Government.

We have an horrific balance of payments problem. It is amazing that when the Liberal Party was in government under Menzies and Fraser it ran a terrific surplus of trade. Our standard of living continued to rise, we were all living well and we did not need the sort of tax regime that these characters have put in place. Now we see them running up anything up to $2 billion a month in debt. As a farmer I know all about the debts we have to pay. I am struggling to pay the 18 per cent and 20 per cent interest rates to balance the Government's books. The situation these blokes have put us in is absolutely ridiculous. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), does not do a bad job for the veterans, but I would like to have a go at the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about the sort of tax regime that he has put in place. Anything that moves is taxed these days. Superannuation is taxed to death.

Who is doing all the work for the Treasury? The Treasurer says that he has not had to increase the number of public servants. Of course he has not because the employer has been asked to make all these new tax arrangements. To help the so-called worker, a new superannuation package has been introduced. Who pays for it? Who does all the pencil and book work? It is not the worker; it is the employer who has to do it all. This is foisted upon him. He has to fill out all these forms every month. These days, the poor farmer I represent spends half his week in the office working for the Treasury. That is what it amounts to.

There are all sorts of brand new taxation arrangements. These measures were introduced in the May statement last year. We have had one Budget and another statement increasing taxes since that time. Every time we get a statement in this House from the Treasurer another $1 billion worth of taxation is imposed upon us. These are the facts. I do not have to speak in broad terms about these matters. All that happens to the primary producer is that he loses the sort of help that is needed in the bush.

There is something in these Bills which I support, and that is the 150 per cent write-off for science endeavour for companies. They have to be registered to get this concession of 150 per cent for expenditure on research and development. That is something this country sadly lacks. I fully support this measure. In fact, I think it should be 200 per cent. However, I question why it should apply only to a registered company. Even a farmer in small business does experimental work for his fellow growers or for a department. They run trials on such things as increasing yields and finding ways to do jobs better. I think that those people should also be entitled to a tax deduction, not just big business.

The Government supports big business. To qualify for a tax deduction the company must be registered. For God's sake, it costs $100 per year just to register a company. If it is not registered, the Tax office will say that it cannot claim a deduction. A farmer might have spent thousands of dollars to increase the quality of wheat or he may have worked with one of the cattle counts on a research farm to increase the production of beef cattle or to increase the yield of wool to help our balance of payments. Farmers slave their guts out to try to get the Government out of the hole it has put us in. What sort of help do they get when it comes to taxation arrangements? None at all! They have all been abolished. There is hardly one left.

There has also been an increase in the tax free self-employment scheme for superannuation, which I support. In fact, it ought to be higher. I believe that members should be able to transfer their previous superannuation entitlements to the parliamentary superannuation scheme. When I became a member of this House I belonged to a self-employed superannuation scheme. If a State member moves to a Federal House his State superannuation can be transferred to the Federal fund, but the money a member has been paying into a private scheme as a self-employed person cannot be transferred. I think that is a gross disadvantage. Why should a State member of parliament have the privilege of transferring superannuation, while any other dogsbody like myself who belongs to a self-employed scheme is not able to transfer to the Federal fund? I would like the Minister to look at this issue and see whether some changes can be made.

I thought it would be interesting tonight to look at the parliamentary superannuation scheme. I know that people do not like to talk about it because it is felt that we get too much. In fact, we do not. We probably used to but under this Labor Government the whole scheme has been taxed in half. There is hardly any superannuation left at the end of a member's term in parliament. I asked the Department of the House of Representatives to look up my entitlement. I am not ashamed to talk about it. If I were to drop dead tomorrow, I would be entitled to $87,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would we be so lucky.

—I would expect the honourable member to save me if I started to go pale; at least I trust him that far. If I completed the full four terms in the Parliament or 12 years and then retired, the rate of my superannuation would go up quite substantially. I would actually get $141,000. I would prefer to stick out this fourth term, which I happen to be in, so that I can get the extra benefit. I use this example because pre-1983-pre-Labor-we were charged 5 per cent tax on our lump sum superannuation payment. However, since 1983 the Government has introduced a new tax regime. Having come into the Parliament in 1980, for the entitlement that I would receive I would pay $1,500. It is to be remembered that all this income to be got from superannuation is to be added on to any other moneys earned during the year. If I happened to be retired I could be mowing lawns and earning $100 a week or chipping burrs for my neighbour and getting paid two bucks a day. That income must be added to the superannuation and then one of these horrific tax scales which Keating has imposed would be applied.

SPEECH.PARA: On top of that we are required to pay a 1.25 per cent health levy. These characters come in here and talk about reducing the scales. They do not tell you that the poor people of Australia have to continue to add on this extra health levy of 1.25 per cent. I wish to God they would start deregulating the health industry. The Government is in favour of deregulating the wheat industry and putting the poor farmer to the dogs, but it will not do anything about deregulating the health industry. The health industry is totally tied up, totally regulated and totally taxed. The community has to pay 1.25 per cent of its income. If a person earns a higher income, a percentage of that is paid. I probably pay for half a dozen people who are meant to be suffering from bad health. Most of the people on the lower scales do not pay anything.

It is interesting to run through these figures. Post-1983 the taxpayer is paying 31.25 per cent tax. On my retirement benefit I would pay $18,750. As I said, that figure is to be added to what I may earn. At that tax level I would pay 31.25 per cent tax. That is just for politicians. I think that we can use ourselves as the classic example of how the Labor Party has increased the superannuation tax regime. After one has completed four terms or 12 years in Parliament and one loses at the polls or retires, one is entitled to take only half of one's benefit in a lump sum and the other half must be taken in a pension. As I said, prior to 1983 we paid only 5 per cent tax; now we are paying 31.25 per cent tax.

There is another problem. If I leave voluntarily, although I would get $87,000 I would be entitled to only a $14,000 pension. The other thing about superannuation is that it pays to live to a reasonable age. Someone who is over 55 pays only 16 1/4 per cent on the first $60,000 of the retirement benefit lump sum. If he is under 55 he pays the iniquitous 31 1/4 per cent tax. Those figures are from the Department-straight from the horse's mouth. All I can suggest to honourable members is that they work for a full four terms of Parliament and live to 55. After that they can get out, still paying quite a deal of taxation but paying at the lesser rate. I would suggest that a lot of the young turks around the place who are under that age should stick around for a long while if they want to get any benefits for their pension. By the time they do get out they will be looking forward to some sort of entitlement. Also their wives will be entitled to their pensions once they pass on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite right too.

—I am sure they put up with more than we do, being members of parliament. I hope that the honourable member's husband gets some of her pension when she passes on. I am sure he will look forward to his pension. I am sure that he has had a tough time since the honourable member has been in the House. The maximum benefit in our scheme is payable after 18 years of service. After that, as a pensioner, we are entitled to 75 per cent of our salary. If we get beaten at the polls before we have served four terms-or 12 years- the benefit is calculated on three terms. So there is some advantage in being beaten, not that it would be all that exciting for that to happen on polling day.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that is being introduced is a capping on these arrangements. The Minister has not even got around to making an announcement on this capping proposition. It is not a benefit; it is another tax. The Government suggests that we cannot have too much superannuation. It is going to introduce a tax levy if we take ourselves beyond a certain level. We are waiting for the Minister to announce these changes. Although they are meant to come into operation on 1 July 1990, I am told that the scribes that be in the Department are still running around trying to work out what a fair and equitable cap will be, whatever that is. It means that if we want to have enough money left after paying tax to retire in some sort of comfort, we are going to be restricted by having to pay yet another tax rate on top of the existing rate.

We know that the 15 per cent tax has been introduced in respect of properly constituted funds. We can roll over our lump sum and have a fund invest it. People are now being asked to pay 15 per cent tax on their net earnings. This is just a case of more taxation in the system. I can never understand why the Government is not prepared to leave some money with the people for a change. They will do a better job than the Treasury will with the funds they have to invest in businesses. That is all I have to say in relation to this Bill. If the Government will not support our amendments, I guess we will oppose the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My heart bleeds for the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) after hearing his wonderful speech about the poverty of members of parliament and the inadequacies of their superannuation. I think he probably won the Government a few votes tonight by telling these people in the electorate that we have actually cut back on superannuation for members of parliament. There is not a lot of sympathy in the community for those of us who are fortunate enough to have a decent superannuation scheme, which undoubtedly we do have in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) gives effect to a number of superannuation tax reform measures announced in the May economic statement. It continues the reform of the tax system that the Labor Government has been carrying out since 1983. Amongst other things it also includes measures to repeal the special tax treatment of calculated liabilities of life insurance companies.

As this is a sizeable piece of legislation, I shall contain my remarks this evening to the superannuation changes, as have many of my colleagues. In this context I concur with the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) in his address, and also those made earlier in the debate by the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins). Contrary to some opinion expressed in the course of this debate, savings through superannuation will not be discouraged as a consequence of these measures. Their effect is not to increase the tax on superannuation, but to achieve a bring-forward of tax liability and achieve a fairer tax treatment of superannuation funds income by taxing investment income at 15 per cent and extending the imputation system to these institutions. The after tax benefits of fund members will be largely unaffected by the changes.

I draw the House's attention to an article by Barry Dunstan in the Australian Financial Review some time ago, on 3 June 1988, just after these arrangements were announced, in which he was discussing the unacceptable risks, as he put it, of minimising superannuation tax impact. There is no way that the Government is saying that funds have to undergo the imputation exercise. That is not the point; the point is that there is a way now for life insurance companies to minimise the tax on their funds if it is seen to be appropriate. They can go down that track if it is seen to be appropriate for their fund and not endanger the savings of people who have their money with them.

The taxation of superannuation will be placed on a more consistent and less costly basis as a consequence of the measures contained in this Bill. These reforms will establish sustainable long term arrangements which will enable individuals and the industry to plan and invest with certainty. This should encourage, not discourage, savings through superannuation. The fact is that despite the tax cuts, savings made through superannuation remain the subject of very considerable tax concessions even for those on the new lowest marginal tax rate of 21 per cent. Furthermore, the two reforms are quite separate and cannot properly be linked. For instance, low paid workers may receive far greater benefits relatively from superannuation than more highly paid workers simply because they do not have the same security of employment and are less likely to be able to save in other less compulsory ways. Benefits cannot always be equated with cash outcomes.

Some commentators have tended to overlook the tax deferral benefits available to superannuation savings. Superannuation benefits are only taxed at 15 per cent as they accrue and on retirement after the age of 55 the first $60,000, indexed to average weekly earnings, of the assessable post-1983 component of the benefit, as well as the person's own undeducted contributions will be tax free while that part in excess of the threshold will be taxed at 15 per cent. As benefits will be taxed as they accrue at rates well below the lowest marginal tax rate, this will provide even low rate taxpayers with substantial tax deferral benefits.

The argument about the desirability of superannuation as a savings mechanism for low paid workers seems to assume that they all currently have access to superannuation and that somehow a choice should be made between lowering the tax rate for such people and taxing superannuation contributions. Although more workers are now able to obtain the benefits of superannuation as a direct consequence of our Government's continuing endeavours in this area, many low paid workers are not yet in a position to access superannuation in their industries. Necessary reforms are still being negotiated to ensure that people such as regular part time employees are extended the opportunity of superannuation. We do not have to look past our own backdoors and our own employees to see that this is the case.

To emphasise this particular point, I would like to acquaint the House with an example of the difficulties confronted in some industries where a significant segment of employees are female part time workers. A well known Australian organisation-which I will not name-has been involved in negotiations with its industry union for about six years in relation to an extension of superannuation to its part time employees. During this time the number of part time employees has increased substantially, and they now comprise about 15 per cent of the work force. Needless to say, the vast majority of these employees were women. Of 5,000 such workers, only 50 were men. Happily, I have been informed that the problem has now been satisfactorily resolved, but not without a considerable degree of agitation and activity on the part of the union in recent times, and the incidental involvement of a number of members of Parliament. Madam Deputy Speaker, you might recall the case.

That example is not unique. Failure to extend pro rata benefits such as superannuation to part time employees simply institutionalises the practice of employing such workers because they are cheaper. This Government has a commitment to improving the conditions of work of Australians as well as to protecting their wage rates. Consistent with the policy of bringing forward the tax on end benefits to the point of contribution, deductions will no longer be allowed for amounts not paid into a fund but merely set apart by an employer to provide superannuation benefits. I suspect that that is the type of fund to which the honourable member for Maranoa was referring when he mentioned the one that he was in.

Deductions will now be available only for amounts actually paid to a recognised fund. This, too, is an important measure. In the past, the absence of a specific, discrete, inaccessible and publicly accountable provision for superannuation through an approved institution or fund has cast doubt on the bona fides of some superannuation schemes, and workers have naturally been reluctant to sink their hard earned money into accounts which may disappear into thin air in the event of an enterprise collapse, closure or amalgamation. In other words, this aspect of the legislation is in place to protect the money of workers.

I noted the contributions of honourable members opposite on this legislation with particular interest, given the fact that their respective parties have never evidenced a commitment to universal or even near universal availability of superannuation in the work force, and neither have they ever pursued initiatives such as portability of superannuation, without which superannuation is rendered unviable for people working in insecure areas of employment. While recognising the genuineness of the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) in asserting the need for the removal of the income and assets test, I cannot agree with his argument. The objective of an age pension, which equates to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, would not have been achieved without the imposition of the assets test and the income test. Neither would it have been achieved under a Liberal-National Party Government. It is, after all, an objective enshrined in Labor Party policy, and one to which the Government was and is committed.

The honourable member for Sturt also talked about people having a choice of retirement income, but did not refer to opportunity or ability to save. This matter was covered, in part, by the honourable member for Perth. There are many people in Australia who lack the resources to save for their retirement. They are low paid workers, if they are workers at all, who have not had either the opportunity to access superannuation or the level of disposable income necessary to save. The recipe of universality and choice put forward by the honourable member for Sturt is unrealistic. It would inevitably lead to a blow-out in the cost of providing adequate retirement incomes for an increasing number of people, and the only choice then, under a Liberal Government in particular, would be between the age pension and other forms of retirement income. Unfortunately, in these circumstances outlined, this would be a battle which the age pension would lose-as it did under the last Liberal Government. I do not believe for one moment that that choice would be made out of spite. Rather, it would be made because honourable members opposite do not seem capable of understanding that some people in our society are genuinely unable, for a variety of reasons, to set aside funds for sustaining themselves in their retirement.

The other point mentioned by the honourable member for Sturt related to the need for a liberalisation of the definition of savings for retirement, such that home purchase would be classified in this way. The honourable member claimed that there are legal ways of ensuring that double dipping could not occur. He is probably right, but he has not convinced me that it would be easy. The human condition is one of great complexity. Administration and monitoring of such a scheme would necessarily be tremendously intrusive and Australians would not countenance it. It is for this reason that I am personally opposed to lump sum payouts of superannuation beyond an acceptable minimum. I agree absolutely with the Government's earlier decision to tax these at a higher rate than the 5 per cent mentioned by the honourable member for Maranoa because I believe that the double dipping that was occurring was costing this economy a great amount of money and also depriving pensioners and people who required assistance with their incomes of an improvement in their conditions.

The Government has reduced income taxes on two occasions since coming to office, the most recent being announced in the April statement, and this has been accompanied by substantial improvements in family income. This is more than the Opposition has ever managed to achieve. Measures such as those contained in the Bill tonight help to make the tax system fairer and more just. I support the legislation and oppose the amendments put forward by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation to impose a new system of taxes on the superannuation industry and recipients of superannuation is indicative of the legislative incompetence and irresponsible attitude of the Labor Government. The eventual changes to the taxation of superannuation were first signalled in the 1988 May economic statement. However, the complete legislation dealing with these complicated, significant and short-sighted changes was introduced into this House only last week. We are debating the legislation now, only a few days later. We have had little opportunity to examine the details of the most recent of the Bills presently before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislative inability of the Labor Government and the irresponsible Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to legislate in a timely manner has produced uncertainty for businesses and for those who are seeking to provide for their future through superannuation and investments in superannuation funds. It is typical of the sloppy approach towards this Parliament which the Treasurer takes. The quality of legislation on taxation matters in this House is another indictment of the performance of the selfsame Treasurer.

It is not surprising that the Australian economy is now showing signs of advanced decay. In the context of that indefensible economic decline, the role of superannuation is particularly important. It is through such very long term investments that people seek to guarantee their future against the uncertainties of day-to-day economic change when they are no longer in a position to earn income. The value of those investments can be severely affected by government taxation policies and those economic polices which produce high inflation and erode the value of long-term investments.

Superannuation is a particularly important issue. These taxation measures affect not only tax and income policies, but also the whole range of social security measures which the Government oversees. At stake here is the question of private provision for welfare or the dependence of Australians on government. This question is more difficult now than it once was. Limits of resources available to government mean that future governments must balance the need to guarantee the existing rights of pensions to dignity and to a pension which is not theirs from charity but as a matter of real or perceived right after years of paying taxes against the fact that people will increasingly choose not to rely on the uncertainty of government support from dwindling resources.

It is almost trite to observe that Australia has an ageing population and, therefore, a declining tax base from which to support the increasing numbers of older people. Many consequences flow from these changes. One is that compulsory retirement should be re-examined so that healthy people who are beyond the age of 65 can continue to work for as long as they choose without being financially disadvantaged. Another is that governments of all complexions must seek to encourage people to make private provision for superannuation. The uncertainties involved in the presentation of these changes over more than a year discourage those contemplating superannuation.

The firms which provide superannuation funds have already had to make provision for paying these new taxes even though the legislation has not been debated in this Parliament, let alone been passed by it. On top of this uncertainty, the Government is proposing a series of new taxes on money invested in superannuation funds and on lump sum superannuation payments. This superannuation tax package began as a fiddle at the time of the 1988 May economic statement. It was designed to bring forward government revenue from lump sum superannuation payments so as to increase the apparent Budget surplus in the following couple of years.

The Government was quite willing to sacrifice the long term planning of individuals for their future to the short term interests of the Labor Party. The Treasurer has become an expert in budgetary fiddles since his first ham-fisted attempt at a Budget in 1983. They are not sufficient justification for poorly drafted and-thanks to the Government-inadequately debated legislation. The effects of this legislation, which had its origins in a clever trick dreamed up by some adviser I presume, will be felt long after the Labor Government falls and its budgetary problems are forgotten.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not be remembered.

—The changes to the taxation of superannuation was seen as the trade off for the reduction of the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent. The honourable member for Bradfield interjected saying that they will not be remembered. A government of our complexion will have to pick up the problems. I can imagine Government members, on this side of the chamber, laying on us the fruits of their insensibility and insensitiveness.
—Very bitter fruits.

—Very bitter fruits, indeed. These measures are estimated to produce revenue of $980m in 1989-90 and $1.4 billion-that is $1,400m-in 1990-91. We know that the effects of that corporate tax package over time will in fact mean greater revenue for the Commonwealth Government and, of course, more commensurate burdens for Australian businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: The mirage of lower taxes in the corporate rate tax area is ominous for those who are now looking forward to cuts in personal income tax. This legislation, which is part of that corporate tax package, will also have a significant impact on the affairs of everyday pay as you earn taxpayers whose only major investment, apart from their family home, is a superannuation scheme to provide for some comfort in retirement. An essential element of the Treasurer's argument was his statement that no recipient of superannuation payments would receive lower payouts because of the new tax structure. The shadow Minister for social security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), subsequently demonstrated without question that a range of losses, up to as much as 17 per cent, could be incurred by some people in some circumstances. As usual, the Treasurer's assurances to the Australian public were found to be worthless. It seems that only those who vote are of interest to the Treasurer.

The pattern of the Treasurer asserting an implausible account of a benefit to voting Australians, which is dutifully reported by his followers in the press before ultimately being abandoned when reality proves the Treasurer wrong, has been repeated so many times that it is now expected-it is passe. The estimates and predictions of the Treasurer have lost all credibility; they cannot be trusted. The worst errors are in his estimates of the effects of taxation and the revenue to be gained from new taxes, whatever their nature. Time after time, the capital gains tax, or the fringe benefits tax, or a sales tax change, or some other tax measure, has produced much more revenue than the Government found it convenient to admit when the measure was announced. We can have little more confidence in the assertions of the Treasurer about this legislation.

Under the new arrangements which are contained in this package, a 15 per cent tax will be imposed on the contributions by employers to superannuation funds. This tax represents a large slice of the revenue gains expected from the package. It involves, essentially, the bringing forward of revenue which would have been collected when superannuation payments were eventually made to retirees. There is nothing intrinsically more plausible about this arrangement than about those which existed previously. Like the rest of this tax package, it is not based on any principle or on a clear direction in taxation policy; it is a tax bred of expediency, rather than of a more sensible approach to taxation, which is so desperately needed to relieve the burdens of taxation on Australia.

This legislation will also impose a 15 per cent tax on the income from investments made by superannuation funds. This new tax will be partially offset against the dividend imputation credits on domestic equity investments made by the funds. It is estimated that after these credits are taken into account the effective rate of taxation on some funds could be as little as 4 per cent. Given that low return, it is questionable whether the enormous administrative costs on business and the Australian Taxation Office justify imposing this element of the new tax at all. As these costs are realised, there must be a real prospect for increases in the rate of the tax in the future. In other words, it could be considered to be the thin end of the wedge.

The Treasurer sought to present this tax as a means of promoting investment in Australian securities rather than securities overseas. Any incentive for domestic investment would derive from the fact that imputation of dividends is not applied to foreign companies paying tax overseas or to overseas profits earned by Australian companies. The new tax on the investments of superannuation funds would be minimised by investing in large local companies which offer fully franked dividends. Therefore, this is far from a neutral tax. It seeks to direct and distort the investment profile of some of the largest investors in this country-I refer to the superannuation funds. Indeed, it encourages firms to modify their behaviour so as to minimise tax-a practice that the Treasurer claims to frown upon in other circumstances. It is now clear that tax minimisation is okay so long as the Treasurer's permission is obtained first. What is new about that?

Australian firms can do without the gratuitous advice of the Treasurer to invest in what is really a fairly limited number of Australian companies. Fund managers must be encouraged to invest so as to maximise the return to policyholders, not the doubtful interest of the Government. Most superannuation funds already maintain extensive investments within Australia. However, if they are to continue to expand and are not to dominate local markets, the largest funds must invest overseas. The subtle form of protection which is involved with this tax further undermines the Government's claims to credibility and economic reform. If only slightly, this measure will provide comfort for companies to be less efficient than they might otherwise be, to return less to their shareholders than they otherwise might, and to be less competitive with the funds of shareholders than overseas companies are.

Another concern with this tax is that it will fall more heavily on funds such as approved deposit funds and roll-over funds which invest in safer securities such as bonds that will not attract any imputation credits. This is yet another distorting outcome of this hastily conceived, if slowly implemented, legislation. Considering all of these effects, it is clear that there are substantial grounds on which to reject this part of the Government's superannuation tax package. I doubt whether the Government is fully aware of the potential consequences of this legislation. It was brought together as a gimmick to hold together the corporate tax package-no more no less. Honourable members opposite who have no principled commitment are not really endeared to this package. I suggest that they consider the constructive changes which the Opposition has proposed by way of the amendment put forward by the honourable member for Bradfield.

The third leg of this package, which is nearly unstable enough to fall, is the 16.25 per cent tax on lump sum superannuation payments of over $60,000. It replaces the Government's earlier tax on lump sum superannuation payments. That earlier package caused havoc enough with people about to retire when it was first introduced. This new package has compounded that uncertainty. People want to provide for their futures without being dependent on government. However, they are cautious about the type of long term investment that superannuation represents when the Government imposes new constraints and imposts on their investment. Superannuation is an area in which stability is essential. This Government has not provided that stability.

Despite the rhetoric about providing for the aged, the Australian Labor Party is even discouraging those approaching retirement from looking after themselves. This package, in keeping with the sorry record of the Keating inspired Labor Government on taxation matters, is at least consistent with its record. It is full of consequences which were no part of the design of those who drafted the legislation. The Government has had 12 months since its original announcements to refine this legislation. Yet this package of Bills, which we will debate just one week after the most recent of those Bills was introduced, is as sloppy as any of the myriad of other tax Bills that have been introduced over the past six long years of Labor rule.

TALK.START.PARA: —They gave us only four days.

—It gave us four days to consider very complex legislation with far reaching consequences which, as I have already indicated, this Government fails to acknowledge. The Treasurer has not even kept his promise that payouts of superannuation will not be affected by the new taxes he has introduced in these new measures. Yet again, narrow political considerations have predominated over economic rationality. Government policies in taxation and social security are not-I repeat not-moving in the right direction. They undermine private provision for the futures of individuals. They reduce incentives for private individuals to save or invest. The Government should accept the Opposition's amendment. I hope that it learns from the numerous mistakes it made when implementing the corporate tax package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed that in a speech which obviously the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) has taken a long time to write and put together there were so many statements which were factually quite wrong and insulting in certain ways in relation to social security and superannuation policy. Some of the comments he made in relation to the actions and behaviour of the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) were in fact unnecessarily insulting and did not get to the point at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just say this to the honourable member for Curtin: having returned from a visit overseas and seeing something of the social welfare systems of other countries, the actions of this Government in relation both to economic management and social security stand up in world terms and comparison. If one wants to put together a comprehensive economic management package that works, combined with a package to deal with the problems of the poorer sections of the population and provides social justice across the board to the population, one should have a look at the programs of this Government which are so impressive that they are now being copied in other countries as examples of how to proceed.

The conservatives in this place proclaim compassion for the ordinary citizen, the aged and the poor. But whenever one asks them for specific programs and policies that will achieve any better situation, what does one get? One gets contradictions and statements which go in different directions. When one analyses the Opposition's concrete policies, they come down to right wing ideological nonsense.

In this last week we have seen the real face of the conservative parties in this country. What happened in the preselections that were held in Victoria for the Liberal Party of Australia? The triumph of the New Right forces--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I raise the question of relevance to the legislation before the House.
—I am trying to establish the point of relevance.
—There is no relevance whatsoever between superannuation and preselections; none at all.
—I will get to the point of relevance.

—Order! I ask the honourable member for Calwell to keep his remarks relevant and pertinent to the subject. However, during this debate there have been very wide-ranging comments from both sides of the House.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I have spoken in the debate. I think we have been remarkably restrained in that particular context.

—The honourable member is entitled to his opinion. The Chair makes the decisions. This has been a wide-ranging debate, but I ask the honourable member for Calwell to come back at this stage to the point of the Bill.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, we have had from the Opposition a number of statements about our Ministers and our members and the positions that they have taken on superannuation and aged policy. I think in that context it is relevant to refer to the prescriptions and policies of the Liberal Party. I was referring here to one of the most pre-eminent persons in the Liberal Party, Professor David Kemp, who recently defeated the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), one of the moderates in the Liberal Party, for preselection and what he had to say about this very question of aged policy.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. With respect, I put it to you that if the honourable member for Calwell wishes to discuss the Liberal Party's retirement incomes policy, which has received the endorsement of virtually every organisation around Australia, we would be happy for him to do so. But it is not responsible to go beyond that.

—Order! The honourable member for Bradfield declares the point of order and then awaits the decision. Certainly the Chair has been listening to many speeches which link Government and Opposition policies to the legislation. I see the contribution of the honourable member for Calwell as being within those parameters.

—I do not know why the honourable member for Bradfield is so sensitive in respect of this question. Is it because he does not want me to refer to the contrast between the Opposition's policy and our policy? I think it would be entirely unfair in this debate for members opposite to attack our policies and refer to our policies and, when I try to respond, all we get is the honourable member for Bradfield taking a number of points of order against me. The fact is that members opposite do not want members on this side to discuss the Opposition's policy for the very good reason that we know what forces have been behind the fashioning of that policy, and I refer to the forces of the New Right which have been responsible for--
—Ha, ha, ha!

—The honourable member laughs, but the fact is that those forces have taken control of the Liberal Party in New South Wales and Victoria, as I have mentioned and as was proved by recent preselections where we saw the defeat of the moderates by the New Right, which is responsible for the policies being put forward by the honourable member for Bradfield in relation to the aged--

—On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker: I take exception to the honourable member's suggestion that I did not prepare or write the policy in relation to this area. That is what he said and I do not accept it.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, am I to be constantly interrupted with false points of order?
—Get on with the debate, for heaven's sake!

—I am trying to get on with the debate, but obviously the honourable member does not want to hear what I have to say. After all the comments of the honourable member for Curtin and his attacks on the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), the honourable member for Bradfield impertinently keeps interrupting me when I refer to the Opposition's policy and the nonsensical ideas put forward in this area by members opposite. I return to the comments of the honourable member for Curtin. Obviously I will have to restrict myself to some of his comments in order to satisfy the honourable member for Bradfield. The honourable member for Curtin said, `It is a trite observation that Australia is an ageing society and that therefore we are not going to have enough money for the provision of aged care in the future'. Why is it a `trite' observation? I would have thought that it is a crucial observation about which all Australians should be concerned. Certainly, we on this side of the House are concerned about this matter, and our population and immigration policies are designed to deal with this question. It is not a trite observation at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's elderly citizens are demanding to know how any government-whether it is our Government or a government formed by members opposite, and let us hope that that is a long time in the future-will deal with this very serious problem; that is, the problem of how to provide sufficient retirement income for Australia's elderly citizens in a period when the population is ageing in a substantial way. So, instead of the honourable member for Curtin addressing this question, he says merely that it is a trite observation. It is certainly not a trite observation, and the honourable member for Bradfield should recognise that. It goes to the essence and heart of why we are amending the Superannuation Act. We recognise the importance of making changes to ensure that people provide for their superannuation and that it is more broadly available to more people in Australia. In other words, we are trying to move to a situation in which over a period every Australian will be in a position to be in some kind of superannuation scheme and have some provision for their old age and for their pensions.

Of course, the Opposition has decided that it will attack certain technical aspects of these reforms. But it does not come out with any set concrete suggestion about how we deal with this overall problem. One only has to look at history to recognise the behaviour of the Opposition in relation to this question. During the period of the last Labor Government, the Whitlam Labor Government, attempts were made by the Labor Party to introduce a national superannuation scheme to cover all citizens. That was resisted by the Opposition forces. As a result, we are paying the price for the lack of such a universal scheme. That is a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a fact.

—Why does not the honourable member take another point of order? Will he deny that fact as well? If we had moved in this area years ago we would not be faced with the kind of crisis we are faced with. We are not the only country to be faced with this crisis in relation to the ageing of the population and the problem of superannuation; other countries in the world would face similar problems. But we would have moved a lot closer to the solution of the problem if these changes had been made.

SPEECH.PARA: What are we doing as a government? The Minister for Social Security, in my estimation, is the greatest social reformer in the postwar period in terms of the social programs which he has put forward in this country. Anyone can see the difference in his record of concrete achievements within a difficult economic climate as distinct from the lack of achievement by the Opposition when it was in government in an easy economic climate. One can look, for example, at the achievements in the areas of child support, family assistance programs, and pensions and benefits. In all of those areas we have been able to assist. At the same time as having to face difficult economic decisions he has put forward great social reforms.

The important thing here is that we now have a study, through the report of Bettina Cass, of the serious questions involved in retirement and superannuation. For the first time we have had a comprehensive study of what needs to be done in this country. It is on the basis of that report that we will be moving to legislate in the next year-indeed, in the next term, which will certainly see another Labor government in office-to ensure in the longer term one of the best retirement programs in the world for elderly citizens. That is the program that we are aiming for in Australia.

I have discussed the question of the changes involved in these Bills in this broad context because the Opposition tried to raise these matters in a broad context. What do we find from the Opposition? We find that the Opposition is not moving to oppose the legislation completely but moves a number of minor amendments. Then it makes a lot of noise-about what? The noise is about these minor amendments. These are the minor amendments that have been moved. The Opposition makes a lot of noise about these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member is completely mistaken. We are opposing the legislation if our amendments are not accepted.
—Order! I am not sure that that is a point of order.
—Let us keep the debate accurate.
—We are all familiar with those tricks in the Parliament.
—Order! I call the honourable member for Bradfield to order. His interruption is quite irregular.

—The honourable member has been interrupting for the last 10 or 15 minutes. I want to answer one claim by the honourable member for Curtin. He mentioned the 15 per cent tax on investment by superannuation funds which is recoverable through the procedure of imputation credits, a very important procedure that we have put into place, another revolutionary change of the Treasurer. The honourable member for Curtin said that this measure was no good because it was trying to interfere with the investments of superannuation funds. Why? Because it was interference to try to encourage those funds to invest in Australian companies. That is what he said. He said it is not an open market policy if we try to encourage superannuation funds to invest in Australian companies. In other words, he said the government should do nothing to encourage superannuation funds, which are among the biggest investors of capital in this country to invest in Australia and Australian corporations.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the honourable member for Curtin, any action by the Government to encourage investment in our own country and in our own corporations is to be seen as some kind of undue interference. Does the Opposition stand for the selling out of Australia or what? What a nonsense this is. In other words, one of the most positive measures for a long time to encourage capital investment in productive Australian enterprises and in Australian companies, to encourage superannuation funds to invest in them, is described by the Opposition, this bunch of no-hopers over here, as being contrary to some vague ideological principle of the New Right that I referred to before. The fact is that this is a very important and very sensible measure that has been well thought out in order to encourage investment in the area in which we need it most if we are to turn the Australian economy around; namely, in the productive companies of this country.

So I do not quite understand why the Opposition is opposing that particular clause. To me, this is an incredible opposition to a very sensible measure. It also means that the impact of the 15 per cent tax on the payout of superannuation funds is reduced, as the Treasurer said. In other words, superannuation funds have been told, `Look, you can pay the 15 per cent tax, but you can get back most of that 15 per cent if you invest in Australian companies and in Australian shares'. It is an excellent scheme, an excellent idea, for helping to encourage capital formation in Australia. Instead of that, we find the Opposition getting up and saying, `This is no good because, after all, it is some kind of interference in some vague concept of the free market'. It does not mind interfering in the free market to suit its rich friends whenever it suits them, but when it is a measure which is intended to ensure the direction of these scarce capital funds in this particular way for Australian production, especially in the areas where we need it most, namely, Australian manufacturing capital, we find the Opposition, as usual, in an incoherent way and without thinking through it, wanting to oppose it.

Given the way in which the Opposition has tried to argue against these changes, I am amazed to see that it has not suggested more amendments to the Bill than the honourable member for Bradfield has suggested. I do not understand why the honourable member for Bradfield thinks that simply changing this particular clause is some alternative policy on this question; it certainly is not. For him to say, `If we do not get this through we are going to oppose the whole Bill', what is going to be put in its place?

TALK.START.PARA: —A Bill without the taxation, obviously.

—It is going to be a Bill without the taxation. How is the Opposition going to deal with the problems that are identified in terms of superannuation funds? The honourable member for Bradfield has not answered that in his contribution to the second reading debate. He has not explained what sort of policy he would put forward to deal with the need for more money in this area.
—For your Treasury, yes. You want more money for your Treasury. That is the whole basis of your taxation policy. This is the highest taxing Government in Australia's peacetime history.

—Here we go. We hear the generalised comments about high taxation. We heard the usual story from the honourable member for Curtin that there is something wrong with the capital gains tax. Every time the New Right conservatives want to get up and say something about taxation, they attack the capital gains tax. Why? Because some of their rich friends have not benefited from the introduction of that tax. If we had not introduced the capital gains tax, we would not be able to sustain pensions and benefits at the level at which we are sustaining them. There is no question about it. What would happen is the same as happens in other countries that have foolishly adopted new, right philosophies in government. Pensions would be cut and benefits would be cut. The fact is that, with the increasingly ageing population, there would be a reduction in the pensions. So we totally reject the arguments of the Opposition.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am really surprised and somewhat disappointed in the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) for constantly interjecting tonight in an attempt to stop the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) contributing to the debate. The honourable member for Bradfield had done nothing but try to stifle that contribution. As the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), who previously occupied the chair, said, there is the opportunity for a wider debate, as there must be. One cannot discuss taxation changes in any field without relating the discussion to other areas of taxation. These things are very much intermixed; they are very much connected.

SPEECH.PARA: If one were more in contact with the community, if one went out and spoke to retired persons, one would find that their concern is not focused simply on taxation and superannuation, but on the standard of living that people in retirement enjoy or do not enjoy. The honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) and I, as members of the task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on retirement incomes which went from State to State, discussed these matters at first hand with 3,000 or more individual retirees in this country and we came back with many messages for the Government. One message that came back clearly was that what any government must do is provide a standard of living which is equitable, sustainable and reasonable for all retirees, whether they are on superannuation or government-funded pensions. Nowhere could it be said that the changes in the taxation on superannuation could be seen in isolation from other areas of taxation that affect the standard of living. So it is wrong for the honourable member for Bradfield to try to stifle the broader debate tonight with, can I say, inane and pointless interjections. In fact, his colleagues in the Opposition were far more wide-ranging in their contributions.

The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) spent some time trying to indicate, although without statistics, that the general economy was flat, dead, on the way down. Yet, if he had bothered to look at the statistics he would have found an acceleration in this economy. He would have found that unemployment is down and is going down and that employment is going up. We are increasing our job creation. Productivity has increased. The economy, while flattening out, as it should so that it cannot get overheated, is still very much one of high activity.
