So that if the honourable member for Curtin can raise wide ranging matters in this debate I do not see why the honourable member for Calwell or any other honourable member cannot do likewise. What rubbish for the honourable member for Curtin to say that the economy is on a rapid downturn. I suppose that is because his memory of when Opposition members were last in government was when this country faced a recession. Perhaps they dream daily of crossing the floor and occupying the government benches and of the golden years when they nearly wrecked this country, when they nearly sent it down the proverbial gurgler.

Another Opposition colleague of the honourable member for Bradfield-I refer to the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron)-had the hide to make the statement that this Government has the highest tax rate in federal history. Only last month the Treasurer (Mr Keating) introduced his April statement which reduced, for the third time the marginal rates of tax, so that those rates are now far lower than they were during the Fraser years. When they are combined with the family allowance and the family allowance supplement payments the position is different from that claimed by the honourable member for Maranoa. In fact, there are rising standards of living for those people in the lower economic groupings, the lower income areas, who were neglected for years; in fact bruised by the Opposition when it was in government.

It is impossible to talk about retirement incomes unless we can talk about the contributions that wage earners are able to make towards superannuation to provide for their own income in retirement years or for those who have to rely on the pension. When we talk about retirement incomes, we have to talk about what the Opposition will do. I want to repeat one line delivered towards the end of the contribution of the honourable member for Calwell, and that was that an amendment trotted into this House tonight to these Bills does not constitute an economic policy, does not constitute a policy on superannuation. The amendment is a reaction to what the Government is doing. In other words, it is in recognition that this Government has an acceptable policy which, even in the Opposition's own terms, is generous but requires some fine tuning.

If the Opposition had a policy which it had engendered amongst its own ranks, it would have come in here with that alternative policy. In fact if it had a policy which is acceptable to the people, it would not be on that side of the House, it would be on this side. But it was rejected repeatedly in 1983, 1984 and 1987. When the next election is held it will be rejected again, because amendments, off the cuff statements and silence during press interviews are no substitution for an economic policy.

The Opposition has spent some time shuffling its leadership and very soon it will be changing and recycling its front bench. The community has to ask: `What do we get for that? Do we get cosmetic changes or do we get a change in some form of policy?'. Since the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) last occupied that position, a great many words have been spoken about taxation, including in this debate, by members of the Opposition. This House and the Australian people have been told on many occasions that the Liberal Party would soon be releasing, would soon be exposing for criticism, would soon be detailing to the public, its own taxation policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last August.

—Last August, the honourable member for Hawker reminds me. But there is not a single word, not a scintilla of evidence that it has in its feeble mind a taxation policy. So what do we have in the shuffling? A change of pace. Do we wait longer or are we going to see a change in the Opposition's thinking? The latest episode in the Liberal Party's long running taxation saga was when the Leader of the Opposition spoke to the National Press Club in his capacity as shadow Treasurer. In this case I must say that the title of shadow Treasurer was most apposite, particularly appropriate, for he said very little of substance but he promised a great deal in the future if we had the patience to wait. His speech and answers to questions were strong on rhetoric but weak on content.

SPEECH.PARA: His colleague the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson)-a man who gained his doctorate and his professorship in the lucky dip-comes in here and says just as little, just as few words of explanation. So it is more like the shuffling of a comedy or song and dance team. If one were to give them a title, knowing that the honourable member for Wentworth drives one of those flashy sports cars from Italy, and knowing the preference for sartorial splendour of the new Leader of the Opposition, we would call them Gucci and Ferrari. A song and dance team is not good enough for the Australian people. It will be rejected at the next election for what it is, farce and comedy. The time has come for the Opposition to give the Australian people more than simple rhetoric. The time has come for the Leader of the Opposition to show whether the souffle tag is merited or not and whether we will hear something of substance instead of shadow.

To contrast that image with that of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who now sits on the back bench, it can be said of the honourable member for Bennelong that what you saw was what you got. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has given him a reference. I suppose `hard working' and `honest' if not inventive, were accurate statements. But at least we got what we saw. Now, with all the tinsel and the packaging, the window-dressing, we have something to rival Myer's windows at Christmas time. In other words, the community still has to guess what the Opposition has in mind for its taxation policy because it hides the truth.

I suggest that, with the shuffling and the changing, there is still the commitment to the hard, dry economics referred to by the honourable member for Calwell. That was probably nowhere exhibited more than in the hard fought preselections that took place in Victoria only last weekend. We know that the honourable member for Kooyong is to hold fast to the dry line of economics that is postulated in Future Directions because he said that the legacy left by the honourable member for Bennelong-hard, dry, responsible economics that have no heart, no soul and no compassion-is what he will embrace and carry on like a standard to the next election.

We have to ask ourselves whether, with the new Opposition front bench when it is announced and with the new leadership already elected, we will see the same old policy. The Opposition has not announced a new policy. It has said that it will just reject, throw out, this Government's tax reforms lock, stock, and barrel. Let me explain what I mean by lock, stock, and barrel, because that is what the honourable member for Bennelong and now the honourable member for Kooyong have said they are going to do. We hear nothing about the substitute policies. The Opposition will reject the Government's taxation policies lock, stock and barrel. Its policies are election-driven. They are not based on what is good for the country, not on what is best to bring about a proper, decent, sustainable retirement incomes policy based on a combination of superannuation and pensions but on `How can we out auction the Government come the next election? How can we somehow, with our tinsel and gaudy presentation, have a better point of sale at the ballot box than the Government?'.

Firstly, members of the Opposition will suggest that they can lower taxes further-hold out the fistful of dollars like they did in 1977. Then, after the election, when the votes are locked in, they will take the dollars back. In other words, their task, their idea, is to present a package which they cannot sustain but which is there for electoral-driven purposes just to lock in the votes. Then they would promise to lower taxes, not for the general population but for their mates. They want to get rid of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax so that the rorts that went on when the Opposition was in government will keep going. Instead, they will give a new tax to the ordinary wage and salary earner, to the pensioners and the retirees we are talking about tonight. That is called a consumption tax. In other words, it is the good old reverse Robin Hood-you take from the poor and you give to the rich. That is their stock in trade. They lock in the votes and their stock in trade is to reverse the taxation burden.

Then, if they have any brains, they will have to work out how to pay for these tax cuts. What do we find if we look to the past? We have to look there because we have heard no new policies. We have to listen to the words of the Opposition, shadow Treasurer-I suppose that is the honourable member for Wentworth, although it has not been properly announced as yet-and the honourable member for Kooyong who was in the Fraser Cabinet. We find that they will continue those policies, such as a freeze on pensions. They would ignore the benefit and the necessity of child care in invigorating the economy. In other words, they would have pensioners and mothers with child care needs over a barrel-they would have them in the gun. So, there we have it, lock, stock and barrel: lock in the votes, employ their stock-in-trade of reversing the tax burden in this country and then, to pay for the whole shemozzle, have the ordinary people of this country over a barrel. Why do we believe that what happened in the early 1980s will continue? Last weekend in Melbourne at the preselections for Goldstein and Higgins members of the far right of the Liberal Party-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I regret once again to have to take a point of order on the question of relevance. We are talking about superannuation legislation and not preselections.

—I must say that I am somewhat surprised that a point on relevance was not taken earlier in the debate. I ask the honourable member to make his remarks relevant to the Bills being discussed in this cognate debate which relate principally to taxation questions.

—A certain amount of latitude is allowed in debates on taxation Bills. While you have been in the Chair, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have already referred to the opportunities taken in this debate by the honourable member for Maranoa and the honourable member for Curtin, who certainly strayed from the subject far more than I have. I want to explain the relevance of the preselections. Immediately after being preselected for the seat of Goldstein, Professor David Kemp-by golly, this place is raining professors lately although, as the Treasurer says, they sink without trace-said in an interview that he thought there were too many people on welfare in this country. The same thing could be said about pensions, that there are too many retired people on pensions in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Through its work and policy development based on Bettina Cass's excellent paper-No. 6-on retirement incomes, the Government is able to say that the only way it can continue with providing retirement incomes is on the twin bases of pensions and superannuation. Yet, these right wing future members of this House say that there is too much reliance on the Government payroll; that too much is being spent on pensions and welfare payments. But there is no policy, mark you, to put in the place of what this Government is doing. In other words, we will have more and more of what we have seen under the Opposition and which this Government is correcting in respect of superannuation. There are very few women on superannuation; it is mainly the domain of males-not all males, but males on higher income. That is the way it has been. The Opposition never did anything about it. This Government has said that the last productivity increase of 3 per cent should be paid through a widening of the availability of superannuation. In other words, all wage and salary earners will have an increased opportunity to enter superannuation and provide for their futures with less call upon tax paid for superannuation schemes. Yet, the future members of this House who have been preselected in Melbourne-the right wingers-are going to drive the new leaders of the Opposition.

As I said before, the honourable member for Hawker and I have gone around the country as part of the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes talking to the real people who matter-those approaching retirement and those in retirement. These people said that for years this had been the most neglected area by governments and they were pleased and excited by the prospect of the development of retirement incomes under this Government. They would be able to plan for their future and their security. They asked questions about what would be the effect of the 15 per cent taxation on employer contributions and the removal at the other end-which has not been raised very often by the Opposition-of the 15 per cent on payouts to superannuants. We were able to say quite clearly, and this legislation puts any other argument to rest, that there will be no extra tax paid by superannuants in this country. Perhaps the most important part of this legislation is the opportunity, as the honourable member for Calwell said, for superannuation funds to invest in Australian companies.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to thank all honourable members who participated in this wide-ranging cognate debate covering six taxation Bills. In responding on behalf of the Government I want to contain my remarks mostly to those made by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). Let me say at the outset that the honourable member for Bradfield is an intelligent person, but so much of what he has said on these issues in the past has been an exercise in deliberate mischief. He has created needless anxiety and needless alarm, particularly among people approaching retirement age. All members of this House, at some time or another, have received representations arising from that mischief, and that deliberately caused needless anxiety generated by the honourable member for Bradfield.

SPEECH.PARA: He used not to be like that. I do not know why he has developed in that manner. I have known him for some time. He used to be a thinking, very upright person-a person of utmost integrity. I do not understand why he has changed. The only conclusion I can draw is that he, like other members opposite--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister is impugning my integrity. I want to re-emphasise that if I have been doing my job to advise people of the effects of Government policy, it is to my credit and not to that of the Government.

—The matters which the honourable member is raising are matters to be dealt with by way of personal explanation, if the honourable member receives the appropriate leave from the Chair. I do not know that it will be granted if he continues to raise such points by way of points of order.

—The honourable member and I have known each other for some time and have exchanged views across the table. I think everybody on this side of the House would applaud him if the information he was circulating was accurate. That is the comment I make. I know it was not accurate and he knows it was not accurate. I wonder why he is pursuing that course. He used not to be like that. That is not impugning his integrity, it is simply stating a fact.
—I do not put out inaccurate information.

—The honourable member is an honourable and intelligent person. Why he wants to worry and cause anxiety to people who are approaching retirement age, I do not know. It is not like him; he used not to be like that.
—You were a decent chap once.

—He was a decent chap once. All I can say is that the honourable member is feeling the pressure that is being applied on that side of the House with the recycling and recasting of tasks involved, with changes in leadership, changes to shadow ministries and the move to the Right. It is the pressure of the New Right which is causing difficulty over there.

SPEECH.PARA: I was concerned that, earlier this evening, before the dinner adjournment, the honourable member for Bradfield went through the exercise of expressing concern about the savings of ordinary Australians, as he put it. I do not think anybody in this country has forgotten his lack of concern for the savings of ordinary Australians in 1981, 1982 and 1983 when he was a member of the Government that saw the economy of this country collapse-no one could see the bottom. It was the worst decline in the economy since the Great Depression. At the same time we saw the unemployment rate rise to double figures-there was almost 11 per cent unemployment and almost 12 per cent inflation. Savings of ordinary Australians were being rapidly eroded and destroyed before people's eyes. I do not know where the honourable member for Bradfield was at that time, but I would have liked to have seen him express his concern at that time rather than now because, at that time, he was a man who said what he believed. I know he does not believe much of what he says now; I know him too well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop being insulting.

—I know the honourable member very well. I know he does not believe much of what he says. I would not say that if it was not genuine. He knows that. In that period of just over 12 months almost a quarter of a million Australians lost their jobs. I wish the honourable member had expressed some concern then about that.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do not want to interrupt the debate, but the work for the dole program which I initiated in my electorate-called Youth Work-was the first initiative ever conducted which the Minister's Government destroyed when it came to power. So he should not get up here and say what I did or did not do. I have a damn good record in that area.

—I say to the Minister that if the point of order had been taken on relevance I may have been more inclined to rule in the honourable member's favour. Perhaps it would be a little less provocative if the speeches were more relevant.

—That is very wise advice; I accept it. The honourable member for Bradfield and I share some views and some recollections. I wish he was the fellow he used to be. Has anybody in this nation forgotten the McCabe-Lafranchi reports or the Costigan reports? What happened to the taxation system during those years? It all comes together. It all happened in that period prior to 1983.
—On a point of order: I do regret that I have to raise the issue of relevance again. The Minister's remarks are not relevant to the superannuation Bills before us.

—In addressing the point of order, I must say that my remarks are utterly relevant to the package of six tax Bills that are before this chamber. The debate up to this point has been a very wide-ranging debate. If somebody had taken points of order earlier there would have been no debate. I seek your agreement on this, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—I am aware that the debate has been very wide ranging. I was somewhat surprised that points of order on relevance were not taken much earlier in the debate. Most of the speeches I have sat through have been from honourable members on the Minister's side of the House. Perhaps we could contain the debate to the Bills that are before us and to the matters that require reply.

—I agree. The point I was coming to was that in that period prior to 1983 we looked at what was happening to the taxation system and we now compare that with the measures that have been taken by this Government to make it a fairer tax system. We should recognise one thing: the only growth in the seven years prior to 1983 was the tax avoidance and tax evasion industry. During that period the tax burden moved away from the corporate sector, away from the high income earners and onto the shoulders of wage and salary earners, the pay as you earn taxpayers and their families. They are the people who suffered during that period. I am sure that fact is not forgotten and will never be forgotten by Australian taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to respond in general to the arguments put forward by the honourable member for Bradfield and to indicate at this early stage that we will not be accepting the amendments that are to be moved by the honourable member for Bradfield. The Opposition proposal to eliminate the 15 per cent tax on investment income of superannuation funds will be rejected by the Government. It is rejected by the Life Insurance Federation of Australia which represents the major participants in the superannuation industry. It is even inconsistent with the Opposition's own retirement incomes policy. The very low rate of tax on the earnings of superannuation funds was introduced in the May 1988 economic statement to give this very significant group of investors access to the Government's landmark imputation system. Under that imputation system, tax paid on a company's profits gives rise to a credit which can be applied by a shareholder to reduce tax payable on dividends paid to the shareholder from those profits. This was one of the most historic moves and beneficial changes in the history of the taxation system in this country.

The May statement also extended the imputation system to life officers and registered organisations. These measures complete the removal of the bias in the tax system favouring debt over equity. The only responsible way of extending imputation arrangements to superannuation funds is by introducing a tax on fund income at a concessional rate so that we have a tax liability against which imputation credits can be offset. Imputation not only gives a fairer treatment of dividends and interest but it removes substantial inefficiencies hindering the development of Australia's equity markets. Until tonight the Opposition has consistently endorsed the extension of the Government imputation system to all taxpayers. But tonight it seeks to deny these provisions to superannuation funds. I believe that the Opposition has very little appreciation of the wide ranging consequences of such actions. I confess that I do not think the honourable member for Bradfield really understands how the system works or the implications of what he is moving. It is not overstating the position to say that passage of the Opposition amendment would require a reassessment of the continued viability of the entire imputation system.

Before the changes announced in the May statement, superannuation funds and other large institutional investors such as life officers and friendly societies were excluded from the imputation arrangements. This meant that franked dividends they received were wasted. Superannuation funds and institutional investors were attracted to debt instruments rather than to equities. A number of so-called tax effective financing schemes and other tax avoidance arrangements also resulted. These included schemes promoted by companies publicly associated with the Liberal Party. The Opposition amendment, if successful, would return superannuation funds to a position in which they were encouraged to make investment decisions based on taxation advantages rather than the greatest overall economic return. Superannuation funds would no longer prefer investments in those companies which pay a fair measure of Australian tax; instead, they would again have an incentive to invest with those best able to exploit loopholes in the tax system and invest more funds abroad.

Who will be the losers in that kind of arrangement? The losers will be the Australian economy and the Australian people. I have said on a number of occasions that the Liberals are like leopards, they do not change their spots. At the first opportunity they are back to their old habits, back to loading the burden onto the pay as you earn taxpayers and their families and away from the high income earners. That will result in an unfairer tax system weighted against wage and salary earners.

The removal of superannuation funds from the imputation arrangements would force the Government to consider complicated anti-avoidance provisions to prevent tax effective financing arrangements once more becoming popular. The Opposition's decision to impose the tax on investment earnings is difficult to understand for other reasons as well. It is clearly inconsistent with the Opposition's own retirement income policy launched in November last year. That policy stated that the Opposition would `continue to provide company tax imputation credits to superannuation funds on franked dividends'.

Several representatives of the superannuation industry have stated publicly that in practice the tax will have no effect on the investment earnings of most superannuation funds. In some cases superannuation funds are expected to have excess imputation credits which they can use to offset the tax on contributions. The net result is significantly improved end benefits for those investing in major superannuation funds. For other superannuation funds, including many approved deposit funds, the earnings tax will either be minimal or could be readily reduced by an adjustment to their investment portfolios. Tax liabilities can be reduced by investing in shares, but also by investing in assets which provide a return in the form of a capital gain. Moreover, even in those cases where some net earnings tax would be payable, it does not follow that after tax end benefits would be lower. The reason for that is that the reduction of tax on end benefits intentionally exceeds what is necessary to offset the new tax on deductable contributions. This is a quite deliberate design feature intended to provide an offset to any residual effect of the earnings tax.

I will turn now to some of the more specific points made by the honourable member for Bradfield earlier this evening. The honourable member claimed that the Government's changes to superannuation taxation have made investing in superannuation unattractive. I want to emphasise that this proposition finds absolutely no support among any of the major superannuation funds. In a letter to the editor of the Australian Financial Review on 4 May, the taxation and legislation manager of the Australian Mutual Provident Society superannuation said, `There remains significant tax incentives to contribute to superannuation'. In a statement issued this evening the group managing director of National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd has said that the new tax arrangements `present a significant level of incentives to encourage the community to save for retirement, and this should be welcomed'. National Mutual has said that it is essential that the legislation `should be passed quickly in the interests of fund members and administrators'. This position has been supported by the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, which on Friday called for the speedy passage of the legislation. The Opposition's amendments do not have the support of any credible voice in the super- annuation industry. One of the reasons for this was outlined by the managing director of National Mutual in his statement tonight:

There has been significant consultation with the Government over the drafting of the Bill, and all of the significant recommendations contained in the 15 point submission by the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia, the Institute of Actuaries and the Life Insurance Federation of Australia have been accepted and included in this Bill.

The honourable member for Bradfield seems to have based his argument on the proposition that people will be made worse off by the Government's legislation on the basis that superannuation funds commonly only hold 15 per cent of their portfolios in equities. The honourable member is hopelessly ill-informed about the true position. Apparently, he does not understand the importance of the concessional taxation of capital gains in reducing the effective earnings tax rate. This is one of the reasons why many funds do not expect to pay any net tax on investment earnings.

Finally, I note that I have seen a statement released by the honourable member for Bradfield to the media tonight to the effect that, if the Opposition amendment is defeated in this place-as it will be-the coalition is committed to opposing this Bill in toto in the House of Representatives. All I want to say about that is that it is a grossly irresponsible position to take. It would deny the revenue some $980m in 1989-90 and $1,400m in the following year.
In conclusion, I turn to the Opposition's proposal that the $60,000 lump sum threshold contained in the Government's legislation be increased to $125,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker: I do believe that the Minister should be at least accurate to the House.
—There is no point of order.

—There can be no more graphic demonstration of the fact that this Opposition represents only the very top end of town, the very top end of the income scale. In the 1987-88 income year, less than one half of one per cent of eligible termination payments declared for tax purposes were higher than $55,000. Not surprisingly, these eligible termination payments were all received by high income earners. No more than a handful of people would benefit from the Opposition's amendment-and those who would benefit would be very wealthy people. It is essential that the Opposition's amendment be defeated so that the taxation of superannuation can maintain an acceptable degree of progressiveness. The government is not prepared to see higher income retirees advantaged relative to people on lower and middle incomes, and nor is it prepared to see their families advantaged. The Opposition's amendment would also encourage more people to take their retirement benefit in a lump sum rather than in the form of a superannuation pension, with obvious adverse implications for retirement income policies generally.

SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated at the outset, the Government will be rejecting the Opposition's amendments. The measures which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced in May 1988 substantially enhance the integrity of the superannuation system. They place the taxation of superannuation on a more tax consistent and less costly basis. They lay the basis for sustainable long term arrangements. They enable individuals and industry to plan and invest with certainty. They provide a positive inducement for Australians to save through superannuation, and the government will not be swayed by the opportunistic and vacuous arguments which the Opposition has put to the House tonight. I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 8-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 9, page 15, omit proposed section 281, substitute the following section:
Assessable income to include taxable contributions

`` `281. Subject to section 275, the assessable income of a complying superannuation fund of a year of income shall only comprise taxable contributions made to a fund in a year of income and the special income in the year of income.''.
(2) Clause 9, page 17, omit proposed section 290, substitute the following section:
Assessable income to comprise only taxable contributions and special income

`` `290. Subject to section 275, the assessable income of a complying ADF of a year of income shall only comprise the taxable contributions made to the fund in the year of income and the special income in the year of income.''.

The amendments will effectively excise the 15 per cent tax on investment funds as they will be applied to superannuation funds. The purpose of the amendments is to ensure that millions of superannuants' end benefits will not be reduced and to ensure that superannuation remains a viable retirement savings alternative. We have just heard the Minister's response to my speech in the second reading debate, in which I covered in some detail the essence of these observations. For the benefit of the Committee I emphasise again quite clearly, so that there can be no doubt at all in the Minister's mind, that contrary to the advice given to him it is utterly absurd to suggest that dividend imputation, if the changes we propose are in place, will somehow or other be lost. Surely, logic dictates that if we are removing a tax we do not need dividend imputation. The whole purpose of the Government's imputation arrangements was to lessen the tax and to transfer it to other tax credits.

If we remove the tax as we are proposing in this amendment, clearly the observation made by the Minister is logically unsustainable. I seek his advice on that matter; no doubt he will give it in due course. The reason we are moving this amendment is quite simple. This package of Bills contains three new tax points. They were first advised in May of last year. Here we are 12 months later and the legislation is not yet through the chamber. It has been subject to only four days advice on this very complex area of policy because the Government chooses to force the issue, despite the delay of some 12 months.

Industry, in particular, is desperately concerned to get this matter sorted out one way or the other. The Minister has been happy to come into the chamber and give us quotations from the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd about this attitude. Other organisations, such as the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia Ltd, have been arguing for months, supported by other companies such as the Australian Mutual Provident Society, which have also argued for months, that the application of a 15 per cent tax on dividend income is not only extremely expensive to administer, but also is at a cost to individual contributors to superannuation.

The point I emphasised in my speech on the second reading motion and which I now re-emphasise is that, contrary to what the Government bothered to tell the million-odd people who have recently gone into 3 per cent productivity schemes, because of the imposition of this tax, virtually all of those people will be losers. It stands to reason that if the bases of their schemes are to be subject to a level of tax which prior to this was not in place, clearly their end benefits will be less.

I have already tabled in the House the most detailed analysis that has been conducted in this area. It demonstrates beyond doubt that in virtually every category of superannuation coverage there are a significant number of losers, despite the commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that not one beneficiary would be worse off by 1c. The fact of the matter is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was less than truthful in his observations on that matter. Maybe he was led astray. Maybe he just got carried away by the rhetoric of the moment. These changes will involve losers. As an Opposition which is responsible in this matter, we hold the Government to account. It is no good hiding behind situations and trying to obfuscate and alter the basis of the debate. The fact is that we have 3.2 million people, at least, in superannuation schemes. The Opposition is desperately interested in getting as wide a coverage for superannuation as possible. However, there is no way it can seriously be argued that an end benefit of somewhere between $18 and $20 a week-which is precisely what we get from 3 per cent of average weekly earnings-is in any sense an adequate basis to sustain financial independence in retirement.

What we are all about is giving the millions of people with superannuation and the millions of people who do not yet have any form of superannuation, access to a range of products which will enable them to achieve some greater degree of financial independence in their retirement. On that point at least the Government and the Opposition appear to be at one. Therefore, I find it most offensive that the Minister at the table should come in here and allege that somehow or other we represent the top end of town-to use his expression-when the amendments we are moving tonight are specifically directed at helping the hundreds of thousands of low to middle income earners who, under normal circumstances, have great difficulty in achieving adequate financial support for their retirement outside the pension system. The Government shares with us-at least in its verbal capacity if not in reality-the belief that we must, for the sake of future generations of Australians, do what we can to reduce access to pensions for those who do not need them or to those who have alternative sources of financial support. The obvious and the logical outcome of that policy initiative must be that while people are in the work force they must be given adequate incentive and opportunity to save through superannuation so that when they receive their retirement package at approximately 55 years of age, or later, they will have an appropriate level of financial independence.

The Minister made the point, as did other Government speakers, which I underline and support, that we cannot indefinitely, with the ageing of the Australian population, find ourselves in a situation where people believe that there is an incentive in not saving for tomorrow in the belief that, because they claim they have a right to a pension, regardless of their assets, in future days it will not really matter because somebody else-the taxpayers of tomorrow-will carry the load. To approach policy with that belief is to sell this nation short and fail in this Parliament to represent the reality that we have to plan for the Australians of tomorrow and for those who are not even born. It will be their generation, and our children's generation, who will have to carry the cost of our retirement income in another 20 or 30 years time. It is short-sighted in the extreme to regard superannuation as yet another milch cow. The Minister made the observation saying, `This amendment will rip the guts out of the $1.4 billion tax base in this arrangement'.

I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that in the Treasurer's announcement on this matter he claimed that in a full financial year the total tax from those three new tax points will be $1.4 billion. We are talking about a major reform to one of them. We are talking about removing from the legislation the second tax point. We are not talking about removing the first, which is the tax on contributions, because that is worth at lest $1 billion. I interpolate here to say that the Government has not yet had the courtesy to tell us its precise estimates for the tax fall in those three specific points. Nevertheless, it is reasonable to assume that the first tax point will be the major one. It is the cheapest one to administer. It is the easiest one for funds to apply. It is of minimum cost to contributors. Therefore, we live with that particular tax arrangement.

We are trying to amend the third tax point. That will be the subject of a later address by me when I speak to that proposed amendment. On the second tax point, which is a tax on investment income, the fact is that the estimates we have been given are as low as $20 million and as high as $120 million or $150 million-we do not know exactly what the tax base will be. Perhaps the Minister will tell us. One thing is sure: every cent of that amount is being taken from the contributions and from the benefits which have accrued to the superannuation funds of millions of Australian workers-not just of the top end of town, as the Minister claims. What is so pathetic about this particular approach is that by removing revenue from the centre, the Government will be effectively reducing its final tax on the lump sums at the end. Not satisfied with that, the Government will apply a third tax to what is left. As I said, I will have more to say about that in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) made great play of the 3 per cent superannuation. I remind him that that was an initiative of this Government. His government had no concern for superannuation for the less well off in the community, for lower to middle income earners. Now, through some piece of opportunism, the Opposition seeks to express its concern. Let me go back to what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) actually said, as distinct from what the honourable member for Bradfield has just said. All I have to do is refer to page 3228 of Hansard of 3 June 1988. I quote the Treasurer's words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it will allow the Government to bring forward nearly $1 billion of its own tax money . . .
This change in superannuation has two parts to it: a bring-forward of the 1983 deferred tax arrangements and the tax of 15 per cent on the funds. I repeat the Treasurer's words:
. . . it will allow the Government to bring forward nearly $1 billion of its own tax money-now lying in superannuation funds-
not contributors' money, but the Government's money-
without diminishing any personal end-benefit by one cent.

That is absolutely true; it is correct. It has been endorsed by every member of the industry-the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd, the AMP Society, and every actuary. The only person who has got it wrong is the honourable member for Bradfield. Yesterday I sent him a note about 10 errors, with 10 replies to his errors. The Treasurer went on to say:
The Government has therefore decided to bring superannuation funds within the full ambit of the imputation system, giving them access to dividend tax credits.
To achieve this a tax of 15 per cent will apply to fund earnings.
But this 15 per cent tax can be neutralised or offset by the receipt of dividend tax credits.

It is also quite clear that the honourable member has great difficulty in understanding my earlier remark that the fund, by change of its portfolio, can derive considerable tax credits from the imputation system. He does not seem to understand the change in the composition of its investment portfolio. If he does understand it, he deliberately avoids it in the course of his comments. As I indicated earlier, I do not want to drag everybody on. The Government rejects the amendment.

``(2) Where:
(a) if paragraph (1) (a) applies-the order of the court was made before 1 December 1988; or
(b) if paragraph (1) (b) applies-the cancellation of the shares took place before 1 December 1988;
the following provisions have effect:

(c) if the adjusted market value, referred to in subsection 159gzzzf (1) of the amended Act, in relation to the shares exceeds the consideration in respect of the acquisition of the shares then, for the purposes of the application of the amended Act (other than Part IIIa or section 159gzzzh) in relation to the cancellation:

(i) paragraph 159gzzzf (1) (c) of the amended Act has effect as if the reference in that paragraph to the adjusted market value of the shares were instead a reference to the amount of the consideration; and

(ii) paragraph 159gzzzf (1) (d) of the amended Act has effect as if the reference in that paragraph to an amount being increased so that it equals the adjusted market value of the shares were instead a reference to that amount being increased or decreased so that it equals the amount of the consideration;

(d) if the adjusted market value, referred to in subsection 159gzzzf (1) of the amended Act, in relation to the shares exceeds their indexed cost base to the subsidiary concerned or, where the shares were cancelled within 12 months of their acquisition, their cost base then, for the purposes of the application of Part IIIA of the amended Act in relation to the cancellation:

(i) paragraph 159gzzzf (1) (c) of the amended Act has effect as if the reference in that paragraph to the adjusted market value of the shares were instead a reference to the indexed cost base or cost base, as the case may be; and

(ii) paragraph 159gzzzf(1) (d) of the amended Act has effect as if the reference in that paragraph to an amount being increased so that it equals the adjusted market value of the shares were instead a reference to that amount being increased or decreased so that it equals the indexed cost base or the cost base, as the case may be.
``(3) Expressions used in paragraph (2) (d) that are also used in Part IIIA of the amended Act have the same respective meanings in that paragraph as in that Part.
``(4) In this section:
`amended Act' means the Principal Act as amended by this Act.''.

The amendment relates to measures contained in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1988 which prevent an undue reduction in tax liability where a holding company cancels for less than market value shares in itself that are held by a subsidiary company. The Government has decided to introduce a transitional measure to modify the legislation as it applies to a share cancellation that occurred after the date of the announcement of the legislation and on or before the date of its introduction into the House, that is, after 11 August 1988 and on or before 30 November 1988.

By this amendment, when shares held by a subsidiary and its holding company are cancelled, the subsidiary will be deemed to have received the lesser of the market value of the shares at the time of cancellation or the amount of any consideration given by the subsidiary company for the acquisition of the shares. If the capital gains provisions apply to the shares, the subsidiary will be taken to have received the lesser of their market value or their indexed cost based to the subsidiary or their cost base if the cancellation is within 12 months of the acquisition of the shares.

Broadly, this will ensure that the income tax position of the subsidiary is the same as it would have been had the shares been cancelled or otherwise disposed of for their cost price, or in the case of capital gains, for their indexed cost base or cost base as the case may be. The result of the amendment will be that in the period between the date of announcement and the date following the introduction of the legislation, the share cancellation provisions simply operate in line with the announcement of 11 August 1988. I commend the amendment to the Committee. In doing so, I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum which explains the amendment in more detail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing the amendment, although I wish to make some comments about the nature of the amendment, which has been brought on fairly quickly, at least to my attention. We will be giving it closer examination. If we have any further comments to make they will be made in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that concerns me most is that this is another one of those unintended consequences of the haste with which this Government introduces ideas into the public domain and then delays their implementation by way of legislation. This process of legislation by press release has been characteristic of most of the Bills that are before the House. One of the most untenable situations to my mind has arisen in relation to the superannuation legislation which became effective in July last year and where trustees, fund managers, superannuants and others had to operate in a situation where they had no idea what the legislation would look like. This amendment is in a similar vein.

As I understand it, the amendment deals with an unintended consequence. As originally drafted the legislation contained a retrospective element. I am not surprised that we find it containing phrases like, `a transitional measure to modify the legislation', and a whole host of what is gobbledegook about the nature of the valuation of share transactions simply to mask the fact that there was a significant element of retrospectivity in the legislation as drafted which I gather arose as a result of this matter being drawn to the attention of the Government by one of the parties concerned. I hope that the Government has learnt something from this episode-that it should not go off half-cocked in terms of major pieces of tax legislation. It should not rely on the process of taxation by press release. It should not move until, in most cases, it is in a position to put the legislation into place in a meaningful form.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make one important observation in relation to capital gains in the context of this legislation. We are not moving a specific amendment in respect of capital gains. However, it is effectively taken care of by virtue of the earlier amendment that I moved which, regrettably, the Committee did not see fit to support. I want it to be recorded that the capital gains tax proposals are totally inequitable as they cause inequities in the treatment of individual unit holders in a fund depending on when they deposit or withdraw their funds from an approved deposit fund (ADF) or a superannuation fund. Therefore, on efficiency and equity grounds alone the capital gains proposals are seen as being unworkable and, in addition, they will result in higher fees and therefore fewer benefits to contributors. For that reason, as I said, we believe that the capital gains provisions are completely unacceptable to the Opposition and, of course, in government we would excise them from the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —If any member of the Government believed in even half of the rhetoric on this superannuation package of legislation he would be voting with the Opposition on this side of the chamber. Much has been said tonight by the Minister at the table claiming that we on this side of the chamber are interested only in the upper end of business, ignoring the fact that the very substance of this reform is directed at helping the ordinary, average, and lower income families in Australia. The purpose of this reform is to increase the current threshold of $60,000, above which a tax of 16.25 per cent will be applied, to $125,000, above which that tax will be applied.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are simply meaning to do is increase the sum to the appropriate amount equivalent to what it costs the Australian taxpayer to fund a married couple through a reasonable period of life in retirement. We have taken the national average of life expectancy, we have multiplied that by the appropriate annual pension, and the amount we have come up with is approximately $125,000. If the Government members are truthful about their rhetoric and really believe the objective of this legislation which they claim to be that people should have greater financial independence in retirement, how is it that the Government can apply yet another, a third onerous tax of 16.25 per cent, including Medicare levy, to people who have lump sum payments in excess of $60,000?

The Minister at the table made the observation that, last financial year, less than one half of one per cent of people had superannuation lump sum benefits in excess of $50,000. What are we here to debate-the past or the future? What are we here to try to establish in Australian law-a set of principles that will encourage people to have greater financial independence in the future or is the Government prepared to put, in legislation, the onerous controls which will ensure that hundreds of thousands of people will continue to depend on the pension in the future? And why? Because Government members, in their small minds, are unable to appreciate the relationship between incentive and tax and, until they understand that basic principle, they will never be able to succeed in any area of taxation law and certainly not in superannuation.

By lifting, as we propose, the threshold from $60,000 to $125,000 Government members are sending a signal to every worker, to every manager, to every person who is able to save for his retirement and, hopefully, the hundreds of thousands of people who, because of the Government's taxation arrangements, simply say it is not worth their while to do so, that we want across the board in all parties in this Parliament as close a level of universality of coverage as possible. But, as I said in my speech in the second reading debate and as I repeat, in their small-minded approach they are regarding superannuation as yet another taxable milch cow and have missed the whole purpose of their legislation, which is to ensure that people have greater financial independence in their retirement.

I do not wish to take up the time of the Committee at this late hour, I wish simply to implore and beseech Government members opposite that here is their opportunity to stand up and let the Australian people in their millions know that in the future we do not want their children to be saddled with massive social security debts because of an ageing population, that we want people to have greater freedom in their retirement. The only effective way of achieving that is by ensuring that from the time people first enter the work force they start putting aside a measurable amount of money on a regular basis, which will multiply over the years and give them a measure of real independence when they finally retire. The Government has not achieved that in its 3 per cent productivity schemes. It has not achieved that in the passage of these Bills through this chamber tonight. But I assure the Government that the Opposition parties here and in another place will maintain their rage and their interest in the welfare of the Australian people, because if the Government is not going to look after them, it is certainly our duty to do so. I formally move:
Clause 26, page 43, lines 16 and 17, omit proposed paragraph 159 SG (1) (c), substitute the following paragraph:
``(c) in relation to the year of income commencing on 1 July 1988-$125,000; or''.
