SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking from a somewhat unfamiliar position in this chamber, I can tell honourable members that the world looks a little more distant, but no more distant than the practicalities of development in Australia under the concept, as the Government puts it, of a Resource Assessment Commission. We know that the Government itself is a bit of a sham and is labouring under significant difficulties. We know that in the reality of the marketplace those who run around with vocal minorities, wave banners and get their images on television and their voices on radio-and occasionally their names in print-are people who significantly frustrate the development and growth of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted to see that my dear friend and old colleague the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren)-battle scarred though he might be-at least had the courage of his convictions. Sadly, the members of the Government do not have that same forthrightness or ability to present their arguments knowing that nobody really senses that they believe what they say. The Resource Assessment Commission Bill is what might be called the Graham Richardson palliative, for if I have seen anybody who, as a latter day greenie, is more inept at presenting what is genuinely a requirement by all of us in Australia that our basic natural resources be protected, it is the person who, for the moment, is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

This Bill is designed to try and somehow put in place a device which the Government says is going to keep the Graham at bay, to keep somehow his interventionary practice from frustrating the decisions of State governments which properly have responsibility for land use in Australia. This Bill has not been introduced because people genuinely believe that in some way it will facilitate the development of new projects. This Bill will not make it easy for those who are prepared to invest shareholders' money and taxpayers' money in order to develop. This Bill is designed to ensure that the Government does not have to take decisions. It is designed to ensure that minority groups will not be beating at its door with poor old `prevarication Bob' finding it hard to know which way to swing. This Bill has been introduced because the Government sees that it is going to help it get through a bit of political problem.

We know that the Government is not bad at trying to face political problems. After all, it has had more than a few little difficulties with the third runway at Mascot. The Government is not doing too well when it comes to trying to persuade the electors of Tasmania that the Tasmanian Government should not be returned. In fact, from what I can see, Robin Gray has run a great campaign and I look forward to being able to work with him when a coalition government is elected here. Similarly, I must admit that the Labor Party is not doing too well in the State seat of Merthyr. I will be interested on Saturday to see the result up there. In case Labor members have forgotten, we have a pretty good National Party in Queensland. The Labor Government here is finding it harder and harder to try and get people in Merthyr to accept that Mr Goss and his ilk need support.

With this Resource Assessment Commission Bill, as in Merthyr and in Tasmania, we have a Government trying to avoid taking hard decisions and facing up to the responsibility for where it goes. I say to the people in the Parliament: we need to comprehend something of the difficulties that face the Government. I know that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and the Minister for Resources (Mr Cook) have found these super ministries a little too tough a nut to handle. The Australian Financial Review of 14 February reports that the relationship has deteriorated badly over the reshuffle of the responsibilities between the two key resource industry Ministers. We thought that was just an occasional shaft-a few honourable members have had one or two from me in the past and will continue to enjoy the same in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop being personal!
—The honourable member should not worry-we will be on the other side of the House and a few honourable members opposite will be over here.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that according to the Sydney Morning Herald the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, decided he would use an Australian Petroleum Exploration Association conference to tell the world that the oil and gas industries are paying too much secondary tax. I found that very interesting because we know that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy thought that was his bailiwick, and the poor old Treasurer must have thought, `I thought secondary taxation was mine'. Senator Cook-and bully for him-thought, `It might be a good idea if I let everybody know that I am going to get out there and battle for them'. The only problem is that, having made that speech, he has been put under wraps and nobody knows when anything will happen. I commend him for at least recognising that secondary taxation in the oil and gas industries is, frankly, far too high and is causing enormous difficulties.

We have a device that is designed to avoid some of the complications in resource development in this country. It is also important to note that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories tells us, on the one hand, that he did not want to push for the Wesley Vale development but that, on the other, there was worry about adverse balance of payments problems. When the Government looked at Wesley Vale Senator Button said, `It would be great if Australia could process the pulp here. We have the resources, and it would generate jobs'. They seem pretty natural sorts of measures that a State government would want to encourage. One might even think that occasionally Federal Labor Government Ministers might think that jobs for the working men and women of Australia were perhaps worth supporting, but not so our environment Minister.

Nobody on this side of the House denies the impact of the pollution that may or may not have occurred from a pulp mill. Nor is it a fact that as far as we are concerned there should not be a proper appraisal of the environmental impact. Certainly, we are concerned about the effect on the fishing industry and about the general effect on the environment. But we are also worried that, as far as Senator Richardson is concerned, he remembered at the very last minute that we have a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation should be involved. One would think that even members of the Labor Party would know of the existence of the CSIRO. After all, they have done their best to destroy it. I commend the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), the Opposition spokesman on energy, science and matters relating to the CSIRO, for the way in which he has identified the progressive cuts masterminded by that great political strategist Neville Wran, as Chairman of the CSIRO, and implemented by poor old Barry Jones, whose science statement this week was supposed to be the great green light for the development of scientific resources in Australia. Frankly, it was a bit like a damp fish-a bit like my friend opposite, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). Every time I look at him I think of what would happen if we had a bait on the end of the hook.

The trouble is that if Senator Richardson thought CSIRO was the right body to bring in, he did not bring it when the project was first developed. He did not go to the State Government and say, `We understand you have the land use responsibility. We know you want to create employment. But we would like to bring in the CSIRO to help you with the development of an environmental impact study'. No; that would be a far too rational approach for the Federal Government. What did the Federal Government do? It waited until the eleventh hour. The State Government had been coming and going, trying hard to reach a compromise between what it thought everybody wanted and development. Probably, it foolishly listened to Senator Button and thought that he meant it when he said, `We want development in Australia'. But Senator Richardson same in at the eleventh hour.

Our objection to the Federal Government's intervention is that it ought to be able to make up its mind and not listen to every two bob group in the community that tell people they have something to worry about. Frankly, I believe that the environment Minister's intervention was probably the catalyst for this piece of legislation. The Resource Assessment Commission Bill is designed to ensure that the environment Minister is not embarrassed by last-minute interruption to a major development proposal. It is fairly important that people in the resource industry understand that this Bill will not help them.

Sadly, but naturally, many of my friends in AMEC and in the Australian Forestry Council, who are looking to develop Australian industry, are saying, `We think this would be a great idea but we do not know how the devil to get through to these Labor people. This is the way the Government might be able to get some decisions out of them'. If the Government can tell me why it wants another layer of bureaucracy in Australia, why it wants somebody to stop the Government making decisions, why it wants to create a body which has no real responsibility, where the States, which have prime land use, are denied a voice in selecting special commissioners, why it wants a group that is constituted not to facilitate objections to development, then it has another thought coming.

The Resource Assessment Commission is not going to achieve what the developers, naturally, want. The developers, who are trying to do something about the chronic adverse balance of payments situation, want decisions made. They want a government that is prepared to get up and say, when a proposition is advanced, `These are the criteria we want you to meet. It is not an environmental problem. These are the ground rules. These are the obligations'. If the Federal Government is speaking to a State government it should say, `We are going to work with you'. We would prefer it if the State government did the environmental impact statement. We believe that there is a role where the Commonwealth and the States can surely at least talk to each other. We know that is hard. We saw what the poor old Minister for Primary Industries and Energy did to the wheat Bills. What has happened to the complementary legislation that successively, over the years, coalition Ministers seemed to be able to negotiate?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not what we did to the wheat Bills; it is what the wheat Bills did to you.

—I think that the wheat Bills have done a great deal for me. They have enabled me to tell the people of Australia that 90 per cent of what the National Party wanted it has achieved. That is far more than the honourable member is going to achieve in the seat of Denison in his short term life in this Parliament. I will be interested to see the result of the Tasmanian State election on Saturday. I wish Robin Gray well.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill does not provide, therefore, for the proper, rational balance between Federal and State governments. It does not facilitate decisions, and therefore it should not be supported. People need to put the frustrations that developers in Australia feel against some of the headlines about declining oil availability, for example. There is one in the Sydney Morning Herald of 2 May that interested me, `Oil deficit heads for $10m a day'.

People need to understand that Labor has increased the degree to which our Budget each year provides for interest payments that are now second in outgoings. Our overseas debt and our chronic balance of payments are realising an aspiration of the Treasurer for the banana republic status that he mentioned some time ago. With the oil deficit heading for $10m a day, why does the Government want another layer of bureaucracy? Why is it employing another group of people to stop it making decisions? It would be a good idea to lay down the guidelines. Where are the guidelines for Wesley Vale? Months after the whole thing has been shelved and another one seems to be developing, why can the Government not tell the community what it wants? It cannot do so because it decided it would set up another body. It wants another bureaucracy and a few more jobs. If the Government thinks that is good for Australia, then what the devil is the Government about?

There is a problem. Australia has run up a petroleum trade deficit of $413m this year. That is a little more than $1m a day. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 2 May forecasts that within the next few years it will be as high as $10m a day. By the end of this century it will be 10 times worse than it is today. The deficit will be $3.7 billion a year.

This Bill seeks to make it harder and harder for the oil industry, for those who are involved in oil exploration, for members of the Australian Pipeline Industry Association, to do something. If the Government is going to have all these interventionary processes people have to understand that that is the price of Labor. Have they thought of all the millions who work under the guy who sits in the box seat occasionally in this House? They ought to look at what he suddenly tries to do when he thinks that the populist cry requires his intervention. It was reported in the Australian Financial Review on 5 May that Mr Silver Hair himself had voiced his strong opposition to mining Antarctica. I would be delighted if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said a bit about mining in Australia, if he expressed a few views about development in Australia and if he did not create a Resource Assessment Commission designed to avoid his having to take decisions.

The statistics are pretty worrying throughout the mining field. The Bureau of Mineral Resources has given projections of mineral resource exports between the year 1988 and the year 2000. One would think that it would know a little about what was going on. The rate of growth in export revenue between 1980 and 1988 was 100 per cent. In 1988 export revenue amounted to $17.2 billion. It will rise to only $21.5 billion in the year 2000, a growth of 1.9 per cent. I think that is appalling. In other words, what has happened in the last eight years is that, taking benefit of the policies we introduced, the Labor Party has been able to benefit and Australia's exports have benefited by a growth of $9.2 billion to $17.2 billion. Between now and the end of the century they will go up by only 1.9 per cent. I ask why this has happened.

Some honourable members might have attended the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC) conference last week. The guest speaker was the Prime Minister. He did not say very much about how his Government is going to try to facilitate growth and development and he did not say very much about how the new mineral resources will be developed. Even the Treasurer did not say anything to us about the balance of payments or when he will redress the situation. I think that people need to understand that the Resource Assessment Commission will frustrate the position even further.

If honourable members thought that that area is bad, they should look at the industrial record. The Prime Minister has claimed to have done many things for Australia. He has said, `Things have been quite out there in the industrial environment. The ACTU loves us and we love it. It is a great little happy band of brothers'. The only difficulty is that if we look at the industrial area and the mining area, what do we find? `Strikes take highest toll since start of the accord', says the Australian Financial Review of 4 May. The biggest percentage increases over the figures for the previous year occurred in coal mining, 73.2 per cent; other mining, 65.8 per cent; and metal products, machinery and equipment manufacturing, 56.8 per cent. What is the Government doing? The Government says, `We are going to help you make decisions. We are introducing another body, the Resource Assessment Commission. We are not getting rid of the strikes'. The strikes take place because the Government really has not addressed fundamentally the failure of the accord. The Government has not deregulated the labour market. The poor old wheat cocky can have this lot. The Government does not worry about the guys who are really causing problems for Australia-the members of the trade union movement that the Labor Party needs to survive. I do not think it is good enough, and the Resource Assessment Commission is not good enough either.

If honourable members thought that that is bad enough, we have another area that affects all this development-the amount of land that is locked away. If honourable members look at the AMIC report of 1988, they will find that conservation parks, reserves and other areas, not including marine parks, take up 5.6 per cent of the available area in Australia. Aboriginal owned or controlled land, including land under claim in the Northern Territory, not including national parks, takes up 14.1 per cent. Land subject to owner veto in Western Australia and possible future problems in the Northern Territory, Tasmania and Queensland, not including Aboriginal land, takes up 3.3 per cent. Other areas, including defence ranges and training areas, all of the Australian Capital Territory, restrictive coastal zones and some urban areas, et cetera, take up 0.5 per cent. Future wilderness areas proposed by conservation interests not including areas in existing parks, reserves and areas already restricted are foreshadowed to take up another 11 per cent, and we are told that land subject to future veto and conservation areas take up another 22.2 per cent.

What is happening to Australia? We have a device here, a Bill that is designed to put in another intervening process. There is no power in that Bill to do anything about unlocking land. There is nothing in this Bill about looking at who has the rights for land use or how we will overcome the areas of Australia that are locked up. We are not saying that the Government should not exclusively reserve some types of land. We are saying that it is important that people understand in Australia that we have a chronic adverse balance of payments problem. We are saying that it is important to get a balance between protecting the environment and proper development considerations. We are saying that multiple land use is possible in Australia. We are saying that the Government should approach this subject rationally and make decisions as a government. It should recognise that some areas must be locked away, but it should recognise equally that in relation to some of the areas that potentially could be locked away as well as some of the areas that are now locked away it is denying any opportunity for profitable development and any opportunity to generate more export revenue. Frankly, the sooner this Government realises that the more we get into hock the more our living standards fall, and the more our living standards fall the more the Australian people suffer, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could lock some of them away too.

—It would be a good idea. That is probably a very sensible suggestion. What will be the first reference to this inquiry? It will of course, be the forestry industry. I support the proposition that there should be some rational examination of the forestry industry, but why the devil does the Government have to set up another body to do it? I do not know whether honourable members opposite understand that in the past few years imports of forest products have been consistently valued at approximately $1.5 billion, whilst exports have been valued at about $400m. That is not just a statement out of the blue, it is contained in a press statement made by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) on 9 December last year. I find it fascinating. This concerns an industry in relation to which people are saying, `You know, it is pretty nasty out there cutting trees. Gee, it is bad to see an industry that has existed since the establishment of white settlement in Australia, an industry which has contributed thousands of millions of dollars in income over the years, which generates employment for so many people. It is terrible to let that industry survive!'. What did the lot opposite do in relation to north Queensland? The industry in north Queensland has been managed effectively and well. If there is need for change, sure, we can talk about it where it is needed. But the Government is locking up enormous areas, and never mind the consequences.
—Cut them down overseas.

—Precisely. It has led to the desecration of many of the jungles and forests in lands where governments cannot afford to say no, where environmental considerations do not matter. What is the Government going to do? It will set up a resource inquiry. It will not in any way prevent the making of an environmental impact statement, it will set up another forum, another bureaucracy, another layer so that the poor old Government cannot be forced to make decisions. It is not good enough. It is not as though things are too certain even in our mining industry. The Minister for Resources has told us that the world iron ore industry has been badly squeezed in the past few years. We know what has happened to steel demand and we know about the variations in coal prices. We know all the problems that exist out there, and I think it is about time the Government did something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: As to this side of the House, our resources policy is designed to address the decline in petroleum self-sufficiency; encourage the discovery, appraisal and development of our resource base; encourage conservation measures in the use of energy; encourage the use of renewable energy resources; support measures which add value to our resources; improve the efficiency of mineral and energy industries; develop an internationally competitive and reliable export sector; and facilitate Australia's access to international markets-and we are actually going to take the decisions that should be taken by government. We are not going to set up another body to do it. I think Australia will be much better off as a result.

I was interested a while ago to read a statement by Senator Richardson about encouraging uranium exports. We know that the Government has decided that it is not going to get rid of the three mines policy until after the next election. We also know that the Government is not going to do anything about removing full price controls. However, we will. We also know that it is about time the Government did something to lift the three mine policy. It does not mean in any way that we will remove adequate environmental controls and international safeguards, it means that we will the industry to compete in a market in which, as all we know, prices are fairly depressed at the moment. We know that there are problems. However, the Government has denied those mining companies the right even to explore for markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much for deregulation.

—So much for deregulation, as my colleague says. I think it is about time the Government understood what it was all about. For those reasons, we on this side of the House oppose the Bill. In order that the whole of the nature of our objections can be understood more clearly, I want to take a somewhat unusual course, which I gather has not been taken in this House for a while. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`the House declines to give the Bill a second reading as it is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for-

(1) its prevarication over major national development projects where minority viewpoints have been allowed to prejudice a rational balance between valid environmental concerns and development proposals and delay Government decisions;
(2) its failure to recognise land use as properly the responsibility of State and Northern Territory Governments;
(3) not providing an explicit role for the States in the Resource Assessment proposal;
(4) failing to ensure consultation with the States before the appointment of special Commissioners to the Resource Assessment Commission;
(5) using the Resource Assessment Commission concept to atone for public reaction against the Government's last minute intervention on the Wesley Vale Pulp Mill; and

(6) providing yet another layer between development applications and Government approval to the detriment of proposals designed to a ameliorate Australia's chronic balance of payments problems through their contribution to Australian export revenue and in offsetting domestic imports.'

That amendment, in a few short words, says the Bill is not much good, the concept is lousy, and we cannot see any reason to introduce yet another layer of bureaucracy to try to help the Government avoid taking decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the motion.
—The honourable member for Gilmore cannot second the motion as he is not in his proper place.
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very interesting to see that little bit of confusion in the National Party of Australia. We do not know who is speaking, who is the leader, or who seconds the amendments. It is always good to speak after our new backbencher, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). I am glad to welcome him up here. I notice I am closer to the front bench than he is, so I doubt he will ever get back. However, I saw he had one eye open, keeping it on the new stud who has arrived, the new Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt).
—That is offensive.

—I am sorry. The right honourable member for New England spoke a bit like the old bull in the back paddock who has been disposed of by the new bull. The new leader was a bit late coming in to listen to the old Leader of the National Party. He was not here for the first five minutes of the right honourable member's speech. It was interesting that his first speech as a backbencher was on the environment. Maybe that represents the greening of the National Party. I hope so, but with the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) around, I do not know.

SPEECH.PARA: The right honourable member for New England whinged a lot about the establishment of the Resource Assessment Commission. He said it would restrict the miners and the oil companies from going about their business of exploiting Australia. He said that approximately 40 per cent of Australia was locked away from the exploiters. The Australian Minerals and Energy Council (AMEC) must have had its figures mixed up somehow to have come to that sort of a determination. The right honourable member for New England then moved:
. . . the House declines to give the Bill a second reading as it is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned. . .
His amendment went on to list those matters for which he considered the Government should be condemned.

I bring to the notice of the House a press release by the Liberal Party of Australia on its environmental policy. It is from Senator Christopher Puplick, who I think is the shadow Minister for the environment. It is dated 21 November 1988, and: is headed, `Coalition's new policy adopted by Labor'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is No. 3 on the ticket.
—I have heard that he is No. 3 on the ticket. The press release reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The announcement that the Labor Government will establish a new body, the Resources Assessment Commission, represents a major triumph from the Federal Coalition. . .

Can I be reading it correctly? Yes; the Press release does have the shadow Minister, Christopher Puplick, saying the Labor Government's move is a triumph for the Federal coalition. The statement continues:
The decision to establish a Resources Assessment Commission picks up several of the Coalition's new policy proposals, specifically those related to:
environment and economic impact statements;
land inventory proposals and assessments;
prior evaluation and resolution of environmental disputes; and
the need for formalised decision making processes to replace ad hoc responses to every dispute or crisis.
Do not forget that this is not a member of the Australian Labor Party speaking. It is Senator Christopher Puplick the shadow Minister for the environment. He went on to say:
In picking up these Coalition policies I have no doubt the quality of environment policy decision making will be much improved, and this is to be welcomed for Australia's sake.

This was said on 21 November 1988. Here we have a complete flip flop once again. We have had this with the coalition leader, so I suppose this is a change in their policy. The coalition was all for this just a few short months ago, but here they have turned around. It is strange how the conservative parties work. If the Opposition can see some advantage somewhere it will go for it. I think that probably the AMEC or some such body has given the wink and the nod knowing that there is an election coming up. In today's Australian newspaper there is the heading `Opposition rejects environment body'. The article states:
The Federal Opposition decided yesterday . . .
That must have been 9 May. That was an interesting sort of a day. There were lots of changes. The Opposition must have thought this was important.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder when they found time to discuss it.

—I do not know when members of the Opposition found time to discuss it. The honourable member is right. There would have been many little meetings. Someone must have snuck it through. I think the ex-leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England, got it wrong. Maybe this did not get through yesterday's caucus meeting of the Liberals and the Nationals. Somebody must have snuck it in.
—This is a bit like Blue Hills.
—Yes. There is something wrong somewhere. I think someone just snuck it in. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Opposition decided yesterday to oppose the government's proposed Resource Assessment Commission (RAC), which would be established to tone down contentious environmental issues.
Coalition sources-
we have had a lot of coalition sources leaking information to our Party, giving us a few niceties about what is going on in their caucus room-
said the Opposition also had opposed the RAC because it represented an attempt by ministers to `walk away' from difficult land use decisions.

Three or four months ago the coalition was supporting this measure and now it is walking away from it. I wish the Opposition would make up its mind and let us know exactly what it thinks about the environment. The backbencher, the right honourable member for New England, made the point that the Resource Assessment Commission would install another level of bureaucracy. The Resource Assessment Commission is an independent body. It cannot be termed as another level of bureaucracy. It will be lean and mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many people will be on it?

—There is one chairman and he can coopt other people. The honourable member said that the Resource Assessment Commission will override the rights of the States. It does not intend to override State's rights. The States have been informed of the RAC's intentions and progress on details from the beginning. The States are being offered the opportunity to have further discussions. As the RAC is modelled on the Industries Assistance Commission, there will be ample opportunity for the States to contribute to the final advice through the process of consultation which is practised extensively on this side of the House. As we know, it is not practiced on the other side of the House. The right honourable member for New England said that establishing the Commission is an attempt by the Minister to walk away from difficult land use decisions. He said that the RAC will provide independent advice to the Government on difficult decisions. The final decisions on these matters will still be made by the Government. The right honourable member said that the RAC is a mechanism to prevent undue influence where vested interests have high stakes in the results of land use decisions. I could go on a lot about this legislation, but I realise that many people are waiting to retire for the evening. However, I would like to raise a couple of things that the Liberals do when they get into power. Let us have a quick look at what has happened in New South Wales without this Resource Assessment Commission. A heading in a newspaper reads, `Greiner to defy Canberra on logging'

SPEECH.PARA: The article states:
The Greiner Government yesterday threatened to defy Canberra in National Estate forests.
The New South Wales Minister for National Resources, Mr Causley, put the Federal Government on notice he would allow sawlogging of the forests-even if Canberra prevented woodchipping.

In the short time he has been in office, Mr Greiner has broken more than 100 promises. I do not have a couple of hours to list them all; they just go on and on. However, there was one promise that he did keep. He was elected probably on this one promise, and he has kept it. He promised that he would abolish two great national parks-Tantawangalo and Coolangubra, and he is about to try to do that. These parks were of course set up by Bob Carr, the great Labor leader in New South Wales and a great environmentalist. I have heard many of his speeches. He is also a good bush walker. I have read a little bit about him and I enjoy bush walking myself. The only way that one can really appreciate what goes on in our forests is by going and having a look. This same Minister, Mr Causley-

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he a National?

—I do not know what he is, but he probably is a National. They are all usually the same. A heading in the Australian Financial Review says `Crack heads, says minister'. The article under that heading says:

SPEECH.PARA: A NSW minister has urged the forest industry to `crack political heads' and make political threats to ensure its victory over conservationists.
The article was quoting Mr Causley, the Minister for Natural Resources. It went on:
Mr Causley said the timber industry now had a fighting chance to win its battle against conservationists-due to the solid political support it was receiving from the Greiner Government.

The Greiner Government is backing the extortionists who are threatening poor conservationists who are fighting to save this planet. Through the power of big business those people are trying to threaten and crack heads. It is disgraceful what they are doing up there.
While I am on the subject of New South Wales let me quote another article headed `Mineral search in proposed park area'. It says:
The Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Pickard, has granted mining exploration leases in an area which the Government considered making a marine national park.
That is near the Solitary Islands near Coffs Harbour.
The islands are the breeding grounds for many seabirds and the Government . . .

These are the sorts of things that are now going on in New South Wales. One can only imagine what would happen if a Liberal-National Government got into power federally. The place would be opened up for mining. There would be developments all along the coast. Nothing would be left sacred. As the right honourable backbench member from New England said, 40-odd per cent of Australia is locked away. That would all be opened up, and very soon mining and exploration would be going on there, and further areas of Australia would be ruined.

I could speak for many hours on this subject-conservation is close to my heart. However, I realise that many people are in their rooms waiting to get home, the lights are going out, so I think that I have got the message to quit.
Debate (on motion by Mr Fife) adjourned.
House adjourned at 12.03 a.m. (Thursday).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Department seeking to acquire a vessel to service navigational aids?
(2) what are the details of the vessel to be acquired?
(3) Will the vessel be acquired through public tenders?
(4) How will those tenders be selected?
(5) How will consultants be employed; if so, will the consultancy be open to public tender?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department has proposed replacement of the three ageing vessels, with one modern vessel.

(2) The vessel as proposed would incorporate features appropriate to future operational requirements. The proposed vessel is similar in size to the existing vessels, will carry state of the art navigation and ship control equipment and include the capability to work with helicopters. it will also comply with Maritime Industry Development Committee Guidelines in respect to crewing.
Performance criteria and user requirements are set out in the Department's document entitled:
``Invitation to Register Interest to Construct a Vessel that will service Marine Navigation Aids Around Australia-DOT 139''.
(3) If it is decided that a new vessel will be built, the public tendering process will be followed.

(4) Invitation to register interest in building a new vessel has been published and closed on 28 March 1989. A short list will be prepared based on the responses to the request for expressions of interest. In addition the second hand ship market is being re-examined to see if there are existing vessels that may be suitable for conversion to a navigation aids vessel.
(5) The consultancy firm of Barnes and Fleck Pty Ltd were engaged by the Department to assist in the project. The consultancy was let following public tender.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 7 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What arrangements are being made to determine air servicing agreements between Australia and Taiwan.
(2) Have negotiations between Australia and Taiwan commenced; if not, why not.
(3) If negotiations have commenced, (a) how are they progressing and (b) when is an agreement expected.
(4) Is he able to say whether any agreement involving Taiwan's national airline will be reciprocal to Qantas.
(5) What steps are being taken to ease standing visa restrictions on Taiwanese tourists wishing to visit Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Any consideration of the establishment of an air link between Australia and Taiwan would take place against the background of terms of Australia's acceptance of the government in Beijing as the sole legal government of China and our acknowledgement of its claim that Taiwan is a province of China. The Chinese government considers that establishment of an air link with Taiwan is a matter concerning China's sovereignty and that countries must consult with China before proceeding. The issue has been raised with the Chinese government.

(2) to (4) No. There can be no formal government-to-government negotiations or air services agreement between Australia and Taiwan, as Australia does not have any official relations with the authorities on Taiwan. Commercial aviation interests in Australia and Taiwan are nevertheless consulting about whether it might be possible to establish air services in the absence of such an agreement. It is too early to speculate on the outcome of these discussions.

(5) Visitor visas for Taiwanese are assessed in the same way as those of other applicants. Because Australia has no representation in Taiwan, applications are assessed and visas issued by officers based at the Australian Consulate-General in Hong Kong. The Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) in Taipei, which is operated by the Australian Chamber of Commerce, provides a visa facilitation service which expedites the movement of documentation between Taipei and Hong Kong.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many individuals (a) have been investigated and (b) are presently being investigated by the Special Investigation Unit as possible defendants under the amendments to the War Crimes Act made by the War Crimes Amendment Act 1988.
(2) Of those individuals who have been investigated (a) how many will be charged, (b) how many will not be charged and (c) when will the first charge be made.
(3) How many individual cases have been sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) for a decision whether to prosecute or not.
(4) How many of the individual cases sent to the DPP (a) will and (b) will not be the subject of a prosecution.
(5) When will committal proceedings begin in the first prosecution to be brought under the amendments to the War Crimes Act made by the War Crimes Amendment Act 1988.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The SIU has opened 564 files, each relating to an allegation that a particular individual has committed a war crime, or crimes. As at 10.4.89, 78 of those files have been closed as the individual the subject of the allegation was found to be deceased. A further 211 files have been suspended, that is, no further investigation is to be made of the allegation.

(b) A further 275 files relating to individual persons are in various stages of investigation. It is anticipated that as a result of a review shortly to be conducted by the Director a significant further number of investigations will be suspended.
(2) (a), (b) and (c)-Not Known at this stage.
(3) None.
(4) Not known at this stage.
(5) Not known at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he been briefed on any matter concerning the National Safety Council of Australia (Victorian Division); if so, (a) on what date or dates was he so briefed, (b) what was the substance of the briefing, and (c) as a result, (i) did he acquire any knowledge of any link between Mr J. Friedrich, the former chief executive of the Division, or the Division itself, and any defence and intelligence organisations and (ii) what is the substance of any such link.

(2) Is he able to say whether there are any consequences for Australia's security resulting from recent events concerning the finances of the National Safety Council (Victorian Division); if so, what are they.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have been briefed by officers in my portfolio on the extent of past contact between portfolio officials and the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia. I have also been briefed on allegations made to officials within my portfolio concerning the NSCA (Victorian Division) and Mr Friedrich. These briefings took place in the context of, and after the commencement of, recent publicity concerning that organization.

To my knowledge there has been no link between Mr Friedrich or the NSCA (Victorian Division) and any intelligence organization for which I am responsible. There may have been isolated contacts with the NSCA (Victorian Division) at the technical level, but apart from one meeting involving NSCA (Victorian Division) equipment capability, no specific instances have been identified.
(2) On the basis of information presently available to me, I do not believe so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Security Intelligence Organization (ASIO) report on 29 January 1986 that Valeriy Nikalayevich Zemskov, who was about to take up the post of Minister-Counsellor in the Soviet Embassy in Canberra, was a member of the KGB Special Reserve.
(2) Was ASIO's report in the hands of the then Department of Foreign Affairs before Mr Zemskov departed from the Soviet Union for Australia on 30 January 1986.
(3) Since its report of 29 January 1986, did ASIO receive any information tending to suggest that the conclusion in its report was other than correct.
(4) Is it a fact that Mr Zemskov, having been identified as a member of the KGB Special Reserve, was allowed to remain in Australia for approximately three years.
(5) What steps have been taken since 30 January 1986 to prevent Australian visas being issued to Soviet bloc diplomats who are known to have an intelligence position or role.
(6) Since 30 January 1986, has ASIO made any other reports to the effect that an applicant for an Australian visa is a member of the KGB Special Reserve or any similar intelligence organisation.
(7) Have any such reports been acted upon; if so, in what way.

(8) What steps has the Attorney-General taken to ensue that ASIO reports on the intelligence connections on applicants for Australian visas are taken more seriously than was the case with its report on Mr Zemskov.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (8) I intend to follow the established practice of successive Commonwealth Governments of not commenting on allegations concerning the Australian Security Intelligence Organization or on matters concerning national security.

Of course, the Leader of the Opposition is always able to consult the Director-General of Security on security matters, in accordance with the provisions of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government given any extension of time to the Special Investigation Unit to carry out its tasks; if so, (a) why does the Unit need this extra time, (b) what extension has been given, (c) when was the extension given, (d) will investigations to be undertaken during the Unit's extended period of operation be into persons other than those being investigated before the extension of time was given and (e) what will be the additional cost of the Unit because of the extension of time.
(2) Why have no prosecutions been made under the amendments to the War Crimes Act made by the War Crimes Amendment Act 1988.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No but the Government is shortly to consider the continued resource needs of the SIU. The Government has on a number of occasions declared that the investigations will be conducted with despatch and that the life of the SIU would be a limited one. This is still the case. There is no statutory time limit on the SIU, but as noted the Government is keeping its continuation under regular review. Mr Greenwood's contract as consultant to the Commonwealth has been extended for a further 12 months from April 1989 to April 1990.
(2) Investigations are continuing.
